Defector tells military secrets 

HAMBURG, West Germany (AP) — 
A Soviet pilot who defected to the 
United States has told of the Russians building phony air bases to fool satel­ lite surveillance while they put the real ones underground. Stern m a g azin e reported Wednesday. 
LU Viktor I. Belenko, who flew his 
MIG25 to Japan last September, was also quoted as telling U.S. intelligence in te rro g a to rs that Soviet m ilita ry authorities are plagued by severe troop morale problems that led to numerous suicides. 
Stem said its information came from a U.S. Central Intelligence Agency report on Belenko and quoted him as saying that so-called “cold belts" are buried in the, ground above the hidden bases to screen them from infrared cam eras which can detect heat from 

 troops and e qu ip m en t. T he b a se s, housing thousands of men, are linked to runways by tunnels as much as 3o miles long. Stern said. 

Coupled with the u n d e rg ro u n d installations are fake air bases above ground with empty buildings and mock planes, designed to mislead Western intelligence. Stern said. It added that since Belenko revealed the existence of the fake bases, 134 of them have been identified in Siberia by Pentagon ex­ perts. most of them near the Chinese border. 

The pilot reportedly told the CIA that every two months 12 m em bers of his unit were flown to temporary duty at one of the decoy air bases to move the aircraft mockups around and simulate activity to fool Chinese air patrols and 

U S. experts studying sa te llite p ic ­ tures. 

Belenko defected to Japan last Sept. 
6. providing Western intelligence of­ ficials with their first close look at the advanced supersonic M1G25. The plane was d ism a n tle d and an a ly z e d by 
American experts before being crated up and handed back to highly p e r ­ turbed Soviet officials. 

In weeks of questioning by the CIA 
Belenko revealed 4.ooo Soviet military secrets that will require the North At­ lantic Treaty Organization to m ake major changes in Western air defense strategy’, the magazine claimed. 

‘ Details included sizes of flight squadrons, positions of underground missiles, command centers and atomic 

 bomb depots, sites of attack and alarm aircraft and secret codes from Belen­ ko’s squadron." the magazine said. 

“ But the questioners w ere really stunned when (Belenko) ... described how brittle the fighting morale of the individual units is and how hard daily life is in general for the Soviet arm y," it added. 

Stern quoted him further as saying there were “ two to five suicide a t ­ tempts per month in our 4o-man bar­ ra c k s d u rin g the gloom y w in te r months." 
“ Bunk neig hbo rs of su ic id e s a u ­ tomatically received seven days con­ finement for failure to provide help. 
With this penalty they tried to force us

Gonzalez resigns as probe chairm an 

U.S. 
Rep. 
H enry B. 
G onzalez 
Wednesday resigned as chairman of the Select Committee on A ssassina­ t e s . 

The congressman, confined to his 
San Antonio home with the flu. cited lack of support from the House lea­ dership. 
Notification of his resignation was sent by Gonzalez in letters dated 
March I to House Speaker Thomas P. 
(Tip) O’Neill and House M ajority 
Leader Jim Wright. 

O'Neill, meanwhile in Washington, said the resignation would have to be considered by the full House, raising the prospect of a divisive floor fight. 
The speaker said lie would not sub­ mit the resignation for a House verdict until lie talked to Gonzalez. 
U.S. Rep. John B. Anderson of Illin­ ois. Republican Conference chairman, added, “ The life of the (assassination) c o m m itte e still hangs by a slim thread." 
Long controversy 

Gonzalez pulled out after nearly a month of controversy with Richard 
S prague, chief counsel to the co m ­ mittee. 
In his letters to the House leader­ ship. Gonzalez said on Feb. 8 Sprague refused to let the com m ittee know which stall positions were least essen­ tial. 
Sprague followed that up, Gonzalez said. “ by convening stall pep rallies generally aimed at maligning me per­ sonally and undermining my authority as chairm an." 
Gonzalez explained since Sprague refused to produce in form atio n on which the committee could make rational budget decisions and pursued a course of action to undermine hun

Salinas, wife subpoenaed 

By BILL MINTZ 
Eagle Pass financier Enrique Salin­ as and his wife have been subpoenaed to testify before a federal grand jury probing South Texas hanking irregu­ larities. 
It was the collapse last June of 
Salinas Citizens State Bunk rn Carrizo 
Springs which triggered a massive probe of South Texas banks by state and federal authorities. 
Along with Salinas, the panel has issued subpoenas to Gretchen Salinas and former Citizens State Bank offi- rials U rban Farrow and Jim Bob 
Nance. 
The panel has scheduled a three-day session beginning next Wednesday. 
The grand jury subpoenas do not mean the four witnesses are possible targets of prosecution. 

Hill says more Texas banks hare problems* Tape SA 

The subpoenas only indicate federal prosecutors believe the witnesses can shed light on matters under investiga­ tion 
Shortly after the bank closed last summer, bank examiners revealed that as much as $2 I million worth of loans were made to Salinas, his family and hank officials. 
The investigators reported the hank issued a certificate of deposit lo Mr. and Mrs. Salinas, who pledged it as partial security on a $l(Ml.3(M) Citizens 
Slate loan to Alex Short, a secretary to the family. 

But the examiners reported Salinas used the certificate to get a loan from another hank 
In a congressional subcom m ittee hearing held here in December. Nance testified loans made to members of a previous group of hank owners placed 
Citizens State in a d i p te r o u s situa­ tion 
Nance is a former executive vice president of the hank. 
He identified the previous ownership group as Dr. Jam e s Batterie, Hon 
Bramble, Willard Merlz and William 
Harris. 
, 

He testified loans were made to members of the ownership group and to members of their families. 
Salinas told the committee he lost $3 million to $4 million when the bank was closed by the state hanking com­ missioner. 
The examiners said they traced the money and found it went to Salinas’ 
Bonsai Corp. 
The exam iners said Salinas told them lie would repay the loans himself. 
The hank examiners also reported a 
887.abn loan to F arrow . who at the time was a director of Citizens State 
Federal sources indicate the grand jury probably will not conclude its investigation next week.

NAIROBI, Kenya — P resid en t Idi 
Amin s security forces swept through the Ugandan countryside Wednesday, k s y s te m a tic a lly sla y in g L ango and * 
Acholi trib e s m e n in a sc o u rg e a p ­ p ro a c h in g g e n o c id e , a c c o rd in g to ™ 
Ugandans fleeting across the border. 
T he re fu g e e a c c o u n ts w ere con- l l firmed by Western intelligence sources | and, in some cases, by telephone in- | terv iew s with foreign d iplom ats in I 
Kampala. 
T hey said a 5,ooo-man “ d e a th I 
'squad” is conducting a door-to-door ■ search for intended victims in some I parts of Uganda, particularly in the B f northern areas native to the two tribes. I 
In Kampala, they said, all govern- I ment ministries were following Amin’s I orders to compile lists of Lango and 
Acholi civil servants, M akerere Uni* I versify was being purged of professors I and students belonging to the tribes, I and all foreign telephone links were I being tapped. 
The refugees telling of the organized massacre, including two former close advisers to Amin and other senior go­ vernment officials, were either Acholi or Lango. Som e said they w ere eyewitnesses to m urders 
All available accounts said Amin’s security forces were running amok in the northern provinces, killing and lmittng at will. 
The 5oo-house Acholi v illag e of 
.Akoro — the home of tonner President 
Milton Obote, overthrown by Amin rn 
1971 — was reported burned to the ground last week and every Bereon in it. including women and c h ild re n , killed. 
Marked for death 
One senior government official, an 
Acholi and one-time confidant of Amin. escaped to Kenya Wednesday and told of his last week in Uganda. Knowing he was marked for death, he slept in a different bed each night, hid in g a r­ ages by day and dressed like a peasant to avoid recognition. 
“ Amin is destroying in a few days what it took Uganda 8o years to build," the official said “ But everyone, even the ministers who recognize the m ad­ ness that is going on, is too scared to do

S A N A N T O N I O EXPRESS-— Thursday March 3 1977 
Angry streaker stripped o f slapstick charge 

A streaker s sly try to strike back against a slap on the backside struck nut Wednesday. 
It all beguin at the e-nd of a long, hot afternoon at a cricket game in 
Auckland. New Zealand. 
Australian cricket captain 
Greg 

( happen was ready when the third streaker of the day bounded across the field during a match last Satur­ day. 
A fluid, wristy slash of the bat across the naked runner's backside sent him scampering for the stands 

Wednesday the Auckland assis­ tant police commissioner ruled 
( happen had played a fair stroke and refused to prosecute him for assault. 
Streaker Leonard McCauley. 23. was fined for disorderly behavior —

' B l u e Eyes' dubs 

 ne ie tooth fairy 

F*resldent Carter has gained a new nickname from singer Frank 
Sinatra. 

At a sell-out chanty concert in 
London’s Royal Albert Hall. Sinatra let the audience, which included 
Princess Margaret, in on his latest nickname for Carter. 

Sinatra said. “ I bring regards from the Colonies and from our 
President — the tooth fairy.” 
Beer baron’s son sentenced 
Peter Busch. 21, son of the heat/ of Anheuser-Busch Inc., has been sentenced to five years probation in connection with the shooting death last year of David Leekcr. 23 
Leeker was shot in the face and killed Feb. IO. 1976. while he was an overnight guest at the Busch man­ sion in Clayton, Mo. 
The elder Leeker is president of the So Good Potato Chip Co. 
One provision in Busch's proba­ 

 tion stipulates that he must not be permitted to handle fire-arms dur­ ing the five-year period. 
Busch, whose father is 
August 
Busch Jr.. board chairman of the brewing company, said the shooting was accidental and later pleaded guilty to manslaughter. 
The suspended sentence and pro­ bation was handed down by St. 
Louis County Circuit Judge Harry 
Stussie.

High thief takes man’s ogle aid 

Roanoke Va., police are looking for a burglar who might best be described as a lOth-story man. 

The thief climbed 15o feet Monday night to the top of a T-erane at the building site of a 1o-story parking garage, police said, then broke into the crane operator's control gondo­ la. 

Operator Mike Young. 25, said the burglar took his binoculars and a stereo tape player. 
Young said he kept the binoculars on hand “for checking out women." 
Down, but not out 

Trumpeter 
Danny Davis per­ formed from a wheelchair at a concert Wednesday night in Plant 
City, Fla. 

Davis, leader of the band. “The 
Nashville Brass," was released from the hospital Saturday after undergoing a hernia operation. 

Hughes flaunted wealth to win foreign favors 

WASHINGTON — The late Howard Hughes, on the run from a tax investigation in the United States, used his enormous wealth to court landlords abroad. 

SS benefits ruled unfair 

LOS ANGUIS ’ IMIS S o v ie t 
W ASHING TO N - The Su­ preme Court declared Wednes­ day that it was unconstitutional tn treat men differently from women in granting survivors retirement benefits under Social 
Security. 
In a 5-to-4 decision, the court struck down a law that provided benefits au­ tomatically to aged widows — regard­ less of their dependency — but re­ 

 quired widowers seeking benefits to prove that at least half their support had come from their deceased wives. 
Tile majority concluded this was sex discrimination. But the five justices couldn’t agree among them selves whether it was discrimination against men ne discrimination against women. 
In an.' event, said the majority, the law s distinction between men and women claimants was based on ‘‘ar­ chaic and overbroad generalizations" and "old notions" that women were more economically dependent than 

 another 

 danish 

 import 

6951 Son Ptdro, residential 344-2338, commercial 341-1691 

 men. 
The four dissenting justices con­ tended there was nothing wrong with a law that favored w idows and cited data to show married women were far more likely to be dependent than married men. 
Defeat 
The decision was a defeat for the 
Department of Health, Education and 
Welfare. It had warned that if the law was overturned it could raise Social 
Security costs by $447 million annual­ ly. 
In arguments before the court, a go­ vernment attorney had charged that the widower who brought the case was trying to "ride the skirtlails" of the women’s rights movement. 
The ruling was another in a series of recent decisions by the justices that has steadily narrowed the permissible limits of laws based oil sex distinc­ tions. 
Earlier this term, the court struck down an Oklahoma law that permitted women to buy beer at age 18 but made men wait until they were 21. 
In 1975. it invalidated a law provid­ ing Social Security survivors benefits to women with children but not to men. 
And in 1973. it struck down a federal law requiring female members of the armed services prove their husband s dependency in order to receive a dependency allowance that male ser­ vice members drew automatically for their wives. 
Impact 
The court’s decision Wednesday, authorities agreed, is likely to have significant impact on the Social Se­ curity system. 
HEW. in its brief to the eourt. noted that an identical provision requiring men to prove dependency for hus­ band's retirement insurance benefits 

 under Social Security already had been held unconstitutional in other cases decided in lower courts. Presumably, the court's decision 
Wednesday upholds those rulings. 
It is changes in both the husband's and widower s benefits plans that could cost up to $447 million a year, according to HIM. 
An expert on Social Security, Dr. 
Rita Ricardo Campbell of the Hoover 
Institution at Stanford University, predicted Weednesday there would be 
"extraordinary expense" if men from now on are automatically granted the benefits women are receiving. 
Dr. Cam pbell, a m em ber of the 
Quadrennial Advisory Council on 
Social Security, also said that if the government instead decides to make women prove dependency like men there would be "administrative ha­ voc.” 
The best solution, she said, might be to phase out both the spouses’ and the widows’ and widowers' benefits pro­ grams over a long period of time. 

First, he flew to the Bahamas where he dangled the dollars in front of 
Prime Minister Lynden Pindling. The billionaire offered to bail out a bank­ rupt hotel and operate it as a luxury casino in the Bahamas. As part of the deal, he spoke of "financial support" for the prime minister. 
This reference in the secret Hughes papers indicates that the money would go to Pindling personally. But spokes­ man for both the Pindling government and the Hughes organization vigorous­ ly denied it. 
Any such otter, they said. must have meant “ financial support" for the Ba­ hamas. not Pindling personally. They point out that, in any case. Hughes never opened the casino. 
Pot bellied controler 
Hughes’ next home away from home was Managua. Nicaragua, which is the fiefdom of A nabasin Somoza. The pot-bellied ruler controls every prof itablc industry in his tiny nation, from cattle farms and hotels to laundromats and houses of prostitution. 
He has an interest in the shoe fac­ tories. the cigarette companies, even the parking meters. The Somoza fa­ mily has acquired just about half the country’s private property. 
Hughes offered to help the Big 
Banana save another of his pet busi­ nesses, Nicaragua's national airline. A secret memo, outlining the airline deal, reminded Hughes pointedly: 
“ Nicaragua could be your alternate home." 
All Somoza would require, the memo suggested, would be "a 12-hour no­ tice." 
_ 
The late tycoon never made it as fur as Costa Rica. But 
President Jose Figueres, who was reported to be having personal financial diffi­ culties, was attracted to someone solvent. 
Early in 1974, he invited the financial fugitive Robert Ves- — ——— co to hide out in Costa Rica. Of course. cl Presidente expected Vesco to bring his ill-gotten millions along with him. 
F igueres also began to feel the same strange attraction for Hughes. 
On March 4. 1974. Figueres wrote to the recluse oil presidential stationery. 
"I have read about you.” he began. "I know you have no problem of residence iii any country at this time, but nevertheless. I want to offer you the hospitality of Costa Rica. 
Freedom with security 
"Our country offers a wholesome climate and a great deal of individual freedom with security.” The letter was delivered to Hughes, along with a me­ mo from his attorney, Chester Davis, pointing out that Vesco had already

An Illinois State University bioche­ mist says he's trying to unlock some of the secrets of aging with just that thought in mind.

AUSTIN, Tex. (AP) — 
The 
Texas 
Supreme 
Court refused Wednesday to let Soul ll western Bell 
Telephone Co. impose temporarily the $298.3 million rate increase denied It by the Texas 
Public 
Utility 
Commission. 
Bell had proposed to post a boud guaranteeing repayment of the rates charged if it lost its ap­ peal of the commission order granting only $57 8 million in increases. 
Hallelujah 
"My one-line comment on the court s action is. 
‘Hallelujah.’" said Att). 
Gen John Hill, who had opposed Bell's request. 
John Dee Lawrence, a lawyer for Bell, issued a statement saying (lie firm was “disappointed" about the decision and said the matter will in* pursued in slate district court at Austin. 
Disappointed 
"We are disappointed that (he Supreme Court 
I did not chooM* to rule on 
I important issues that will 
IHA go away aud that must be laved at s o m e point in tin* future " la»w relict* said 
I hose q u e s tio n s bear directly on tin nlahiv ot 
Texas u tilitie s un helm.} 
Southwestern Bet! to 

I cornuto* prov Ming quail 
Iv Utility serv lee til th e 

"The increased reven­ ues ordered by the Public 
Utility Commission for 
Southwestern Bell arc not sufficient and arc confiscatory , in our opin­ ion. Therefore, we will continue to pursue all legal avenues available to us because our need for additional revenues is real.” lie added. 

Appeal 

The telephone c o m ­ pany’s appeal of the com m ission order is pending before sta le 
District (ourt Judge 
James Meyers of Austin, ulio had refused to give 
Bell any temporary relief 
Bell asked the supreme court to command 
Meyers to grant a tem ­ porary restraining order and to hold an immediate hearing on a temporary injunction 
The request was denied w it boul comment 
Hie eourt did nut issue an opinion on a major question of law raised by 
Bell aud iii six fi tend ut tin* eourt briefs, includ­ ing those flied bv Lone star Gas. General Tele* phone and Dallas Power 
A Light. 
Meyers had ruled tie could co n si de i only w (tether lh** commission acted i ii a ccord an ce with the evidence ii received 
In more titan a mouth of 

Dr. Arian C. Richardson. 35. said that so far medicine has been able to prolong life, but hasn’t always been successful in prolonging a lift* worth liv tug. 
"Medicine," he said, "has not treat­ ed aging, but merely its symptoms. In many cases, death is only postponed to permit an extended period of misery and dependency at tilt* end of a per­ son s life." 

Grant 

Richardson has a $1oo.IHM) grant from the National Institute on Aging to con­ tinue Ins studies lit* said Wednesday he Iio|k*s lo Ik* able lo treat aging as any disease is treated — so it eau In* retarded. 
"Aging is not lilt* passage of time. 
Aging is due to something that hap­ pens during that passage of time." he said. 
Richardson noted that protein is an essential ingredient iii all 
UR* processes aud that aging is caused by a decrease in the manufacture of protein in the cell as it gels older. 
He said he believes the decrease in protein synthesis may stem from a decrease iii the amount of messenger ribonucleic acid (inRNA) produced as j cell gets older. The m olecule. inRNA. directs the synthesis of protein 
III tile cell 

 in RN A 

“We are trying to find uut how lo prevent a decrease iii mKNA. or how to increase it," said Richardson. "We think our research is the first on record lo explore the link between decreased protein synthesis and decreased mKNA in the cell. ll could begin to unl<H*k the secrets of aging." 
Richardson also mentioned a theory that aging may In* built into each ceil as a part of its genetic code "It may be that organisms are genetically pro­ grammed lo self destruct over lune," lie said "Our research may lead to an understanding of such an aging code*’ aud lo ways that it can in* altered lo prolong active life."

RH 

 made the move from the Bahamas to 
Costa Rica. 
But Hughes remained in the Baha­ mas where lie apparently received en­ couragement from Prim e Minister 
Pindling. The secret Hughes papers contain several references to Pindling familiarly as the I'M. 
An Aug. H. 1974. letter from Hughes to Davis finally got down to cases. 
“Regarding the Honorable PM,” wrote 
Hughes. "I truly admire his courage and the actions lie has been brave en­ ough to lake." 
Presumably, this was a reference to 
Pindling’s favorable attitude toward 
Hughes and his projects. 
"I urge you to tell him this,” Hughes instructed his attorney. "I would like to be of assistance. The question is: 
Flow much assistance does he need and how quickly? 
"It is very obvious to me, and I say again that he has been very coura­ geous, and we both know this costs 

7 would like to be o f assistance. 
The question is: How much as- sistance does he (the Bahamas prime minster) need and how quick Ivy' 

 money, or credit, or financial support in one way or another. I repeat, how much of this does he need and on what kind of time schedule?" 
The secret papers indicate that Pin- dling was willing to deal with Hughes, but the negotiations eventually broke dew n. 
The phantom industrialist next ap­ peared in Nicaragua, where he set up housekeeping on an entire hotel floor provided bv Somoza. Later. Hughes moved into Somoza s private head­ quarters. 

Strong cash bond 
The billionaire reciprocated for this roy al treatment in cold cash, buying 25 per cent of Somoza’s airline. When 
Somoza sought more financial support from Hughes, it merely strengthened the bond between them. 
A top Hughes aide wrote warmly: 
“ Meeting with Somoza. invite him as 
H.K.H.'s guest to Las Vegas or any other big city in the U.S. Fly him in an exec. type jet." 
Unhappily. Somoza was losing mon­ ey «>n his airline, which was paying 
$65,UUU a mouth on a British loan. 
Hughes was informed. 
But the men around Hughes found 
Somoza to be their kind of dictator. 
"Somoza is a benevolent dictator, and he is still the most popular ruler in 
Latin A m erica." a top aide wrote glowingly to Hughes. "He has excel­ lent connections in the United Stales on both sides — Democratic and Republi­ can.’' 
B the higher Som oza’s airliners soared, the lower the profits plunged. 
To intice more cash from Hughes. 
Sonioza offered him an interest in a plywood factory, pharmaceutical plant or real estate. 
Asked for too much 
Soinoza s requests placed a strain on the friendship between the dictator and the billionaire. 
“ The General (Somoza) called to- day. and I did not take the cull.’* an aide reported. “ He obviously wants to know your reaction to our meeting. 
"Since lie feels he is in deep finan­ cial trouble vv uh (the airline) — do you want to bail out and forefeight (sic) your stock? Are you interested iii helping him financially save the airline?" 
As a refuge lur billionaires, banana republics can Ik* expensive.

AUSTIN — Texas Atty. den. John 
Hill told a House com m ittee here 
Wednesday conditions which led to the collapse of Citizens State Bank of 
Carrizo Springs currently exist in several other Texas banks.

Brow ns\ ilk*.

, in federal prison for his role in a conspiracy to import 832 pounds 
'.'of m arijuana into the I’.S. 
C S. Bist. Judge John ll Wood Jr. added a lU-year special parole term to the maximum prison sentence.

,. Saver. 
• • 1

.icourt in Corpus Christi Monday on a docket call for an 11-count marijuana c onspiracy in d ic tm e n t and a bond jumping charge.

Muniz iii that country and turned him over to I .S. officials Christmas Day at 
„ the International Bridge in Laredo

Eight more jail guards to face polygraph tests 

Hill told the panel "insider transac­ tions, mismanagement and acquisition of the bank which was deterimental to the bank and the public” led to Citi­ zens State Bank's June 28. 197o col­ lapse. 

Not unique 

"U nfortunately, our investigation has revealed the situation at tile Citi­ zens State Bank was not unique. Simi­ lar conditions exist in several other 
Texas banks.” Hill said. 

Alter traeing the history of Citizen's elosing and the lengthy court action which followed. Hill said "the closing of any bank not only creates unneces­ sary h ard sh ip s for the public, but further diminishes public confidence 

 iii our state banking system. 

"This situation is exacerbated when bauk regulatory authorities are unable to immediately pay off the bank's de­ positors. 

"The litigation also caused public monies to be frozen in the bank (Citi­ zens State), which resulted in the ina­ bility of governmental units to meet their obligations, including the pay­ ment of employes' salaries.” 

‘Rent-a-bank’ 

Hill said the Citizens State Bank ease 
" w a s my introduction to what has be­ come known as the Texas Rent-A- 
Bank Scandal."' 
Based on the Citizens State Bank in­ vestigation. Hill told the panel "there is a pressing need for effective legis­ lation to provide the slate Banking 
Department with the power to review and pass on changes in tin* ownership of state banks. 
" At a minimum,” he said. "a person acquiring control of an existing state bank should be subject to essen­ tially the same requirements as lo fin­ ancial stalkily and managerial ability as provided for applicants tot new bank charters. 

Regulate 

"Such a statute must have effective provisions to permit the Bunking De­ partm ent to effectively regulate ae* quistion by persons more interested in speculation than banking.” 

Hill said IIB1212 "should effectively protect the public against the kind of abuses revealed at Carrizo Springs and' promote the public’s confidence in the banking industry." 

The bill was referred to subcell)- uittee.

'She was either killed or sh e’s being h eld ...’ 

Stinson 

Diana Kaiser disappeared eight weeks ago today. 

.About 3:3o a.in. on Jan. ti, the 
21-year-old woman was d riving down Highway 39 just north of 
Wharton when she looked into the rearview mirror of lier white Chevy 
Luv truck and saw red lights flash­ ing. 
Sin* pulled over and then cit bei­ gel out of the truck lo see why she had been stopped or was forced out. 
She hasn’t been seen since. 
Truck drivers who passed the two vehicles recalled later that the car with the red lights was a dark color 
— probably brown — and had three radio antennas sticking up in back 
Free Spirit 
They figured a county mountie had caught "Free Spirit" (Diana’s 
CB handle) aud was giving her some green stamps for speeding. So they didn't stop to ask questions ci­ bol her to jot down a license number. 
Wharton County Sheriffs Depart­ ment ( apt. Karl Winebrenncr. who examined the abandoned truck later that day. found no signs of a strug­ gle. 
“ I ll be perfectly honest with you. 
At first I thought maybe she had just run off.” he said Wednesday, during a telephone interview. 
"But I cheeked her background pretty thoroughly, and I've eon- eluded she just wasn’t the type to do something like that. 
"I think whoever forced her off the road talked her into getting out of her ear and...” (He didn t finish the sentence.) 
"She was a heavy sm oker.” lie said, “ but her cigarettes wert* still in the truck. That’s why I think she didn't plan to be gone long." 
Foul play 
Once Winebrenncr was convinced foul play might be involved, he be­ gan building a file of information on the missing woman: 
Description: 
White female, age 
21, green eves. sh o u ld e r-le n g th dark brown hair. 3'9", 14o lbs., last seen wearing a black or navy blue blouse, blue jeans, red, white arid blue trac k shoes, a turquoise ring, a silver cross necklace and a white leather jacket with colored embroi­ dery trim. 
Family background: One of five children of a well-known Yoakum businessman, Leslie Kaiser. 
Residence: 
At the time of her disappearance, Diana was living in 
Victoria, where she was employed by a truc k company. 
"She had been working for the firm several months picking up 

 mud samples at oil-drilling sites.” said Winebrenncr. 
"S h e whs on her way b a c k to 
Victoria from a d eliv ery run to 
Houston when she disappeared." 
Red lights 
The ear with the antennas and red lights remains the only significant c lue to the mystery. 
"We've checked a lot of leads on the ear, but we’ve had no luck so far," said Winebrenncr. 
Iii Yoakum. Diana’s parents are realistic about the* situation. 
"I'm sure she was either killed or she’s being held somewhere.” Mrs. 
Kaiser said Wednesday. "After two months, i f s hard to have m uch hope. 
"A truck driver called Sunday and said he* thought lit* saw lier iii 
Brackettville, and we’re trying to check that out." 
The Kaisers and ( apt. Winebrcn- ner have been receiving such tips ever since* D i a n a ’s fam ily and friends began d is tr ib u tin g th o u ­ sands of handbills describing the m issin g wom an and o fferin g a 
SLIMM! reward for information lead­ ing to her whereabouts. 
The truck drivers, whom "F r e e 
Spirit” chatted with on her CB radio during delivery rounds, "have been great to put the circulars iii motels and truck stops everywhere they go." said Mrs. Kaiser. 
"We've had reports from as far away as California from people who saw them." 
Bus station 
The best lead took ( apt. Wine- brenner to a Houston Inis station, where Diana had reportedly been seen. 
"I waited a couple of hours, anti sure enough a girl walked in who looked enough like her to be her sister.” said the 28-year-old officer. 
* - Hut it was a girl from Brazoria 
County.” 
So Diana Kaiser s whereabouts are still unknown. 
However, W in eb ren n er figures that somewhere in South Texas a fireman or a law enforcement of­ ficer or a ( Ber who has rigged red lights atop his ear knows where she is. 
He and the Kaiser family hope that someday soon the driver of the cur that forced Diana off the road will e ith e r c o m e f o rw a rd or be turned in by an informant. 
Anyone with information about the vehicle or the missing woman should call the sheriff’s department in Wharton — AC 713 - 532-155o. 
" U n til we get a b r e a k . " said 
W in e b re n n e r, " w e ’re at a d ead end."

SAN ANTO NIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 
Carter cuts military aid only slightly 

Saudi rocket sale studied 
Freight Damaged & Odd Lot Mdse 

WASHINGTON (AP) — The ( a r t e r adm inistra­ tion is reviewing the sale of 65(1 Maverick TV-guided missiles to Saudi Arabia, Secretary of State Cyrus 
R. Vance told Congress Wednesday. 
Other U.S. officials said, meanwhile, that a $1.4 billion deal the desert kingdom has with Raytheon 
Corp. for SHO improved Hawk missiles is also being re-examined. 
In making a decision on the Mavericks. Vance told a House Appropriation* subcommittee, the admin­ istration will be guided by whether: 
• The weapons are essential to the Saudi Arabia's security. 
• The sale would upset the a rm s balance in the 
Middle East. 
• The sale would contribute to peace between the 
Arabs and Israel. 
“ We are applying the sa m e rules to each and every request, whether it is from the A rabs or 
Israel," Vance said. 
Last month the administration lifted the sale of concussion bombs to Israel. Other weapons deals with Israel and the Arab states are also understood to be under review. 

 the proposed aid levels changed little from those of the current fiscal year. J 
Before leaving office. 
President Ford had su g­ g ested $976 million in m ilita ry aid and the revised p r o p o s a ls r eleased 
W edn esday called for $973 million for 
49 recipient countries. 
Proposed 
U . S . -fin­ anced credit s a l e s to 
Greece were in creased by $13 million to $14o million, reflecting what officials said was the an* „ ticipatcd approval of a five-year base agreement 
- worth $7oo million. 

Turkey 

Turkey, which is due to receive $1 billion under.'!? a five-year b a s e agreement still subject to congressional approval. was earmarked for $2oo million in the next fiscal * year, up $5o million from the current level. 
Taiwan would receive^? 
$23 million, down $ 1 o * million from this year. £ 
O fficials left open t h e * * p ossibility that t h e * decrease was related, in J * part, to U.S. hopes for an improved re la tio n sh ip ' with the People’s Repub-*v lie of China. Another in-, flueneing facto r, they said , was 
T a i w a n ' s growing ability to pay its own way. 
Despite the a d m i n i s ­ tration’s expressions of deep concern over the human rights situation in 
South Korea, there was no change in the $275 million which is in effect for this year. 

WASHIN GTON (A P ) 
— The State Department ii nveiled on Wednesday m ilita ry a s s i s t a n c e proposals that s u g g e s t 
President Carter’s e m ­ phasis on human rights abroad will have little impact on sales of Amer­ ican arms to foreign na­ tions. 
Except for previously announced cutbacks in aid to 
A rgen tin a, 
Uruguay and Ethiopia.

Volunteer army called a failure 

WASHINGTON (AP) - A congres­ sional study described the all-volun­ teer military force as a failing exper­ iment. touching off a 
S e n a t e committee debate Wednesday on al­ ternatives! 
The debate centered on a program of national service, either compulsory or voluntary, to enlarge the pool of po­ tential recruits for the military as well as other public service work. 
The study found that the Army and 
Marin e C o rp s are fallin g short in recruiting, and reserv e forces are greatly under strength. 
It concluded that difficulties and costs will mount iii the future as the pool of 18-year old males declines, un­ employment drops, and civilian pay- scales increase. 
The investigation was conducted by 
William R. King, a U n i v e r s i t y of 
Pittsburgh business professor on tem­ porary assignment to the Senate Bud­ get committee. It was released by Sen. 
Sam Nunn, D-Ga., chairm an of the 
Senate Armed Services subcommittee on manpower, at the start of a series of hearings on the all-volunteer force. 
K ing re c o m m e n d e d a s tu d y of alternative service short of a return to universal conscription which was dropped in rn id-1973. 
He said a backup draft, or a draft for reserve forces only, would be b e n ­ eficial but “ a major new program of 

 national se r v i c e would go m uch further to alleviate the problems which we are currently experiencing." 
King’s report brought some dissent from a panel of academic specialists. 
Martin Binkin of the Brookings In­ stitution said the military could alter manpower policies to improve the out­ look for the all-volunteer force. 
He suggested use of more women in noncombat jobs, tighter screening to reduce turnover, and m ore lenient educational and aptitude standards. 
Richard V. L. Looper of the Rand 
Corporation insisted that the volunteer force "i s a success and is a viable op­ tion for the future.’’ 
Baby dies of auto injuries 

A four-month-old Elmendorf child died Wednesday from injuries received in a Feb. 12 accident in Southeast San 
Antonio. 
J o h n S a u c e d a died W ed n e sd a y morning at Bexar County Hospital, a spokesman said. 
The child was injured in a traffic accident at Gevers Street and Steves 
Avenue. 
The child was a passenger in a vehicle driven by his father. Juan D. 
Sauceda, 26. officers said.

S A N A N T O N I O E X P R E S S — Thursday M arch 3 I 9 7 7 
E xpress colum nist is winner 

San Antonio Express colum­ nist Roddy Stinson has been named a top national winner in the 1976 Jerry Lewis - Muscular 
D ystrophy 
Assn. 
W riting 
Awards competition. 
Stinson was a second place winner tor his column. “ The second time, J. 
( . just ignored the tears " 
The column appeared in the Express on June 15. 1976. 
T he colum n related the poignant m om ent when a volunteer m edical technician, J. C. “ Doc” Thom pson. said good-bye to the children he had helped and befriended at a Texas MUA 

For his effort, Stinson received a plaque and $5oofrom the Muscular Dystrophy 
Association 

 sum m er camp 
In the column, Stinson related how 
Thompson had been told many of the 
55 campers he would be helping would be unable to walk or eat or go to the bathroom by themselves. 

Thompson. Stinson said, had walked away from the crowd as he was getting 

 ready to leave the group at the camp's conclusion because he was crying. 
However, later when one little girl would not let go of his neck after slowly w alking to him, he told her, “ Here comes your mother Dina, guess you have to leave,” Stinson related. 
The column continued: “ Reluctant­ ly, the little girl loosed her hold on her 

 friend. ‘Bye. Doc.’ she said 
“ 'Bye. sug ar.’ said J. C. And this time, he just ignored the drop of water that came out of I he corner of his right eye and started down his cheek toward his red T-shirt.” 
For his effort. Stinson received a plaque and $5(1o from tin' MOA. First place winner was Louis F. Bottine. 
Rochester, N.Y., for an article pub­ lished in the July 2o, 1976. issue o 
Insight Magazine. 
The awards are given annually to jo u rn a lists, s c rip tw rite rs or poets whose work “ fosters better under­ standing of m uscular dystrophy and allied d isord ers and co n trib utes to public support of the effort to conquer these afflictions.

«r th ’«• 
■ neighbors b e s t; crime stoppers—Peters 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursdoy Moreh 3 I 977 
Page 

,4 n— 
— 

9-A 

By DAVID M cLEM O K E 
New courts auf] new laws may help. but good. watchful neighbors are the best crime preventive. Police Chief E. 
E. Peters said Wednesday. 
Peters and Crime Prevention Bureau head Sgt. Fred Whitley were guest speakers to the local chapter of the 
National Exchange Club at the St. 
Anthony Hotel. 
“ We're lucky to see to per cent of the criminals we apprehend ever get into court." Peters said. “ With two new criminal courts added to those already here, maybe we can do something 

 about the other 85 per cent. 
“ New courts are not the total answer, hut it's a lot better than what we've had before. But we still have to count on the citizens to do what they can to prevent crime before it hap­ pens.” 
The* new courts Peters referred to are four new district courts approved for San Antonio by Gov. Dolph Briscoe. 
Whitley briefed the group on the 
( rime Prevention Bureau and how they can use it for consultation on security measures for home and bu­ sinesses. 

“ A good watchful neighbor is the essence of crime prevention," Whit tov said. w 
“ All the bolts, locks and alarms are no good if there's no one around tee hear the burglar and alert the' police.’’ 
Whitley recommended the1 formation of neighborhood groups and their participation in the police depart­ ments crime prevention program. 
Peters noted the governor’s crime prevention legislative package, now before the legislature, will be helpful in deterring crim e, if they're ap­ proved. 

H ouse approves bill on judges’ pay 

CHIEF E. E. PETERS 
C itiz e n s p re v e n t crim e ’ 

EXPRESS CAPITOl BUREAU 
AUSTIN - The* House passed Wednesday, and sent to the Senate, a bill allowing the Bexar Coun­ ty Commissioners Court to sot salaries of county- courl-at-law judges. 
HB5o2 by Rep. Hon 
Bird was passed on third reading by a 113 to 8 vote, with 21 members regis­ tering present but not voting. 
Rep. Jim Nowlin was 

 the only member of the 
Bexar County delegation to vote against the mea­ sure' 
Under Bird's bill, the commissioners court is allowed to sot the eoun- ty-eourt-at-law judges' salaries at a maximum of nine-tenths of the* salary, plus supplem ents, of state d istrict court judges in the* county. 
District court judges currently are paid about 

$35,5oo in annual salary and another $11,ooo in supplements for a total of 
$48,5oo. 
Bird's bill would allow the county court-at-law judges to receive nine- tenths of this or a maxi­ mum of approximately 
$41 .(NMI 
The bill also maintains the current m inim um salary level for county court-at-law judges ol 
$25,ooo annually.

Russians check N-testing 

NCW HOURS 
MON.-SAT. 1o-7 
FRI. 1o-9 

25oo Broadway 1218 S. W. Military Drive 
SPECIAL 

L e a d e r s m e e t 
M A D R ID . 
Spain 
— 
Leaders of Western Eu r­ ope’s major Communist parties met in Madrid for the first time in 4o years 
Wednesday to show soli­ darity with the still-out­ lawed Spanish party and ( to work a common < policy on dissidence in the Soviet bloc. 

 inily wants to make. 
Sakharov went to the 
Moscow People's Court 
Wednesday to press his attempt to move his six- member family from two two-room apartments to one four-room ap art­ ment. All Soviet housing is regulated by the state. 
The court refused lo reverse the housing authorities’ decision. 

 f o l l o w i n g 
P r e s i d e n t 
Carter's meeting with 
Soviet dissident Vladimir 
Bukovsky. 
The news agency Tass issued a brittle and brief report of the meeting from Washington which cited Carter as meeting with a criminal law of­ fender who was expelled from the Soviet Union. 

COPPICED fROM WIRE SERVICES 

G EN EV A — President 
Carter's goal of a prompt agreement to end all nu­ clear testing, under­ ground as well as in the atmosphere, hasbeen ef­ fectively checked, if not checkmated, by the So­ viet Union. 
At Hie United Nations 
Disarm am ent 
Com ­ mittee, which is nearing the end of its 15th year of deliberations here at the 
Palais des Nations, the 
Russians have jumped the gun on the United 
States arid already tabled o draft text of a treaty to ban nuclear testing com­ pletely. 

But it includes one provision which makes ii virtually certain that it will never take effect. 

The Russian proposal simply requires that in order to enter into force the treaty must he signed and ratified by the go­ vernments of all nuclear weapons states — which means France and China in addition to the U.S., 
Russia and Britain. 

The chain es of eit lier the French or the < bin- esc joining in any test- ban agreement are sh re­ mote that this is tanta­ mount to killing oft the idea completely.

SPECIAL 

S A N A N T O N IO EX P R ESS— Thursday March 3 1977 
Poge 11 -A 

Former President Ford waves to fellow skiers as he prepares for several hours of skiing during a snowstorm in Vail, Colo. The Fords will be vacationing in Vail for about a week. 
— AP W irephoto 
'Dirty’ dealers face jail 

COMPILED f r o m WIRT SERVICES 
W A SH IN G T O N 
- 
A gricu ltu re Secretary 
Bub 
Bergland said 
Wednesday that big grain company officials run a good risk of winding up in jail if they \iolate new federal rules against shipping dirty, adulter­ ated wheat and other commodities to foreign buyers. 
“ We're not really in­ terested in levying big fines against these grain companies.” Bergland said in a meeting with a group of farm ers and ranchers. “ W e 'll only charge enough of a fine to pay for the room and board for the time they spend in jail.’' 
Congress passed a new law last year requir­ ing federal takeover of export inspections. The law is designed to correct past abuses of federal grain standards. 
New payroll tax is iii lim bo 

WASHINGTON - The 
Senate Finance Com­ mittee yielded to Carter adm inistration opposi­ tion and decided against raising Social Security payroll taxes this year. 
The panel tentatively went on record in favor of a new tax cut of up to $25o a year for parents of col­ lege students and for doubling an existing tax credit for parents who have to hire babysitters. 
The latter credit — sub­ tracted d irectly from taxes owed — would be raised to a maximum of 
$1 .HIH). 

 d a rte r makes 
K id choice 

W ASHINGTON - Pre­ sident t arter has select­ ed A. Daniel O’Neal. to become new chairman of the Interstate Com­ merce Commission 
It also was reported 
Carter will allow the sue 
* ut the nation's oldest fe­ deral regulatory agency to shrink by attrition to live or seven members from its current statu­ tory membership of ll. 
TX violence is bein*: tritiu m 1*! 

W A SH IN G T O N 
- 
Broadcast executives have testified they arc working hard to reduce violence depicted on television but a noted re­ searcher oil the subject said TV violence has increased sharply. 
George Gerbner. dean 

NATIONAL 
DIGEST 

 of the Annenberg School of Communications at the 
University of Penn syl­ vania. said TV violence has increased in all cate­ gories including family viewing and children’s program tim e on all three networks. The wit­ nesses testified before the House com m unica­ tions subcommittee.

SAN FR A N C ISC O - 
Five auditors from the 
Bailor 
Departm ent's 
Employment Retirement 
Income Security Admin­ istration will begin an audit Monday of the pen­ sion fund of the Interna­ tional Hotel. Motel. Res­ taurant W orkers and 
Bartenders 
Pension 
Fund in Las Vegas. 
Al 
B ra m le l, the 
59-year-old chairman of the fund s trustees, has been reported missing since last Thursday. It was reported the union made real estate loans wiih more than HH per cent of the fund’s assets 
Sewage grants are requested 

WASHINGTON' 
- 
Representatives of coun­ ty and state governments have asked Congress to extend a federal grant program for building and improving sewage treat­ ment plants. 
A spokesman for the 
National Association of 
Counties says about ball of county and city sewage plants will not have fe­ derally approved plans for meeting national treatment standards by lilt* July I deadline.

Panel sees new wave of urban riots 

Our own convenient credit plus Master 
Charge ond Bank Americord

S arotkiris 

W A SH IN G TO N (AIM 
— A government advi­ sory group on Wednesday predicted another siege of urban riots and a con­ tinuing increase in ter­ rorism. The panel urged the nation's police forces to step up intelligence operations and make de­ tailed plans for such emergencies. 
As it is the nation is in a period of false calm, said a report prepared by the Task Force on D i­ sorders and Terrorism. 
Initial reaction to the report was spotty. New 
York Mayor Abraham 
Beanie said his c ity ’s police department “ is al­ ways alert to detect any evidence of terrorism and to take effective steps to deal with it." 
Criticism 

The point of the panel's recommendations is to save lives, said Jerry V. 
Wilson, chairman of the task force and police chief of the District of 

Columbia from 1969 to 
1974. 
In a 661-page report, the group of police of­ ficials and law enfor­ cement specialists said police must prepare to deal with terrorist bombings and kidnap- ings and a new round of disorders similar to the urban and campus dis­ turbances of the 196os and early 197os. 
The task force warned that legislative proposals to restrict intelligence gathering could deprive police of the information they need to stop terror­ ist acts. Wilson said the task force favors w ire­ tapping with court war­ rants to spy on potential terrorists. 
Tactics 

Asked whether the group also supports elec­ tronic surveillance against groups thought to be planning civil dis­ orders. Wilson replied, 
“ generally, no." 

Continued from Page IA shapes, sexes, colors, and occupations. 
Fifteen candidates are younger than 
3o, and 28 are 5o or over. 
Eleven of the candidates are wo­ men, six more than two years ago. 
Occupations range from student to outdoorsman to auctioneer to manage­ ment consultant to weatherman to professor. 
There’s even a journalist, not to mention a writer. Twenty-nine of the candidates are Mexican-American, and near a dozen are black. 
The deadline for signing up to vote in the April city election is Thursday. 
Absentee voting starts March 14 and ends March 29 at five locations, in­ cluding city hall. 
Final day 

Friday is the last day for candidates 
.who have filed to have second thoughts and pull out of the race. 
Those candidates who stay in the race will draw for place at 1:3o p. rn. 
Friday in the City Council chambers. 
Candidates, their ages and occupa­ tions, and the districts in which tinw­ are running follow .

Austin is goal of union march 

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursdoy Morch 3 1977 
Pope 13-A 
Law m akers take the time to hear S.A. historian 

RAYMONDVILLE, 
(A P ) — A sm a ll group of Moxican-Amer- jeans calling themselves the 
T e x a s 
F a r m 
Worker’s Union (TFW ) is hiking to Austin hoping to lay a controversial bill at the feet of the Texas 
Legislature. 
“ We hope to arrive in 
Austin on Palm Sunday 
(April 3 ) .” sa id Tony 
O rendain, the self- professed TFW sp o k e s­ man. “ We have 18 p e r­ sons with us today, but on the w eek en d s w o rk e rs from El P a so to M u le­ shoe will join us.” 
The m arch b egan 
Saturday about 33o miles south of Austin at the San 
.Juan Shrine in the Rio 
Grande Valley, called the 
“ Valley of 
T ears” by 
Orendain.

 conditions, m urder and r e p re ssio n , so-called 
‘right-to-work’ laws, lack' of political and civil rights and human misery have converted the plush and green valleys of the 
Rio Grande into what the farm w o rk ers call the valley of T ears.” reads a pamphlet Orendain sells entitled “ The Struggle of the 
T e x a s 
F a r m 
Worker’s Union." 
Bill 
Orendain and his fol­ lowers also ca rry with them the 34-page bill that would give farm workers unionization and collec­ tive bargaining powers. 
Ile also has a petition supporting the bill with 
“ about 15,ooo to 2o,ooo s ig n a tu r e s and could p o ssib ly triple by the time we get to Austin. 
“ Many people do not want the legislation in­ troduced,” he continued but added the bill has the pledged support of state 
Sen. C arlo s T ru an of 
Corpus Christi and twit state representatives, Ir­ ma Rangel of Kingsville and Gonzalo Barrientos of Austin. 
Orendain also said the bill is an “ almost carbon copy of the 1973 bill passed in California.” 
The 47-year-old union organizer said he became involved with farm workers about 23 y ears ago after meeting Cesar 
Chavez, who championed the cause in California. 
O rendain w as secre- ta r y tr e a s u r e r of the 
United Farm Workers in 
19H7 when Chavez sent 

 him to T e x a s. He h as sin ce form ed his own group, the T exas F arm

T.R. FEHRENBACH legislature ad d re sse s T exas 

EXPKESS CAPITOL BURT AU 
AUSTIN — Law m akers took time out Wednesday to celebrate the 141st birthday of Texas' indepen­ dence highlighted with a speech by San Antonio author and historian T. R. Fehrenbach. 
Fehrenbach. whose 14 books in IO languages include “ Lone Star, Fire and Blood.” and “ Com- m anche” , was invited to address the joint session of the House and Senate by Sen. .John T raeger of 
Seguin. 
“ I have lived in times and places where some have tried to im press me with the unimportance of what we know as the birth of T exas,” Fehrenbach told the packed House cham ber and gallery. 
“ We Texans, however, have a blood memory to live by. 
“ I have a blood memory of courage and sustained 

 hopes that extend across the generations . . . of the 
Alamo, of Goliad, of Washington-on-the-Brazos and a battle on the banks of Buffalo Bayou . . . where men were true to Texas and to themselves. 
"Out of this struggle they m ade a nation both o f 
Texas and America, not an empire. Texas m ade both a sm aller and greater nation on this continent,” 
Fehrenbach said. 
Tracing T e x a s’ history in sweat and blood. F eh ­ renbach also recalled the people's struggle to carve a republic and later a state from the soil of the wilderness. 
“ I have enormous faith in people who have been rooted in the soil of their history," he said, “ for it is in this soil that the real strength of this nation is rooted forever. 
“ I glory in being a Texan.” 
S.A. m an’s death in M exico probed 

SPfCIAl TO THI EXPRESS 

MEXICO CITY — A spokesm an from the U.S. 
E m bassy Wednesday said Mexico City police were still conducting an investigation into the death of 
San Antonio native Douglas M. McEachern dr. 

McEachern, 42. was found dead in his apartment at 1o:15 p.m. Monday by friends. 

“ The door was locked, but one of the friends had a key because McEachern went out of town frequently and this friend took care of the apartm ent,” the spokesman said. 

McEachern was found in a bathtub filled with water. He had several stab wounds, most of them in the neck area, the spokesman said. 

Researcher 

M cE achern w as a ch em istry professor and re­ search er at the Advanced Stu d ies Center of the 
Institute Polytecnico Nacional in Mexico City. He had lived there IO years. 

McEachern is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Douglas M. 
M c E a c h e rn S r ., 13o T r e a s u r e W ay. A fa m ily spokesman said no funeral arrangem ents had been made.

M a n a g in g Editor 

TW Q B still wonders about the aquifer 

Texas Water Quality Board directors will try again Thurs­ day to sort out the argum ents over a protective order for the seven-countv Edwards aquifer. 

T wo counties want out of the present order and TWQB E x e ­ cutive Director Hugh Yantis has been trying hard to a c c o m m o ­ date th e m . Y a n tis' first p r o ­ posed a separate order — and procedures for water protection that would be included in each order — for each county. Five of the c o u n t ie s , through then- elected officials, objected. 

 against pollution. 
An extensive examination of present conditions and pro­ posed changes for Uvalde and 
Kinney last Fob. 9 followed an earlier TWQB meeting at which the directors were obviously un­ prepared to hear the debate. 

Bexar. 
Medina. 
Kendall. 
Comal and Hays counties sup­ port the a r g u m e n t that the aquifer is a single underground water reservoir and what affects one part of it affects it all. Kin­ ney and Uvalde argue that po­ pulation and development den­ sity is too sparse to matter, a s ­ s u m in g ordinary p r e ca u tio n s 

In view of the unanimity of officials from the five counties who want a single order — as it is now — the directors should require p e r su a siv e e v id e n c e that the proposed changes are in the public interest. Our position , has been stated repeatedly: On the basis of Yantis' first pro­ posed Edwards order and his lack of professional treatment of a problem zone in the aquifer's 
“ hot zone" off IL S. 281 north of 
San Antonio, we have lost confi­ dence in his administration of sound water policy. 

Texas and society 

1'he live-county presentation is important. 

G onzalez abandons lost cause 

 and quits assassination panel 

A breakdown in House lea­ d ersh ip has alm ost certain ly finished off a proposed investi­ gation of the assassinations of 
President John Kennedy and Dr. 
Martin Luther King .lr. 

 than budget allowed, insisted upon a $8.5 million annual bud­ get and big staff. The House gave the committee $84.o(1(1 a month and limited its life to the end of March. 

Sir: Re: "R esidents of Texas town now arc so rry ” (Georgie Anne Cloyer. 
Express, Fob. 25). Is it possible that ou r local e d ito rial s ta ff has been scooped by Georgic Anne? 
How is it that this Eustace, Tex., dram a would have escaped analysis but for the thorough research activities of Geyer and Company? 
A sinister instigator is exposed and a dismal symbol is proposed; the symbol of a small town in Texas as: Defiant? 
Ignorant? Regretful? Self-sufficient? or What? 
What is this article about any way? It is a m ish-mash of phrases about PHA, 
Texas Power and Light, Acm e brick, small town complacency, living with coloreds, an instigator of a mayor, and governm ent b u reau cracy reg u latin g social change in spite of less federal interference by the 
C arter 
Administration. 
Maybe it tries lo say that a big complicated state like this (Texas, not the United States) would never receive the proper aspects of socialization were it not lot the national wire service and its syndicated experts on small town Texas society. 
Incidentally, how does one go about determ ining if a signature has been 
“ scrawled angrily" on a petition? 
Robert Sheppard

W elfare found to he disgusting 

U.S. pensions should be fair to retirees, future taxpayers 

President Carter is poking around a sensitive nerve on the 
“ almost uncontrollable c o sts” of military retirement pensions and other manpower costs in the defense establishment. lit* wants a blue-ribbon com ­ mittee to examine tile problem. 
Some id’ those costs are a part of the price the country must pay for three major wars within a single generation. They are easts that must be paid as fair­ ness and prior c o m m i t m e n t s require. 
But there are costs that are rolled into practice that is called double-dipping. That means one worker taps the federal pension pool from two different jobs. 

Assuming federal pensions are fully funded — which is* a reck­ less a s s u m p tio n , indeed — a c o m m itt e e of a c tu a r ie s , blue ribbon or not, could project dol­ lar requirements into the future. 

All the pensions funded from public federal funds should be included in the stu dy. That means congressional as well as career civil servants. 

Personnel policies, including pay. allowances and pensions, should be fair and affordable to the next generations. When they are not, it means Congress has been careless in its oversight job 
— and there's painful catching up to do. 

Sir; It gets pretty dern disgusting to hear from anybody that's on welfare tell you that they can't work in your yard because it will cause them re­ duced welfare cheeks. 
I wanted about two hours of yard work done. This young man told me that he would charge m e $13 to dig up the two toot by It) flower bed and $2 to pick up the extra grass he'd pulled out and another $2 to put all of this extra grass aud weeds iii the front of the curb for the garbage m an to pick up. 
Needless to say. I told that boy to get oil of w elfare and try to m ake an honest living because I don't believe in paying a bum $2o for 3o minutes work. 
I thought I would be helping a poor underprivileged person out by letting bim do som ething to earn a few bucks iii my yard but that's not the ease any more. 
The unions and the welfare have put this country iii such a bind that the country can ’t go anywhere but down and to hell. 
Don't tell m e about unions . . . I was a Union Iron W orker for 27 years and all of the new men I got that cam e out on any job that I was in charge of wore too d u m b to know th e d iffe re n c e between a granny and a square knot.

Departm ent, this country is going to hell and last

Cuba.

Cuba’s record 
Considering C uba’s record these past 
17 years, why should we wish to estab ­ lish economic or political relations? 
It was Castro who stole $1.8 billion in property belonging to the stockholders of U.S. com panies, Castro who turned his island into a hem ispheric outpost and missile base of the Soviet Union. 
( astro who publicly executed scores of e n e m ie s an d ja ile d by th e te n s of th o u s a n d s C u b a n s w h o se p r i m a r y crim e is sharing the political beliefs of most Americans.

Look at Castro

A m eric a n is m th ro u g h o u t th e C a rib ­ bean. from Ja m a ic a to Puerto Rico.

Africa.

Com munist victory in Angola and" the widespread atrocities com m itted in the south of that country. 
Called failure 

* 
Critics say that since Castro has nut fallen, the U.S. em bargo is a failure 
Nonsense. 
The e m b a rg o ’s purpose w as not to topple Castro, but lo m ake his regim e pay an e c o n o m ic p ric e for p la y in g monkey to the organ g rin d e rs iii the 
Kremlin. 
It has worked splendidly . 
Cuba no longer ran k s th ird in p er capita income in Latin Am erica. 
Her foreign debt is enorm ous. 
Rationing, even of sugar, is in effect. lier economy has been w racked by an absence of ears, trucks, sp a re parts. etc*., as w ell as c o l la p s in g s u g a r prices. 
I he econom ic burden on the h a rd ­ pressed R u ssian s — who pay ( astro three tim es the world price for sugar. and sell him 99 im r cent of his oil at half the w orld p rice — is e s tim a ted between $2 m illion and $4 m illion a day simply because a few greedy Amer­ ican b u s in e s s m e n a re in te re s te d iii

IDI AMIN, as unpredictable as usual, has gained the headlines with his dealings with Americans in Uganda. An escapee from Uganda gives his view on Amin in the ac­ companying article. 
BLOOD BATH 

Continued from P age IA anything or say anything. Tho archbi­ shop (Janani Lim inn) tried to say so­ m ething and he's d ead .” 
This official and several other highly placed U gandans who have sought re­ fuge here this week provided the Los 
Angeles T im es Service with an account of recent U gandan h o rro rs far m ore extensive than prev iously known. 
All w ere m e m b e rs of U g a n d a 's d i­ m inishing class of educated elite. In addition to the two who had access to 
Amin, one was a doctor and two were university professors. Each said that revealing his nam e or his precise po­ sition would endanger his family, left behind in Uganda 
They said an underground network had b ee n s e t up to aid d i s t r a u g h t 
Ugandans — an increasing n um ber of whom are top governm ent w orkers — in their escape from Kampala. 
T hey w ould not e l a b o r a te on th e network other than to say it involves a h arro w in g jungle jo u rn ey by foot to cross into Kenya and that dozens have been killed in unsuccessful escape a t­ tem pts. 
The crossing is m ade without inter­ feren ce from K enyan officials. T he 
Kenya te rm inus is at K isum u. west of 
Lake Victoria. 
T he refu g ees said the “ d is a p p e a r ­ ances" and arrests first becam e known about J a n . 18. one w eek b efo re the celebration m ark in g Amin s sixth a n ­ niversary in office. 
"In U ganda." said a M akerere Uni­ versity professor, "w hen you bear to­ day th a t s o m e o n e is a r r e s t e d , you know that person is d ead." 
At least 1o,ooo 

While there is no firm estim ate how many people have been killed in the p as t s e v e n w e e k s , on e of A m in 's form er confidants said that in Uganda the num ber is believed "to be not less than 1o.ooo." 
Thousands of others are in flight. 
Most a re Aeholi and Lango but to a lesser degree C hristians and intellec­ tuals also have fallen victim to Amin s ire. 
The latest death toll would not be out of c h a ra c te r for a reg im e which the 
G e n e v a -b a se d In te rn a tio n a l C o n fe r­ ence of Ju rists said in 1973 was guilty of the “ worst reign of terror iii recent 
African history." 
E stim ates of the num ber killed since 
Amin, a form er arm y sergeant with a s e c o n d - g ra d e e d u c a t io n , a s s u m e d power in 1971 range up to 3oo.ooo Tens of thousands of other U gandans have fled to neighboring countries. 
When Amin uncovered iii la t e J a n ­ uary w h a t he believed w a s a plot lo overthrow him , he formed a 5.ooo-man unit, composed of soldiers and civilian s e c u r ity p e r s o n n e l, to tr a c k dow n 
HBG QUITS 

How in-law escaped clutches of Idi Amin 

Lango and Aeholi tribesm en through­ out the country, sources said. 
All reports indicate that the unit is both ruthless and effective. 
T he A eholis, a ta ll, d a rk -sk in n e d p eo p le w ith a h is to ry of w a r f a r e , generally live in the area around Oulu. north of K am pala. 
T he L an g o . a sto c k y peo p le w ith cerem onial skin cuts extending from the corner of their eyes. are native to the nearby Atura region. 
T ogether the tribes com prise about 4 per cent of U ganda’s population. 
Until the recent purge started, about half the m e m b e rs of the 2o.ooo-man arm y w ere Acholia and Langi. 
Amin is a Kakwa. from the n o rth ­ west nub of Uganda beyond the Albert 
Nile. It is considered one of the m ost backward of U ganda's 4o tribes. 
A m in ’s latest bloodletting, a c c o rd ­ ing to ev e ry av a ila b le re p o rt, is un attem pt to elim inate all Aehoiisan and 
Langi in positions of any type of au th ­ ority and to replace them with KAK- 
WAS. 
Amin has not trusted the two tribes since his earliest days in office, partly b e c a u s e of t h e i r p o w e r th r o u g h n u m b e rs in the a rm y and partly be­ cause Obotc. now in exile in Tanzania. is an Aeholi. 
Educated a threat 
It is also known that Amin considers anyone with an education a threat. At the Jan. 23 celebrations he announced: 
“ lf the lecturers want to leave M aker­ e re U n iv e r s ity , let th e m . I ll g e t lecturers from Britain and the United 
States." 
Dozens of p rofessors and stu d en ts have disappeared iii the m eantim e and intelligence sources said Amin seem s intent on rcmov mg all educated p e r­ sons from positions of responsibility. 
As an exam ple, they point out that the m an Amin choose as his vice p re­ sident six w eeks ago. Gen. M ustafa 
Adrisi. can barely read or write. Some of A m in’s newest and closest advisers are illiterate and have to use an inked thum bprint in lieu of a signature.

47-year-old Sun Antonio man found at his residence Wednesday night with a gunshot wound in the head.

Barricntez. of 2517 Quintana Boud.

By FRANCIS N YEN DE K1BEDI 
NAIROBI, Kenya — In 1961, when I was 12, my 21-year-old sister, Sarah, failed to return home for more than a week, and our mother was very worried. 
Then one day. a blue sedan drove up to our house and a tall. powerfully built man got out and asked for our m other. 
When she a p p e ared , tilt* m an told her: " M o th e r. I am your son 
I am 
Cap>t. Idi Amin. I work in the arm y at 
Jinja. Your daughter Sarah is living with me. 
T h is w as m y first g lim p s e of the m an who was to become my brother- in-law — and the president of Uganda. 
He m arried my sister. S arah, and they had seven children. 
A m in tr e a te d m e like a y o u n g e r b rother, and I spent m y school holi­ days at his house with Sarah. 
He was a good com panion, .lolly and considerate, never showing a trace of cruelty toward his family. 
But even then he was unpredictable, often m aking p ro m ises he could not fulfill. 
• I doubt anyone would have guessed that Amin would one day become p re­ sident. but it was clear he was c a re ­ fully building a cadre of young soldiers personally loyal to him. 
So, when I was 2o and had finished secondary school, he arran g ed to get me into the arm y. 
Chief of staff 
By then Amin was chief of staff of the arm y and air force, and I was to train with a unit composed of pro­ teges. 
B efore I co m p leted th e p ro g ra m , however, I was transferred to the air force and sent to G reece, which then c o n d u c te d a t r a i n i n g p r o g r a m for 
Ugandan jet pilots. 
Amin overthrew P re s id e n t Milton 
Obote in 1971. and shortly th ereafter people began to disappear. 
At first I found it hard to believe 
Amin was responsible. 
I still th ink that in th e b e g in n in g these events were the work of supporters Amin could not control. 
W hen s o m e o n e o p p o se d h im . he would shout. "I don’t w ant to see this m a n 's f a c e ." and th e m a n w ould simply disappear. 
When Amin felt really threatened, he m ight even have o rd ered so m e o n e ’s death. 
But when he said kill one m an. his underlings killed four. 
Soon, even m e m b e rs of his own fa­ mily were in danger. 
My uncle, Sh a ban u K nutu, fo rm e r m in is te r of p o w er and c o m m u n ic a ­ tio n s , d i s a p p e a r e d a n d f is h e r m e n found his body in the Nile. 
My b ro th er, W anum e K ibedi, was foreign m inister, but in 1972 he began

During the six years since hp seized power in a m ilitary coup. Idi 
Amin has ruled Uganda with arbi­ trary caprice. 

F r a n c is 
N y e n d e 
K ib e d i, a 
27-year-old Ugandan now in exile. was the dictator’s brother-in-law and cam e to know him well. 

In this first-hand account. Kihedi d escrib es the constant fear that grips the Third W orld’s most no­ torious tyranny. 

 o lear for his life and fled to Kenya, where he resigned his post. 
His successor, Michael Ondoga, the cousin of another of A m in's w ives, was also found dead in the Nile. 
A fter m y b ro th e r d efe cte d . I w as brought hom e and assig n ed ground jobs. 
Sister divorced 

Two y ea rs la te r Am in, a M oslem , divorced three of his four wives — my sister (whom he had renam ed “ M am a 
M alyam u"). Hay and Nora. 
He gave no reason, but Kay was On- d o g a 's c o u sin , m y s is te r w as W'uti- em e's niece and Nora, like Obote. was a m em ber of the Langi tribe 
Soon afterw ard, Kay's dism em bered body was found in the back of a car. 
In M arch, 1974. m y sister suffered a broken arm and leg in what we believe was a planned au tom obile accident; four months later she m anaged to es­ cape to Nairobi, and Amin was said lo be furious. 
I staved in the air force, doing my job. trying not to attract attention. 
Taking walk 

At dusk on Saturday. Nov. 8. 1975, I was walking with my fiancee. Justine 
Tvvinomugisha. and som e other friends on Nakulabye-Bakuli road iii K am pala. 
U ganda’s capital. 
I was off duty and in civilian clothes. 
Suddenly, a fa m ilia r gold Citroen- 
Maserati — the only one of its kind in 
Uganda — cruised slowly past us. 
Its bulky driver was Amin himself, who looked at m e without sm iling or nodding. 
I felt a cold feeling in the pit of my stom ach. I feared he would ring my com m ander and ask what I was doing. 
But before his ear bad disappeared a black D atsun of th e S tate R e search 
Unit — Am in’s secret police — pulled up aud two men jum ped out. 
One sa id to m e : " T h e p r e s id e n t wants to see you.” 
It was dark when we reached A m in’s lodge at Makindye. 
An officer took m e into the living room w here Am in, big g er than I r e ­ m e m b e r e d h im , w as s it tin g like a 

 huge, overfed python, watching a film about himselt on I gouda television. 
I saluted and said. "Hello, sir." 
He didn't answer. 
Finally Amin asked in an indifferent tone of voice. “ W here have you been all this tim e?” 
" S ir . I have been at m y p la c e of work, at Guin Air B ase." 
" S tu p id ! " Am in b a rk e d . T u rn in g down the volume of the television set. he faced me. “ What don t we know ?" he said. "You are dealing with rebels and collaborating with exiles." 
Then he turned to two com panions and sa id . " T h i s boy is d a n g e r o u s . 
Even now you xx ill bear on the BBC — after only one hour — th at we have arrested h im .” 
‘Go with him ’ 
After talking with his aides in Nu­ bian. which I cannot u n d ersta n d , he said to them in English. "Go with him to where he sleeps.” 
Then he turned to face the television screen again. 
I w as taken to the State R esearch 
Unit at N aguru, where executions are carried out. 
That night they questioned m c ex­ tensively about any contacts I had with people outside Uganda. 
T h e next day I w as d riv en to my hom e by four carlo ad s of police and soldiers with subm achine guns. 
I was handcuffed and forced to kneel on the floor of m y bedroom while they searched. 
T h e n I w a s ta k e n to M a k in d y e 
Prison, where my uncle, Ondoga. and countless others had been executed. 
When my m other heard that I had been arrested and probably killed, she went m ad with terror and anger. 
She went straight to A m in's lodge in 
K a m p a la a n d d e m a n d e d th a t th e guards let lier see the president or give her m y body. 
They put lier in a cell at a police station and the next day took her to a m e n tal h o sp ital, w h ere she w as d e ­ tained for two weeks. 
Was not dead 
But I was not dead: I was alone in a cell at Makindye. 
Soon m y family found out I was alive and my fiancee w as som etim es able to b rin g m e food. T h e prison fare was rice m ixed w ith b e a n s and a lot of pebbles. 
Then, in the early afternoon of Dec 
29, th** guards cam e for nit*', gave me my shoes and w ater to wash my face and hands. 
An arm y b rig a d ier c a m e h u rry in g up to m e as if in panic, and in a.m inute later I was in his M ercedes Benz, be­ ing driven tow ard A m in ’s re so rt on 
Lake Victoria. 
When we arrived, the brigadier, si­ lent and shaking as if in fear, led me 

 into the villa past the p ark e d lim o u ­ sines of m in iste rs and provincial go­ v ern o rs — and rad io and tele v isio n journalists. 
It was the last tim e I saw- Idi Am in. 
As I ste p p ed inside th e lo u n g e , I h ea rd h im say in a c h e e rfu l voice, 
“ There, they have brought N yende.” 
The room was full of new sm en and dignitaries. 
Also p r e s e n t w e re A m in ’s s e v e n ch ild ren by m y s is te r, and m y own parents. 
Everyone grew silent. 
T h en A m in s a id : " T h e r e is L t. 
Ny elide, his two p aren ts, and all the seven children of M ama M alyam u." 

" R e c e n t l y , an d e s p e c ia ll y la s t n ig h t," 
Am in w ent on, " t h e BBG, instructed by form er m in ister Kibedi, has been pouring out baseless stories th a t all th e s e p eo p le w e re d e a d — killed by me. But now Kibedi will be asham ed Take their pictures and have them on television and in the p a p e rs.” 
Then he looked at me 
“ Why should I kill N yende?" A m in asked. 
“ He i> a young boy, be has no m oney or position in the country. Why should 
I kill h im ?" 
He didn’t tell 

Amin did not tell th e p r e s s I h ad been in prison, but m ade it seem as if I had just com e from air force duty. 
He told m y p aren ts: " N y e n d e w as arrested by my driver because he was found lo iterin g in d a n g e ro u s p la ce s and was m issing from duty. My driver thought it good to a r re s t N yende be­ cause lie could easily get killed in such a place and th e b la m e w ould be on m e .” 
Openly telling lies 

In the 14 years I had known him . it w a s the first tim e I heard Amin openly telling lies about m e. He looked at m e and realized I w a s dism ayed. 
I knew I w as no lo n g e r s a f e in 
Uganda. 
A fter the p re ss co n fe re n c e. A m in had us booked into th e N ile H otel, where the room s are said to be bugged. 
I warned m y parents not to talk. 
I w a s told to report back to the m ili­ tary police officers’ mess. 
Instead. I slipped out of the hotel, w ent into b id in g , g a th e re d to g e th e r what money I could find and took the bus to Nairobi. 
Money taken 

At the Kenya bord er, the U gan d an soldiers found the money. 
An officer took m c aside and quietly pocketed it, but let m e go without even checking m y identity; All he w as in­ terested in was the money. 
I w a lk e d IOO m e t e r s fro m th e 
Uganda side to the Kenya border post and was free.

He also d escribed the s u m m a ry execution of a 
Russian pilot who had tried to desert from the unit during a night march. Tracked down. the pilot was brought back to the airfield aud shot by a firing squad while the others w ere called out of bed to watch. 
Belenko said the unit, stationed about 169 miles from V ladivostok, was staffed by either airm en like himself transferred there for disciplinary reasons or highly motivated, regim e-true young officers doing their obligatory “ ice y ear" in Siberia. 

No walls

Borrego said lit* had no knowledge of the new proposed rate which was one of the subjects dis­ cussed at a staff m eeting Tuesday 

The $1.82 figure was m entioned d u rin g bond election discussions and has also been mentioned to a tax office source

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursdoy March 3 1977
