I -B 
New loan bill tagged 'worse of year’ 

By ROBERT OCHOA 

EXPRESS CAPtTOl BUREAU 
AUSTIN — A Senate bill proposing to hike in­ terest rates on sm all loans is being tagged by its opponents as the worse consumer legisla­ tion of the year. 
Underneath the official tag SB615 is found a broad and unsettling at­ tempt to quiet down the consum er finance in ­ dustry — also known as the small loans institu­ tion in Texas. lf it is passed, — and there are indications it may — the bill would prep up the finance in­ dustry with interest rate increases ranging from 
16 per cent to 25 per cent on loans from $5oo to 
$5.(MMI. 
Present law places a ceiling on regulated in­ terest rates on loans not exceeding $2,5oo. 
Pilgrimage 
Advocates claim the bill is so^good it will fin­ ally put an end to the loan industry’s perennial pil­ grimage to the legisla­ ture in search of higher interest rates. 
Loan groups led by the 
Texas Consumer Finance 
Assn. have hounded the state’s lawmakers since 
1967, the time loan com­ panies w ere last grant cd an interest rate increase of 7o per cent. 
Key to the predicted quieting effect over the loan industry is in a 
“ m odulator” form ula contained in the bill. 
The formula, warn op­ ponents. would cast per­ petual confusion over fi­ guring future interest rates. 
Slide rates 
In addition to increas­ ing set interest rates, the innovative formula de­ signed by the bill s auth­ or would allow loan com­ panies to slide their rates up or dow n depending on the rate of inflation and the cost of doing busi­ ness. 
Trouble is. the state 
Office of Consumer Cre­ dit has made projections showing the. cost of bor­ rowing $1,26o went up around 75 per cent in the last IO years. 
Statistics show the category of most loans borrowed from finance com panies ranges between $3oo and $1,2oo to mostly low and middle income persons. 
This is the range ta r­ geted for the biggest in­ terest charge increases under the bill. 
Some of the new inter­ est brackets created under the bill would be: 
• A 36-month loan up to $3oo would receive a charge of $18 per $1oo per year (“quailing a 3o per cent interest rate. 
• 
A 36-month loan ranging from $3oo to 
$1,2oo would receive a charge of $12 per $1oo per year equalling an annual interest rate of 21 per cent. 
• 
Loans over $1,2oo spread out to a maximum of 6o months would re ­ ceive an add-on charge of 
$8 per $1oo per year equalling a 14 per cent annual interest rate. 
SB615, labelled the 
Consumer Credit Reform 
Act of 1977. was the focus of public hearings this week which went into overtime before the Sen­ ate Economic Develop­ ment Committee. 
Testimony 
The hearings resulted in lopsided testimony at­ tacking the bill and pro­ vided the first squareoff between the bill s leading adversary and its spon­ sor. 
Sponsors of the bill in­ clude Sens. Don Adams, l)-.Jasper; Oscar Mauzy. 
D-Dallas and Bill Moore. 
D-Brvan. 
Adams and Mauzy re­ sisted efforts by the lin- ance industry last session to win higher interest rates. 
Sen. Bill Batm an of 
Ganado has been the scourge of the loan in­ dustry for years, 
Patnian adm its he faces tougher challenge this tim e, noting that supporters of his cause in the past have thinned to a dangerously low point. 
Blitz 
Pat man has unleashed a media blitz against the credit reform bill, peg­ ging It the high water mark of loan shark le­ gislation. 
“We re educating a lot of people about the bill and how bad it really is.' sa>s Batm an 
“ Those people will change the way their senators and representatives vote. 
Adams claims his bill will continue to insure sources of credit for per­ 

 sons entitled to it. but who aren't affluent en­ ough to obtain credit from banks. 
Adams defends his modulator formula as a means to “ prevent loan companies from ripping consum ers off in good years and withholding credit in bad years.” 
One of the main argu­ ments being promoted by the loan com panies is without higher interest rates, fewer loans will be made available to the 

 low-middle income consumers. 
Beyond that argument, the industry is showing very little of its own fin­ ancial records as proof positive they really need extra charges. 
The reason they aren't showing their records is because they don't have to. 
‘‘All these reports (fin­ ancial records) are con­ fidential under the Texas 
Credit Code,” P atm an said. 

P roposed b ill w ould raise interest rates on sm all loans in Texas 

The confidential infor­ mation provision was ad­ ded on to the code in 1967. 
Patman said he plans to add an am endm ent to 
A dam s’ bill unlocking the confidentiality. 
Available 
The Ganado senator 
*.nd a battery of attorneys representing public de­ fender offices in several 

 counties testified at the hearing credit is readily available. 
The fewer loans argu­ ment wouldn't hold water 
‘in San Antonio either, according to one public defender from Bexar 
County’s Legal Aid of­ fice. 
“ It's a totally falla­ cious claim when you look at what’s going on in 

 the barrios and poor sec­ tions of our city,” said 
Jam s McCoy. 
McCoy and Linda Ca­ talan of the San Antonio 
Office of Consumer Ser­ vices joined those opposing the bill during 
Monday’s hearings. 
Both said, according to their case loads, business is bustling for finance companies in San Anton­ io. particularly from poor people. 
McCoy described one case of a widow with se­ 

 ven children trying to live on a monthly salary of $4oo. To make ends meet, she had to draw three loans from finance companies. 
“ Despite the fact she had a very low income and such a large- family she had no problem at all in getting the loans,” 
McCoy said. 
Catalani told of another case involving an epilep­ tic woman who was seven months p regnant and caring for four depen­ 

 dents. ■ 
“ She was nervous and concerned about the sei­ zures affecting her baby. 
Her creditors had been harrassin g h e r ,” 
Catalani said. 
Catalani said the wo­ man owed eight finance com panies a total of 
$861.65. 
“There was no end to the cycle. All but one of the companies agreed to take partial paym ent.” she said. 
Opponents of the bill say passage of the credit 

 bill would further aggra­ vate the cycle where per­ sons over extend them ­ selves with too m any loans. 
Patm an and his staff have gathered some evi­ dence finance companies seem to be pretty well off in Texas. 
Mark Leymaster from the Boston C enter for 
Consumer Law testified the state of Massachu- settes lowered the inter­ est rates on small loans last year.

And often they bring in treasures — not of money but of beauty — such as this beautiful tree trunk. W hat artist could hope to match the beauty of this scene on Sargent Beach? 

SAN A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 

It's a gusty day on the beach — but life goes on. 

Gray clouds hid the sun and wind was out of the north last S atu rd ay when G eo rge and Bonnie C a rm a c k visited Sargent Beach. Sargent is on the Texas Gulf Coast near Bay City. 

But the tem perature and the g ray ­ ness of the day gave the beach a unique mood. And those who c a m e to the beach had a wonderful day. 

The C a r m a c k s ’ story on S a rg e n t 
Beach will appear in S atu rd ay 's Ex- press-News. 
All photos are by Bonnie Carmack. 

This is treasure hunting — brought up to date with a metal detector. Mrs. Donna Johnson, a Houston school teacher, and her husband are great treasure hunters. Finding a handful of today's small change is par for the course. But there s always a hope that the coin dug out of the sand will be a Spanish real four centuries old. Mrs. Johnson was one of a group of four “ treasure hunters on Sargent Beach last Sa­ turday.

Senior Center will jointly celebrate their fifth anniversary at IU.3o a.m. and 3 p.m. Thursday at 1215 Fair Ave.

Institute of Senior Centers. Washing­ ton. D.C., will speak at 1o:3o a.m .. after which re fre sh m e n ts will be served. 

The center and apartments will be open to the public for tours, said Linda 
Bridgewater, director of the center. 
State Rep. Roil Bird will speak at 3 p.m. Recognition will be given to some . of the residents and participants. v J 
The center is one of 14 senior centers operated by Senior Community Ser- 
\ices. Inc., a United Way Agency.

Beach. Neither gray days nor gusty winds can stop the tows. Here the ' Christine M " moves on east pushinq a string of oil barges. Watching the highway bridge swing open and the big towboats and their barges glide through is a bonus on a trip to Sargent Beach.

Space is found for new courts 

Bv DEBORAH W ESER 

A Utile informal juggling Wednesday produced a space plan allowing room for all four new district courts under the Bexar County Courthouse roof. 
Three county courts-at-law will be shifted, two to the first floor into space now used by the Sheriff’s Department. 
The third will take over half the space now allocated to the large cen­ tral jury room on the second floor. 
Their vacated space will be taken up by three of the new District Courts. 
The fourth will slip into the third floor space now designated for interim special district court use. 
Affected directly in the courtroom musical chairs are County Courts-at- 
Law .Judges Caroline Spears and Carol 
Haberman. Both will be shifted from the second floor space they now hold to first floor space. 

Review set 
Other space assignments have not been made yet. according to County 
.Judge Blair Reeves. 

With the other four m em bers of 
Commissioners Court, Reeves plans to review the space situation in detail at the court’s regular Friday morning meeting. 
Commissioners Court, Reeves and 

Com. Albert Bustamante agree, will m ake the final court space a ssig n ­ ments. 
Earlier in the day. Bustamante — whose job it is to supervise physical facilities and operation of the Court-’ house building — express some con­ cern adequate space for all four new courts might not be available under the one roof. 
Taxes 

“ I, as an individual, am not about to go to the taxpayer to raise taxes to m eet these (sp a c e ) needs at this time.” he said. 
Money for renovation of the space to be used very likely will be drawn — at least in part — from a $1.6 million general revenue sharing fund set aside for new building construction and fa­ cilities renovation. 
About $5oo,6oo of that fund can be diverted to renovation without addi­ tional public hearings, Commissioners 
C ourt was told Wednesday by County 
Auditor Oliver Lewis. 

The question of financing the reno­ vation surfaced during debate over a resolution affirming the court’s inten­ tion of freezing the $1.6 million for new building and/or renovation for the new district courts.

Bid to halt picket line bus use turned down 

 ire hit 

By LIZ SW EET

“The New Breed of Newscasters as a Tool for Social Change.’’ General admission is $3. 

EXPRESS CAPITOL BUREAU 
AUSTIN — State Rep. Frank Tejeda of San Antonio has introduced three bills aimed at upgrading standards for peace officers in Texas. 

The first bill, HBI394. would require peace officers, in their preparatory training programs, to pass psycholo­ gical and emotional tests approved by 

By JIM WOOD 

San Antonio Transit System trustees 
Wednesday rejected a request by City 
Council to stop leasing buses to haul non-union workers across picket lines at a refrigeration company. 
Trustees cited a legal opinion that it is the duty of the bus system to provide service without discrimination against any person or concern. 
In a prepared statement, trustees said the issue is in court and they will abide by court rulings. 
At issue is a strike by International 
Union of Electrical, Radio and Ma­ chine Workers, Local 78o, against 

 the T ex as D epartm ent of Mental 
Health. 

"I found out there’s no psychological or mental exams required of peace officers,” Tejeda said. 
His proposed legislation would also require peace officers already in ser­ vice to take the tests every three years. 
HB1395 and HB1396 arc companion pieces of legislation that would tighten current requirements for appointed 

Friedrich Air Conditioning & Refri­ geration Co. 
The company is leasing city buses to bring in other workers to keep the plants in operation. 
The union wrung a 6-3 majority vote from City Council last Thursday, ask­ ing the transit system to discontinue the leases on groun ds union negotiating efforts are being under­ mined. 
Advisory 

Since trustees act independently of council, the request was advisory only. 
Union representatives crowded into the sm all conference room at the 

 peace officers to receive certification once they are appointed. 
Under'the two bills, any appointed peace officer would be required to complete a basic course in law en­ forcement within six months of his appointment. 
Any officer found not to have com­ pleted his certification within the six months would be subject to a class B misdemeanor. 

 transit system office to urge trustees to stop the practice. 
Paul .Javior. field representative for the union, said the buses are tran- sportating people from other states and countries acro ss union picket lines. 
; 
“ It was never the intent of the law to use city buses for strike breaking.” 
Javior said. 
Police Chief E. E. Peters told the 
Express he has sent escorts along the bus routes off and on because of re­ ports of vandalism and to keep the situation peaceable. 
But he said he would never let his officers work inside the plant or for the company, even on their own time. 

After hearing union spokesm en make their plea, the four trustees pre­ sent went into closed session although 
Mayor Lila Cockrell, a member, sug­ gested continuing the session out in the open. 
Trustees returned and Murrene Gif­ ford. the chairman, read a statement outlining the board’s position. 
It was adopted 3-1 with Gifford voting against it and M ayor C ockrell, 
Dr. Gerald Parker and Mrs. Reba Ma­ lone voting for it. 

Bills offered to upgrade officer efficiency 

Students at the Univer­ sity of Texas at San An­ tonio are upset over Gov. 
Dolph Briscoe’s proposed budget cuts which would eliminate the universi­ ty’s work-study program. 
The w ork” study pro­ gram provides on-cam- pus jobs, ranging from library assistants to ca­ feteria workers, to help students work their way through school. 
The program had been allocated $125,ooo for the next year and $15o,ooo for the following year by the 
L e g isla tiv e 
B u dget 
Board. 
The state funding, in turn, would g en e rate- 
$8oo,ooo in matching fe­ deral funds and provide a p rogram en ab lin g hundreds of students to earn an education. 
Briscoe, however, pro­ poses no funding for the program. 
Under the leadership of 
Mrs. Susanna Shields, a student in the fine arts department, the students are organizing to protest the proposal. 
Meeting 
These students, Mrs. 
Shields said, will meet at 
2 p.m. Thursday in the 
UTSA Humanities Build­ ing to formulate a plan of action. 
Mrs. Shields stressed the entire City of San 
Antonio would I m * affect­ ed if the college’s funds are cut. 
“ If we lose our good faculty m em b ers, the university will lose its good stan din g and the com m unity will be a f­ fe cte d ,” M rs. Sh ields said. 
The student group, she said, plans to draw up and circulate a petition which a delegation will present to legislators in 
Austin. 
Recommended 
B riscoe’s budget pro­ posal recommends UTSA j receive $1o.9 million less than the university re- 
I quested in o p eratin g funds for the next two 
\ears. 
Dr. Peter Flawn, UTSA 
I presiden t, e a r lie r had j said the university may 

I lose 4o or more teachers from its 3oo-m ember 
| faculty if the Texas Le­ gislature cuts the budget. 
E veritt Mahon, N ic e president for busin ess 
I a ffa ir s, said Dial stilt 
I looks to Im* the case 
“ We probably won’ t 

 h a N e any further infor­ mation until the senate and house complete their study. I think we are about one month away from knowing the final outcome,” Mahon said. 
The vice presiden t said, h ou ev er, he be­ lieved the actions of the 
J student group were pre- j m ature and probably would not do any good. 
“ I really don’t think things are as bad as they i ap|M*ai to In* right now, * 
I Mahon said.

BH IVV AN I, India — 
The political opposition to Prime Minister Indira 
Gandhi is counting on a voter backlash against compulsory sterilization to win this important district in the March 16 election.

Oriental tones by Jack Winter

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 
Tow er to speak at dinner 

V S. Sen. John Tower will be the main speaker at this year's annual Pink Elephant Ball. 
The hall. sponsored by six Republican Women's 
C lubs, is set for 7:3o p. rn. Friday in the San Antonio 
Country Club. 

Adm ittance is $17.5o per person. 
Winner of a draw will be awarded a free ticket for two to New Orleans for three days and nights. 

 com p ete with round trip air fare and accomoda­ tions. 
The chairmen of the ball include Mrs. Skip 
Fahrmann, Mrs. Jack Sim s, Mrs. Richard Eddle- nian, Mrs. Wade Smallen, Mrs. John Bullard, Mrs. 
Simeon Mist rot, Mrs. Dwight Hageman. Mrs. C. A. 
Deasen, and Mrs. Helen Moran. 
Money raised at the function will be used to brin elect Republicans to public office.

MEETS FAVORITE SPUR LOUIS DAMPIER 

8 
Marcie Smith delivers 4 7 N ew s customers. She attends 
M ark Twain Jr. High. She is a member of the G irl Scouts of 
America. O ne of her favorite hobbies is macrame and also help- ing the M arch of Dimes. 

She uses her route profits on school clothes, a bicycle, 
Christmas presents, and she also helped a fam ily whose father was injured on the job. She loaned them $ 2 o .o o with no stipula­ tion on repayment.

FORECAST 
Society gets a new van 

The State Department of Highways and Public 
Transportation delivered the first of 13 specially equipped vans for tran­ sportation of the handi­ capped to the Easter 
Seals Society of San An­ tonio. 
Keys to the van were presented to the society’s executive director R. VV. 
Aaron by San Antonio 
District Engineer R. E. 
Stotzer .lr. in special ceremonies at the district office in Sun Antonio. 
Easter Seals will use the van to transport peo­ ple in wheel chairs to and from its therapy center. 
The program, in con­ junction with Goodwill industries, utilizes com­ pact rn ini-buses. 
Design 
They are designed with wide doors, wheel chair lifts and safety locks to secure the chairs in order to pros ide a unique form of tru\ el 
“ When the program is lully implemented, the elderly and handicapped residents of San Antonio anc) New Braunfels will have bus transportation that is particularly suited to their needs." Bob 
Blase, executive director of Goodwill, said. 
Goodvvill R e h a b ilita ­ tion is scheduled to re­ ceive nine of the 13 new mini-buses. The remain­ ing three will go to the 
Community Council of 
South Central Texas in 
New Braunfels. 
The State Department of Highways and Public 
Transportation, under the provisions of the t'r- bun Mass Transportation 
Act of 1HB4. is working with the federal govern­ ment and local non-profit organizations to develop a new busing program to fit the mohiiitv require­ 

 ments of the elderly and the mobility-impaired. t’nder this program, the federal government will pay Sit per cent of the purchase price of the buses, with the partici­ pating non-profit organization paying the balance.

Cold front brings showers to Texas 

ASSOCIATED m ss 

A cloud cover with .scattered showers was pusher across the state Wednesday by westerly winds from a Pacific cold front which kicked up dust on the South Plains, reducing visibility to less than a mile. 

High wind warnings were issued for West Texas where winds gusted to 5(1 miles per hour. Winds of up to 4h miles per hour were reported in the Pan­ handle. 

Showers and moderate winds blanketed East and 
Central Texas ahead of the front. 
Temperatures ranged from 45 at El Paso to l l at 
McAllen and Brownsville vvitli ads and lids iii other areas of the state. 

Eoreeasts called for westerly winds under clear skies to follow the cold front and a few snow flurries 

 i i i the Panhandle. 
Winds of up to 4d miles per hour are forecast for all parts of the state except the extreme southwest.

Balmy spring nights... feel romantic in a white eyelet and lace dress 

You can look a s beautiful a s a bride anytime .. . 
Our Mexican style wedding dress will add a south of the border flavor to your evening wardrobe and to any occasion you attend. 
Designed after the colonial wedding dresses of old Mexico, this full tiered all cotton dress blends with the grace, history and cultural tradition of San Antonio. Intricate lace and eyelet on the flowing three tiered open work skirt, the square neck and bodice, and the bell sleeves. Sizes 6-14, white, fully lined. 5o.oo. 
Sun Country Dresses. Downtown, North Star, 
Windsor Park, Austin. Charge it!

Two art shows em erge equal 

SKATER Kevin Bubp strikes a flirtatious pose during a 
Holiday On Ice com edy sketch. 

By ROBERT TIEMANN 
Two art societies are exhibiting sim ila r work in San Antonio. 
The Texas W ater color 
Society is having its 28th 
A n n u a l 
E x h ib itio n through Sunday at the 
UT 
H e a lth 
S c ie n c e s 
C enter. The C ontem por­ ary Art Group is exhibit­ ing at Sol del Rio Gallery through March 23. 
In te rm s of q u a lity , th e s e two sh o w s a r e a b o u t e q u a l, w ith th e 
Contemporary' Art Group having a slight edge. 
The W ater color Socie­ ty seem s to be suffering from an identity crisis. 
When acrylic, w ater-base paint cam e on the m arket in the ‘fids, the color field painters such as Helen 
F r a n k e n th a le r , M o rris 
L ouis, 
P a u l 
.Jen k in s. 
F r ie d e l 
D z u b a s an d others took from w ater­ color its c h a ra c te ris tic trait of transparency and its methods of splashing.

Big Bird and friends with Holiday on Ice 

Big Bird and his Se­ sam e Street friends will be lacing up th e ir ice skates Thursday through 
Sunday in the Convention 
Center for Holiday On Ice perform ances. 
J o i n i n g th e S e s a m e 
Street cast will be sever­ al other ice perform ers 

 up the 1977 
H oliday On who m ake e d itio n of lee. 
Follow ing the th e m e 
"M usic Makes It 
Hap­ pen" the show presents a co m b in atio n of a e r o b a ­ tics and com edy which traces A m erican m usic from ragtim e to rock and roll. 
The selections in the show v ary from la rg e production num bers in­ cluding several perform ­ ers to solo spots featuring 

 top s k a t e r s fro m th e 
United States and C ana­ da. 
Tickets for Holiday On 
Ice are being sold for $4, 
$5 and $H at Jo sk e’s and 
J a m and Jelly G eneral 
S to re at 6426 N. New 
Braunfels Ave. 

P erfo rm an ces will be given at 8 p.m. Thursday through Saturday and a 2 p .m . m a tin e e w ill be presented Saturday and 
Sunday.

The sm all scale of the high quality paintings. 
T h is p r o b le m is e v i ­ dent in noting the v ar­ iety of m e d ia th a t a re now b ein g a c c e p te d as w a te r c o lo r s . T h e only a p p a ren t co m m onalities are that the works be on p ap er and not in oils. I w o n d er why th e use of canvas has been exclud­ ed.

C ecille Crow ex h ib its three very strong acrylic co llag e -p ain tin g s which are the m ost interesting w orks in the show ; but what have they got to do with watercolor? 

W eak a r t 
The Contem porary Art 
Group Show is weak and in need of a transfusion. 
With all the new, young artists in town, I wonder why they have not found their way into this show.

J u d y 
U r r u i i a , w h o se m in im a l p a in tin g s and d ra w in g s s e e m s ta rk ly out of place.

The show will continue through March 18. 
Soprano in recital 

Soprano Natalie Belier will present "A Recital of 
A m e ric a n S o n g ” at 8 p .m . T h u rs d a y in th e 
McNay Art Institute. 6ooo 
N. New Braunfels Ave. 
Works by John Duke, 
Charles Ives, Aaron Co­ pland an d Jo h n Corig- liano Jr. will be featured in the free recital. 

Pianist Ruth F riedberg will accom pany the so­ prano during the recital which will be held in the 
Emily Wells Brown Wing of the art institute.

Two free concerts 
F riday 

Tho 
San 
Antonio 
Symphony will present two free concerts Friday 
— one al Travis Park and another at the East End 
Multi-Service Center. 
The first concert will he at noon at T ra v is 
Park. located a cross from the St. Anthony Ho­ tel. 
The second concert will be at the East End Mul­ ti-Service Center, located at 
Blast Houston and 
Commerce streets. 
Associate conductor 
Harvey Garber will con­ duct the orchestra. The program will feature se­ lections from 
“ The 
Sound of 
M u s i c ,” 
“ Showboat” and a Sousa march as well as waltzes by Tschiakow sky and 
Strauss. 
The concerts are infor­ mal and San Antonians are invited to bring their lunch to the noon time concert and to brum the entire family to the evening performance. 
("horal to sing 
M ozart 

The San Antonio Choral 
Society will sing Mo­ zarts Requiem Mass and 
Solemn Vespers at 8 p.m. 
B'ridav in Trinity Uni­ v e r s ity ’s 
M arguerite 
Parker Chapel. 
The program, which will be conducted by 
Henry Holloway, will he repeated at 4 p.m. Sun­ day in the chapel. 
The coneen will he in­ troduced bv Amy F ree­ man Lee. well-known San 
Antonio artist, lecturer and educator. 
Soloists for the free concerts include: Irene 
Aguilar, soprano; Sandra 
Peters, contralto; I) 
It 
Swedherg. tenor, and Dr. 
George (J Gales, bass.

Libraries display wildlife 

Wildlife paintings and the photographs of Ken 
Holloway will he featured iii two San Antonio public libraries during March. 

Paintings bv local art­ ist Laddie J. Nemee will he exhibited iii the gal- lery area of the Main 
Public Library al 2o.1 S st. Mary’s st 

A native Texan. Ncinct, spent much of his child hood hunting and explor mg the brush country of 
South Texas. He has ex­ hibited his painting in juried art shows throughout Texas, 

Holloway s photo­ graphs will lie on display at the Westfall Branch 
Library, at Oil Rosedale 
Court lie began his car­ eer as a fre e la n ce photographer specializ- ing in oil field scenes. 

Ile later worked on the stall of the D allas Morn­ ing News‘where he was responsible for fashion photography and the 
Sunday rotogravure fea­ ture photography. 

 by BEN KING Jr. 
After seeing “ Chulas 
F r o n t e r a s ” (Beautiful 
Bord ers) many South 
Texans may start looking at enchiladas and maria­ chis in a different light. 
The documentary now showing at St. Mary's 
University digs at the roots of Tex-Mex culture and shows Mexican food and sombreros are just a small part of this area’s culture. 
By focusing on conjunto style music, the film reveals the unique spirit and history of the 
Mexican-American peo­ ple without diluting it with romanticism. 
The musicians play the music, which features the accordion and haji) sexto guitar, the people dance and the viewer almost feels like he’s joining in the bouncy polkas. 
Music basis 
Actually the music which forms the basis of the film is the perfect example of the cultural mesh occurring in South 
Texas. 
As accordionist Santia­ go Jimenez explains in the 58-minute, long film, conjunto music is d er­ ived from the German polkas played in New 
Braunfels and other sur­ rounding towns during the ISIMis. 

Mexican 
- 
American musicians borrowed the basic polka rhythm and altered it with Spanish 

 lyrics to frt their more intense moods. 
Filmmaker Les Blank does an excellent job of using conjunto music.as a vehicle to slip the viewer into 5oth wedding anniversaries, backyard gatherings and a typical kitchen during the 
Christmas season. 
Much more 
But there’s much more to “ ( hulas F r o n t e r a s " than singing, dancing and good times. 
Several scenes in the film depict an aspect of 
South 
T e xa s tourists don’t find too colorful — migrant laborers doing hack-breaking work. 
Another scene recalls through a song the 19o7 confrontation between farm workers and Texas 
Bangers in Starr County. 
The lyrics from the gutsy song “ Kindles De 
T e x a s . ” used in the scene, has gotten the film barred from a few schools since it refers to former Gov. John Con- 
M ozart feature 
One of the world’s foremost hornists. Myron 
Bloom, will he featured in the San Antonio Sym­ phony’s all-Mozart con­ cert at 8:3o p.m. Satur­ day in the Theater for the 
Performing Arts. 
The performance will also he given at 7:3o p.m. 
Monday in Laurie Audi­ torium. 

Review 

 nally as a less than fair politician. 
In filming this are a ’s landscape Blank shows an extraordinary talent for catching beauty in what most people would consider mundane places. 

Bor instance the charm of a flower garden in full bloom in front of a tar­ paper shack. 

Several of the m u s i­ cians appearing in the film will make live ap­ pearances at the film's showing in St. Mary's 
Continuing BIdueation 
Center Auditorium 

Three days 

The film will be shown 
Thursday, B'rid ay and 
Saturday at 8 p.m. and 
9:3o p.m. Thursday Flaco 
Jimenez and Salome Gu­ tierrez will make an ap­ pearance. F rid ay Los 
Alegres de Alazan will 

 perform and Saturday 
Lydia Mendoza will sing. 
Tickets for the film are 
SI.5o for students and $2 for nonstudents. “ Chulas 

F r o n t e r a s ” is being sponsored by 
Centro 
Mexico and the Mexi- can-A m e rican Student 
Organization. 
Ballet highlights due 

The San Antonio Ballet 
Company will be pre­ senting highlights from a variety of ballets Thurs­ day. Friday and Saturday at North Star Mall. 
The presentations are part of the observance of 
Ballet Week in San An­ tonio. 

The company will pre­ sent highlights from 
“ Don Quixote,” “ Swan 
L a k e ” and “ Sleeping 
Beauty.” 

The performances will he given at 1:3o p.m. 
Thursday, Frid ay and 
Saturday.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday Morch 3 1977 
UTS A joins program at Kelly 

No, it’s not Amy Carter going for a spin, it's her Illinois look-alike 

Deanna Watters, 8, of Joliet, III., visiting the Chicago Automobile 
Show. — AP Wirephoto 

The University of Texas at San 
Antonio has become the fourth college participating in the Air 
Force Logistics Command’s 
Cooperative Education Program at Kelly AFB. 

The agreement was signed by E.M. 
Mahon, UTSA vice president for busi­ ness affairs, Dr. Vincent L. Avallone, 
UTSA cooperative education director, and Raul Valdez, civilian personnel officer at Kelly. 

UTSA joins St. M ary's University and Prairie View A&M University in 
Texas and New Mexico H igh land s 
University in the program at Kelly. 

The program is designed to blend academ ic trainin g and practical experience by altern atin g periods o f work and school 

Currently 28 studenta from these in­ stitutions work in jobs at Kelly ranging from c h em istry and acco un tin g to personnel and procurement. 

Work 

The program is designed to blend academic training and practical ex­ perience by a lte rn a tin g periods of work and school. 

Students enrolled in the program 

 work fulltime at Kelly half the year, in a GS-.1, 4 or 5 position directly related to their field of study. During the other six months, they return to their un­ iversities to continue their academic tra in in g . T his c on tin ues until the students receive their degrees. 

The program is open to college so­ phomores or juniors enrolled in par­ ticip atin g colleges or u n iv e rsitie s meeting the required academ ic and career standards. 

AFLC, Kelly’s p a re n t c o m m an d , pays the cost of tuition, related fees and books for the stu d e n t’s college during this first year in the program. 

R em ainin g costs of his co lleg e education are paid for by the student, but are mostly defrayed from earnings during the Kelly work periods. 

Graduation 

When a student graduates from col­ lege, he is eligible for a non-competi­ tive career-conditional U.S. Civil Ser­ vice appointment, and offered a GS-5 or 7 position at Kelly related to his cooperative education training. 

Fiesta to bring 
S.A. m illions 

F ie sta is com ing, bringing together three million spectators and participants to pump SSI million a day into San 
Antonio's economy. 
Although the city's an­ nual spring carnival of fu n , food and frolic w ill last only Iii days, Fiesta 
‘77 is expected to gener­ ate more than $13 m i l l ­ 

 ion . 
The annual influx of tourists during 
April 
15-24 this year will also keep the city’s cash re­ gisters busy. 
Sales up 

F ie sta 
C om m ission 
Executive Vice President 
Davis Burnett dr. said. 
“ Interest in Fiesta this year. as shown by ad­ vance ticket sa le s, is a p p re c ia b ly ahead of 
197H.” 
Large groups from Ok­ lahoma to VVashington. 
D C., have confirmed re- serv at ions or pa c k a g e plans for hotel, transpor­ tation, Fiesta tickets and dining, Burnett said. 
B u rnett noted direct income to San Antonio iii room occu pancy tax. rentals and fees and sales tax totaled $182,ooo last y ear. 
He a n tic ip a te s more this year. 
Food, rooms 
An additional $1 m il­ lion a day was generated 

 i i i the form o f food and beverage sales, room ac­ c o m m o d a tio n s, re ta il sales and other expenses, he said. 
Fiesta San Antonio be­ gan in 1891 w ith one e ven t, the 
B attle of 
Flowers P arade. Today there are H3 civic organi­ zations that spnnsror the 
Kl days of Fiesta. 

$8 million rape suit is filed 

A 
14-year-old 
Fort 
Worth girl filed an $8 million damage suit iii district court Wednesday in connection with an al­ leged rape at a North 
Side motel. 
She is suing Trinity 
Valley School i i i Fort 
Worth and Headmaster 
Stephen Seleny i i i the im*- tit ion filed in IHth Dis­ trict C ourt, c la im in g them responsible for her being raped 
She said she was railed iii a North Side motel last 
January while represent­ ing the school in an ath­ letic contest here. 

She clanned in her lie­ ut ion the school and its headm aster were negli­ gent by maintaining a permissive at mosphere and bv allowing her al­ leged attacker to attend the school. 

She also claimed her indefinite suspension fro n d he school following the incident has brought psychological damage to her.

Meat is good for your family. 

Meat contains protein which builds and maintains all body tissues. It forms an im­ portant part of enzymes, hormones and body fluids. The Recommended Daily 
Allowance of protein is 45 grams. 
Meat contains iron which goes toward creating hemoglobin, that red stuff in your blood. It carries the oxygen where it s needed. 
Meat contains niacin which helps the body to use the oxygen to produce energy. 
And it helps keep your skin, tongue, digestive tract and nervous system healthy. 
Meat...is good for your growing family.

 lay it safe 

LEONARD RANDOW, BOB ELLIS DISPLAY EXPLOSIVES 
...for Kimberly Haney, Douglas Mzyk, Jeff Hassmann 

By LOIS HAASE 
A visit to Safety Seminar 
1977 leaves a greater im ­ pression on the 4,ooo to 5,ooo children who attend than the safety they’ ve been learning all term in class. 

The two-week seminar will end 
Friday. Sessions have been of­ fered each week day from 9:3o to 
11:3o a rn. and from 12:3o to 2:3o p.m. 
Safety with electricity is being emphasized by the City Public 
Service Board with film strips and d iscu ssion s. One fourth grader from Ridgeview Elemen­ tary School su rp rised the in­ structor with his knowledge of electrical terms. Seems the class had just finished studying elec­ tricity in class so they were dou­ bly interested in this area. 
San Antonio Police Department is showing films on, bicycle and school safety. A bicycle, with proper safety equipment, is on display so that students can see where reflectors and other safe g u a rd s should be placed. 
Huge posters display traffic signs found on streets and highways so that bike riders can recognize and obey all signs. 
( apt. G. E. Matheny is also showing a film on shoplifting and 

 its consequences. Youngsters are taught at an early age that sho­ plifting is not daredevil fun but a serious crime. Picking up small item s in stores can becom e habit-form ing and a crim in al record can be building while the youngster thinks he’s impressing his friends and having a child­ hood adventure. It can turn into a nightmare. 
Rifle safety 
Patrolm an Leonard Randow and Detective Bob Ellis keep the interest of students with empha­ sis on rifle safety and a demon­ stration and exhibit of war souvenirs. 
Sample explosives are shown and explained so that students will recognize them easily — and leave them alone. 
A table holds a deadly exhibit of what is commonly known as “ war souvenirs.” The danger of these grenades, mortars, motor rock­ ets, parachute explosives and others was apparent by the fas­ cination they hold for the students. 
Gun safety is also stressed. 
Even the popular B B gun is demonstrated to show that care­ lessness could leave someone partially blind. 
Randow stresses that guns are rn ny as dangerous as the person behind them. “ Never point 

 a gun. even unloaded, at anything you do not want to kill,” he re­ minds the youngsters. 
The children watch in a trance as he talks, saying they know he wouldn't bring a loaded gun ar­ ound them. 
Then he pulls the trigger point­ ing the gun at the ceiling. There’s a loud “ bang” as a blank explodes and the children jump a foot off the ground. They are impressed. 
A film, “ Learn Not to Burn.” is shown by the San Antonio Fire 
Department. They learn safety here but the biggest thrill provid­ ed by the Fire Fighters is the ar­ rival of the huge snorkel fire truck. 
Red pan t 

While Fire Fighters put their big red giant through its paces, with its Airbourne Fire Fighter, the children are served soft drinks, courtesy of Coca C ola 
Bottling Company. 
Seminar is co-sponsored by the 
Bexar County Medical* Society 
Auxiliary and the Greater S*n 
Antonio Safety Council. Auxiliary co-chairmen are Mines. Ignacio 
Queralt and Willis E. Brown Ray 
Wangler and Gordon C. Tull as­ sisted representing the Safety 
Council. 
“lf we save one life or prevent one accident, it s all worthwhile,” 
Wangler sas s. 

Dallas designer Les W ilk and Carm en 
Tidwell of the Dallas regional office of the March of Dimes are here for ‘‘Coffee with le s / ’ a benefit fashion show at IO a.m . Thursday it. the new A irp o rt 
Travelodge. Tickets (tax deductible) may be purchased at the door.

Trudeau is no robot 

Montreal Gazette, says Mrs. Trudeau's choice of a short dress for a state dinner probably grew out of the much touted informality at the White House. 

“ We all have been reading how low­ key the Carters have been so perhaps she was responding to that.” 

There is little written about Mrs. 
T rudeau's clothes in the Canadian papers, not only because she doesn t want it discussed but also because people are not that concerned, gener­ ally. about what she wears, according to Carolyn Weiner of Holt Renfrew. 

“ She's a very private person and she does her own thing. I admire her for that,” Weiner adds. 
Excursion 

BY MNA S. HYDE 
IHE W A SH IN G T O N POST SERVICE 
WASHINGTON - Ii Rosalynn 
Carter and M argaret Trudeau took tim e out to talk about fash io n — and it is very unlike­ ly t h a t th e y did — they would find they had a lot in com m on. 

Both like clothes but don't like to harp on the subject, particularly in front of the press. Both have an in­ dependent style and opt for the com ­ fortable and casual, including jeans for the most informal occasions. 
And just as Mrs. Carter brought her sewing machine to the White House, 
M rs Trudeau has one in her residence at 24 Sussex Drive in Ottawa. 

Mrs. Trudeau, who occasionally hops on her bike, wearing jeans, and goes off to shop with a similarly dressed 
Royal Canadian Mounted Policeman trailing her on a bike, likes to browse unnoticed through the racks. 

She m akes her selections at bou­ tiques such as Josee Bes .lardin. John 
Warden or Rive Gauche in Montreal or the fine Holt Renfrew specialty shop. 

“ In the beginning she bought a lot of clothes from Canadian designers,” observes. W arden, a d e s ig n e r of ready-to-wear and lingerie who has his own boutique. 

“ But now she seems to prefer others. 
She may be shopping on Seventh 
Avenue.” Later he added sadly. “ It s really too bad. She could do for Can­ adian fashion what Mrs. Onassis did for the Americans.” 
F re n ch labels 

There are French designer labels in her wardrobe, including Yves Saint 
Laurent and Chloe, and outfits from 
Italian designer Andre Laug, but for very special occasions she makes her own dresses. 

She designed and m ade her own wedding dress (and baked the cake, too) and created the wedding dress as well for the nanny to her children. 
Mary Alice Mullally. 

Designer Warden, who has not seen 
Mrs. Trudeau in the dress worn to the state dinner at the White House, terms the choice “ a little on the classic side but believes it was “ just as fashionable as a long dress ” 

VY iii i Rider, fashion editor of the 

ON FALL LONG DRESSES', JUMPSUITS 

AND LONG SKIRTS. WE MUST MAKE 

ROOM FOR NEW SPRING MERCHAN­ 

DISE, AND HAVE TAKEN 

 t UNPRECEDENTED 
One Montreal boutique invited press coverage of Mrs. Trudeau’s shopping excursion to the store and later found all the clothes she had purchased re­ turned to the shop. And she has not returned there since. 

Several American designers have criticized Mrs. Trudeau's choice for the dinner and Letitia B ald rid g e, former social secretary to Jacqueline 
Kennedy Onassis when she was the 
First Lady, agrees.

“ Unequivocably it should have been a long dress." says' Miss Baldridge. 
“ It s a most formal and dignified occasion.” 

It s h ardly the first tim e M rs. 
Trudeau’s independent style has been criticized. 
Mrs. 
Trudeau told one caller to a radio station, where she was answ ering questions about having worn blue jeans and a Liberal party 
T-shirt on a visit to Cuba, “ I dress and act like a lady most of the time. I have some beautiful lady-like clothes.” 

To another caller she announced that she no longer wanted to be simply "a rose in my husband s lapel." Then she added. “ If you rely com pletely un protocol, you can become a robot."

Dear Ann Landers: My married for two years, husband and I have been 
He seemed normal in 

MACRAME! IT’S A NATURAL! th e ll ay To Start Your Day. Everyday 

PZNITA 

Bareback or Sling, 

 whichever you choose, 

 it s right for you! 

Right for every outfit you wear.

A M M I'

MAU 
LOWER LEVEL 

 every way and I never had any reason to ques­ tion his masculinity. 
Our sex life is good but 
I never had any exper­ ience before I met him so maybe I'm not much of a judge. 
About six months ago, 
B asked me to make up his face just to see what he'd look like if he were a woman.” I thought it was a big joke and did it. I must say he looked beautiful. 
A few weeks later, B asked me to make up his face again. This time I was uneasy and told him it was the last time I'd play the game. 

W i g 
An hour later he came into the li\ing room wearing my best house­ coat and a wig, which he must have purchased himself. I was so upset I couldn’t look at him. 
Now I know what has been happening to my 
"missing” bras and pan- 

Ann

732 N O R T H S T A R M A L L 

 tyhose, I am just sick. 
Is this a hormone defi­ ciency, a mental illness or what? I need some answers before I go crazy. Morristown, N.J. 
Dear N.J. 
Your hus­ band may be a transves­ tite whose kicks end with the dressing up. Some psychiatrists say all transvestites are either homosexual or bisexual. 
Please discuss this problem with a counse­ lor. Your letter raises many questions which I cannot answer. 
Since you’ve been married only two years, it may be that the way to fight this situation is with your hat. G rab it and run. 
Iii love 
Dear Ann Landers: 
I think I'm in love but I can’t get myself to say yes until I correct a few things that are bothering me. 
George smokes cigars. 
I hate the smell. He has a nervous cough that is very irritating. When I mentioned it last week he said. "What cough?” He wasn’t even aware he had it. 
George bites his nails when he’s watching TV or a movie. 
His partial plates click when he chews food. His manners are not good at the table. 
Ile talks with his mouth full and never re­ members to pass anyth­ ing. The salt, sugar. 

 gravy, whatever, stops with him. 
I ve been a widow for nine years and want to get married. George has many good qualities. Do you think I will be able to change these few things that I find so annoying? 
— Hopeful 
Dear IL: 
Unless you are prepared to accept 
George as he is, w ith his smelly cigars, irritating cough, chewed-up finger­ nails, clicking partials and poor table manners, better say no and stop seeing him. 
Marriage is not a re­ form school. 
Blush 
Ann Landers: I started to work in this office six weeks ago and I love my job. But the men I work with have discovered I blush easily. 

Now I'm the prime tar­ get for off-color jokes and crude gimmicks sold in cheap novelty shops. One guy springs this stuff on me and the w hole group gathers around to watch my face turn red. 
I am 2o years old and no prude, but I don’t like barroom stories and crum m y gadgets. 
Is there any way I can learn to control my blushing?— 
Tomato Face 

Dear Face: Blushing is an involuntary act and can’t be controlled. 
Its refreshing to know there’s a girl around who can still blush. View it as an asset, honey. You are one of the last of a van­ ishing breed. 
A no-nonsense ap­ proach to how to deal with life's most difficult and most rewarding ar­ rangement. 
Ann 
Landers’s booklet, "M a r­ riage — What to Kxpect,” will prepare you for bet­ ter or for worse. Send your request to Ann 
Landers, care of The Kx- press. Box 2171. San An­ tonio, Tex. 7N297.

R em em ber When "Com ics” W ere "Funnies” ? 
THEY STILL ARE! 

In the Sunday Express-News 

Don’t let criticism bring 

By JE A N BA ER 
The assertive woman can evaluate criticism. Her ego is not destroyed by it. 
The unassertive woman can't cope with it. 
When your self-esteem is low anyway, ifs easy to interpret any critical comment as “ he/she is rejecting m e.” 
You evaluate any criticism you receive from others as further proof of your worthlessness. 
This attitude can produce severe con­ sequences. You may fear criticism to such an ex­ tent that you anticipate it and thus avoid parties, challenges, closeness, new friendships, a better job, or any situation where you might en­ counter it. 
In this way you limit your life and reduce your ego even more. Or you can set up what psy­ chologists term “ the self-fulfilling prophecy.” 
You're so sure you’re go­ ing to he criticized by otliers — for your voice, dress, certain behaviors 
— that you begin to aet in ways that w ill bring about the criticism. 
You make the decision, 
“ They’re right. I am that way.” And you become that way. 
JVI intakes 

What are some of the most common mistakes women — and men too — make about criticism? 
You fail to realize that every criticism doesn t mean something is wrong with you. In actuality, in many eases criticism can stem from respect, a genuine w ish to help you, and desire for (‘motional closeness. 
There are three kinds of criticism : Justified: justified hut said iii a hostile, inappropriate way; and the put-down. 
If you don't understand these gradations, you w ill never learn to handle criticism. 
When I completed my first book, 
“ Follow 
Me!.” I nervously band­ ed it in to my editor, a courtly 
British-born gentleman named Cecil 
Scott. Three weeks later he took me to lunch at 
I he Four Seasons, where 
I anxiously awaited his verdict. 
After I had made two 

 trips to the ladies' room and had had two Bloody 
Marys, Mr. Scott said, 
“ It s all wrong. You’ve written a series of la magazine articles. It’s not a book. What hap­ pened to all those anec­ dotes you told me about originally?” 
I said, “ They were about me. You don’t want me in the book.” 
Ile responded, “ That’s just what I do want. Per­ sonalize it. Take your time with stories. Let one go oil for five pages, an­ other for three. And get rid of all that alliteration and those 4 darling cute phrases.” 
Somehow I got through the lunch. Devastated. I felt like a complete failure. But that night I realized that this brilliant editor had paid me the compliment of criticism. 
So I rewrote the book. 
You set yourself up for criticism. You constantly ask questions like. “ Did I 
(lo that well?” . . . “ What do you really think of my work?" 
You set yourself up for a critical response and feel depressed when you 

 way” ), attack (“ What^ a idiot you are!” ), standing on your dignity 
(the icy glare and the queenly posture), agreement 
( “ Mea cul­ pa!” ). or door-slamming to be followed by seeth­ ing, sulking, and drawing up plans for ‘T il get hack at her/him/them” ? 
Coping with criticism 
1. Ask yourself, “ Have 
I really been criticized?” 
For example, a boss may say, “ You’ve done a fine job on this report. It will be perfect when you polish it up a little .” 
That's the simple truth — not a criticism. 
2. Consider the source of the criticism and the motives of the critic. The question, “ How’s your social life?” coming from a very popular single friend may well be a veiled put-down. 
The same question coming from a happily married friend may he the prelude to introduc­ ing you to a new man. 
Spite, sour grapes, jealousy, envy lie behind many criticisms. 

 you down 

Part V in series 
' 
A re you a woman or a mouse? 

 get it. I am a second wife. 
When I first got married, 
I used to constantly in­ quire. “ Am I a better cook than Doris?” . . . 
“ Don’t 
I work much harder than Doris?" . . . 
“ Do I have more charm than Doris?” 
I was terribly interest­ ed in Doris, whom, at the time. I d never seen, hut my husband was not. 
Finally, he got sn fed up with my constant inter­ rogations that he started answering. “ No, she’s a better cook"’ . . . “ She s got a lot of charm." 
Defciibive 

You’ve nev er learned to handle criticism and al­ ways become apologetic or defensive when you get it. 
How can you learn to react assertively and constructively to c ri­ ticism instead of with denial ( “ I did not do th at!"), defense ( “ I ve always done it that 

ST A U T STODAY 

F O K :t W A Y S O N L Y ! 

A X \ o O I T I O . V \ l . 

Use your Jay s Optional Account 

BonkAme/icord. MaslerChorge, or Shoppers Charge 

% 
OFF 
ALL SALE-PRICED 
MERCHANDISE 

For example: a regular $4o. dress now on sale for $19. will cost you $ 14.25. 

3. 
Make sure you understand exactly what has been said, instead of automatically looking for a blow to your ego. 
In one ease, a cousin, with whom I ’m very close, commented, “ Why do you write such junk?” about a scries I had done on “ The Other Woman 
Today.” Even though the words were harsh, I knew she didn t mean them quite that way. so I coun­ tered, “ What do you mean by that?" 
She answered. “ I want you to write* that serious hook about French his­ tory — the one you’ve wanted to write so much all these years. I think you could do a grout book.” 
In actuality, her words 
— hostile as they might have seemed — stemmed from lier pride in me. 
4. Try to make your critic be specific. What can you do bettor? W hy is it “ no good” ? Don’t ac­ cept cracks like, “ You have a father fixation!" 
Maybe you do, bul so what? What is your hus­ band really upset about? 
Find out. 
5. Don’t take criticism in the close relationship ut face value. For exam­ ple. you plan to take off oil a European tour bv yourself, and your child says. "You ’re a mean mother." 
What the child means 
| is that she will miss you. 
■ (). Ask yourself, “ Is this criticism fa m ilia r?” 
May In* you should accept 
I repeated criticism (of your lateness, untidiness. 

I etc.) as truth and do something about it. 
7. Learn the technique of handling put-downs or 
I justified criticisms that 
I are expressed in an inap­ propriate way. 
Remember, the world is 
| filled with people who criticize destruct iv cly 
I and woundingly just for 

 the feeling of superiority and power it gives them. 
They pick at others’ faults to elev ate their ow ii virtues. You don’t have to let them do it. You can assert yourself. Your re­ sponse has to fit your own style. Here are some suggestions to get you started. 
A put-down primer lf you feel put-down by the comment, you must answer. Forget the jus­ tification or truth of the comment. If you inter­ pret the rem ark as a crack against you. you have to make a reply. 
The reply should not have the aim of changing the other person. Your goal: to say something that will make you feel better about yourself. 
Take your time before you reply. A brief pause often enables you to think of an effective answer. 
Be prepared. Learn some stock phrases. 
Some women with dif­ ficulty in the put-down area can’t think of an on-the-spot response. 

Learn some sentences that you can call upon almost automatically — for example, “ What are you so angry about?" . . . 
“ Was that a put-down?" . 
. . “ How come you’re in such a bad mood today?” 
If you have a date with a particular friend who always puts you down, it helps to plan in advance. 
Figure out what crack he/she might make this time and how you might answer it. 
Do not use the words 
“ I", “ me,” or ‘‘because’ in the first sentence of your answer. Starting off 

 with any of these makes you sound defensive immediately. 

Break the above rule vv hen it comes to the close relationship. Answering a put-down from a hus­ band or child is different from responding to a salesperson or a co­ worker whom you know onlv superficially. 

With people to whom you arc close, your intent is to increase commun­ ication. not counterat­ tack. Lines like. " I really feel hurt by what you said.” or, "That remark really bothers me. Why did you say it?” work well. 

Even if you’ve spent a lifetime suffering from what the French call l’csprit dc l’escalier (the wit of the staircase, meaning you think of what you should have said on the staircase en route to bed), you can learn to handle putdow ns. 

The rules I ’ve given are for novices. 
As you achieve greater creativi­ ty in riposte, you can break them. As an exam­ ple. I offer the legendary quip of 
Sir 
Winston 
Churchill. 

After his capture in the 
Boer W ar, 
Churchill joined the South African 
Light Horse Division and grew a mustache. A friend of his mother’s told him she eared neither for his politics nor his mustache. 

Responded Churchill. 
"Madam . I can see no earthly reason why you should come into contact with cither.”

Conducted by FRANK TINNEY, President, R. I. Stewart & Co. Inc.

The course consists of 4 sessions. The first will include a frank discussion of today's economy, prices, interest rates and the current investment outlook. 

 later sessions will include taxable and tax-exempt bonds, tax-deferred annuities, stocks, funds, and a special discus­ sion on how to make an investment plan to fit your own personal situation. 

Content will be simple, candid and without sales solici­ tation. Each class will include time for questions. The price is a $5 donation (per family) to any charity.

This is time to plant seed 

SA N A N TO N IO EXPRESS— Thursdoy March 3 I 977 

KATHY IN SUE BRETT FASHION 
... with Plymouth Henry, Pam Severance of St. Anthony 
J I 
Fashions for stars 

“Sue Brett's contemporary fashions vitH be modeled all day Saturday in the 
Spectator Shop at Frost's North Star mn. 
A special salute to the St. Anthony 
Reservations (ST A R ) Secretaries will be paid at 2:3(1 p.m. Rum Severance, head of the association, will be on hand to explain membership in this group to ans one interested in joining. 
ST A R Secretaries keep the wheels of business going sm oothly for their 
"bosses.” The St. Anthony Hotel has instituted a program for them which includes two luncheons a year. Frost s fashion shows, prizes and awards and benefits in trips. 

It is the S T A R S who handle hotel and travel reservations, sightseeing and entertainment plans for V II* visitors. 
Chuck Harris. Sue Brett envoy from 
New York, will be on hand to present the fashion collection. The contem­ porary denims group is made up or fashions suitable for the office, college, and city and country activities. 

The denim group features shirt dresses, split skirts, and jum psuits with tunnel waists. Colors of white, neutral tans, wheat and ecru are im ­ portant along with vivid pastels. 
Sundresses are also included, de­ signed for country fun or dancing. 

The first weekend in March is usually w hen I decide whether to start my outdoor garden from seeds or transplants. 
If my work didn t interfere. I would always start from seeds. 
Fo r one thing, the only way to be sure that transplants of the varieties I want will be available is to make ar­ rangements several months in advance with a local nursery. 
In fact, it may be possible for you to order special varieties and then turn the seeds over to a professional for growing on; nice, if you can afford it. 
However, starting your own seeds is not only a way to save money and grow rare flowers and gourmet vegetables, but there's nothing like the satisfaction of watching your garden grow from scratch. 
Actually, one of the satisfactions of turning 4o. which I did last week, is hav ing three teen-aged children, all of whom like to grow plants from seed. 
So, this year we’ve decided they can start all the seeds we ordered, no matter how busy I am. 

F r o s t -1 re c 
In our area, .frost-free w eather usually arrives around M others Day, so we ll plant any seeds that need to be started indoors by the middle of March in order to allow them the eight to ten weeks of growing time needed. 
You can adjust timing, depending on your local frost-free date 
There are lots of ways to start seeds indoors, but here's the easy procedure I follow: 
1. Fill pots, seedflats or large tin cans (with drainage holes punched iii the bottom) with packaged, all-pour- pose potting soil which has been ster­ ilized; level and firm one inch from the top of the container. 
2. Add a half-inch layer of a sterile p lan tin g m edium such as m illed 
(screened) sphagnum moss or vermiculite. 
3. Sow seeds. How deep to cov er them is the main puzzler, but the rule of thumb is: Cover seeds with a sterile planting medium to the depth of their own thickness. 
If the seed is dustlike, sim ply scatter it over the surface and press lightly. 
4. Set the container i i i a tray of water and leave to soak until moisture shows on the surface: remove, allow to drain. 
5. Enclose the planting, container and all. in a transparent plastic bag. 
Place where temperatures range 

L> 
Coming 
Sunday 

IF T '. r 

■ '■ S r ll hat TI is doing lo your child 

In tin* E x press-IN cw s

Plants in the 
Home 

By 

 e l v in M c d o n a l d 

S s^ . 

 between 65-75F, in a bright, natural light or in a flouorescent-light garden. 
6. Watch for signs of green; some seedlings appear in three or four days, others m ay require several weeks. 
When you see green, begin to remove the plastic, at first for a few hours daily, gradually increasing the time until no cover is needed. 
The idea is never to let the growing medium dry out, either before or after the seeds sprout. However, once the seedlings are up. some fresh air w ill he needed so that they will be strong. 
D irect sun 

7. As soon as seeds sprout, they’ll need some direct sun, or a place about four inches below the tubes in a fluor­ escent-light garden. (Bi* sure that no hot sun shines directly on seedlings covered with plastic.) 
8. As the seedlings grow, you can tell by appearance if they need more light 
(pale and spindly) or less (stunned and yellow ish green). If the seed lings crowd together, use tweezers to pull out enough to allow a little air circulation between them. 
9. By the time the seedlings are large enough to handle, transplant them, either an inch or two apart in large pots or flats, or to in d iv id u a l two- or three-ineh pots. 

Kl. When you are fairly certain there will be no more killing frost, begin to take your seedlings outdoors. At first. place them on a porch, under shrubs, or in some other spot protected from hot sun and strung winds all day. 

After a few days, the house-pam ­ pered seed bugs will have hardened enough to the outside air (or you to transplant them directly to the garden.

LIKE ALL GOOD COOKS 
... Sophia only uses the best 
T/ie in Italy 

“ I love to sing and dance, play cards and gamble at poker! Life has never been better!” 
In fact, like a rare vin­ tage wine, she seems to improve with age and to truly enjoy her new maturity. 
Her successes art5 many but, she claims, she’s far more given to acting because of her need for self-expression than because of fame and praise. 
“ The w orld makes stars. I make film s and the best spaghetti in 
Italy!” 

 c h o t t s c o a k u m 

Sophia's recipe com­ pendium. “ Cooking With 
Love.” is still popular with with her fans. 
“ Spaghetti is still one of my favorite dishes. 
Please be sure and tell your readers to cook it always a1 dente!” she said, laughing. 
Recipes for easy and delicious dishes from So­ phia Loren follow: 
Sophia Loren s 
Chicken on the Spit 
(Serves 3 to 41 
I roasting chicken, cleaned, dressed, weigh­ ing 3 1/2 to 4 lbs. 
Olive oil 
1 
1/2-pound slice of ham 
2 or 3 leaves of sage or 
1/2 teaspoon ground sage 
Pinch of fennel seed 
Salt, pepper to taste 
I large clove garlic, peeled, minced 
8 or 7 tissue-thin slices of prosciutto 
(Italian ham) 
Wash, dry chicken car­ efully. 
Brush lavishly withOlive oil and let rest several hours. 
Mince ham, mix with 

 sage, fennel seed, salt and pepper. Stuff bird; close both neck and back openings with skewers or by sewing with thread. 
Rub outside of bird all over with garlic, then drape bird com pletely with prosciutto. Tie bird up w ith s trin g like a package, and position on a spit. 
Roast slowly, if possi­ ble, over a low wood fire, which is the best of all. 
AFTERTHOUGHTS: If desired, b ird can be roasted indoors on bar­ beque spit. The flavor is sensational and the bird succulent! 
Spaghetti with 
Artichoke Sauce 
(Serves 6) 
8 large artichokes 
Water 
1 large lemon 
About 1/2 cup fine- grade olive oil 
2 or 3 cloves garlic, peeled, crushed. 
Large handful chopped parsley l !v pounds spaghetti, cooked a1 dente 
Clean artichokes car­ e fu lly , rem ove outer leaves and woody part of the stem. Remove prickly ends, cut artichokes into quarters. 
Dice part remaining on the stem. 
Put all the pieces into a bowl of water into which you have squeezed the juice of one lemon. Soak artichokes in water about 
2o minutes. 
Meanwhile, pour olive oil into skillet Add garlic and parsley. Heat the 
(tan. add artichokes, very well drained. Let cook about 4o minutes over low heat u n til m ixture becomes thickish sauce. 
Pour over hot cooked spaghetti Delicious! 
AFTERTHOUGHTS: 
Sophia’s dish is some times served with fresh- ly grated 
Parmesan cheese but Sophia says, 
“ It isn’t even necessary to use grated cheese!”

March 
1o-12 in the mall. 
Housewives, business men and women, hob­ byists and professionals w ill be showing th e ir skills during this second-annual event which is open to the pub­ lic for viewing and vot­ ing. 
Dem onstrations w ill include gum paste flowers, marzipan mold- 

Sophia cooks with love 

 ing. figure piping and creativity with chocolate.

— including equipment, books aud g ift ce rtifica te s— have been donated by Central 
Park M all and stores such us Maid of Scandia- av la. 

Read Ann Landers 

On Life 

 and Love 

 in the Son Antonio Express 

By JOHNA BLINN 

BEVERLY HILLS - “ When I was a child I was so thin and ugly, kids scribbled ‘stecchetto’ 
(little stick) on the door of my grandmother’s house,” said ac­ tress Sophia Loren. 

Looking at the w orld-fam ous 
Neapolitan beauty today, it’s hard to imagine she was ever either scrawny or ugly! 
However, like many people who sur­ vived the war, she’s known the pangs of hunger. 
“ Back then, we were glad to have black bread and soup — although it 

 was nothing like the wonderful mines­ trone soup I fix today,” she said with a laugh, gold-green eyes flashing. 
The years have been kind to Sophia. 
She was here for the Golden Globe 
Awards; she’s still top favorite actress with the foreign press. Sophia loves to cook for her friends. Her menus are often inspired by her geographical surroundings and her guests. 

“ lf I were entertaining in Rome, I d serve my Roman specialty penile all' arrabbiata (macaroni cut on the bias, served w ith a delicious and fie ry tomato sauce laden with chile peppers) or caricofi alia guida (deep-fried arti­ chokes) or a flavored ricotta. 
“ In my forest farm near the Po, I often prepare roast pheasant from the 

 hunting reserve or a delicious dish of river eel. 
“ I like to choose something that is not only a pleasure for guests but does honor to the local cuisine. All it lakes is a little thought and a lot of love! 
“ My grandmother, Luisa, taught me to cook. She was a second mother to me. 
“ We were poor, but she taught me that the most indispensable ingredient of all good home cooking is love for those you are cooking fo r!” 
Like all good cooks, she insists upon using only the best of ingredients, and fresh ones at that. “ Why is there so much frozen meat?” she sighed, 
Sophia seems at last to have found complete fulfillment since her happy marriage to producer Carlo Ponti and 

San Antonio Cypress fari&famiy 
TI____ I__ AA___ L. O I O TT D___ 
I P>/ 
VThursday March 3 I 9 7 7 Page 
I -D 
A 

 the birth of their two sons. 
“ My whole life and all stages of my career have been marked by my urgent need for protection and security. I have had to fight hard, particularly in my private life, but each time I’ve won! 
Food is for me a symbol of security, just as the roof that shelters me.” 
Sophia is still vitally interested in her career, but she seems even more con­ cerned about the education and up­ bringing of her boys. 
“ I’m truly a Neapolitan housewife at heart. I think every woman should have a husband to love and babies to hold and a fine dinner to cook.”

Consommes for fine dining 

By CRAIG CLAIBORNE 
NEW YORK TIMES N EW S SERVICE 

NEW YORK - No section of the A m er­ ican home has in the last two decades un­ dergone a tra n sfo r­ mation on as vast a scale as the home kitchen. 
Bit present-day A m e r ­ ican cooks, for all th eir involvement in exotic and at ti m es esoteric ('cok­ ery. ignore, by and l a r g e , one of th e g r e a t v basic ele m ents of fine dining. 
T h a t e l e m e n t is c o n ­ s o m m e . that h o n o ra b le , indispensable foundation of great dinner s since the dawn of the sophisticated kitchen in F rance. 
A fin e, w e l l - t e n d e d . rich and a m b e r - c o l o r e d c o n s o m m e c a n be c o m ­ pare d to a r a r e v in ta g e wine in its elegance and breeding. 
T h e i m p o r t a n c e of a c o n s o m m e for g r e a t 

Craig 
San Antonians say goodbye to 
Claiborne a n d bis a s ­ sociate Pierre Franey a ho came to San Antonio to demonstrate some o f their fine French -cook­ ing. While here, they ce eaten 
Mexican food almost non stop, judged a chili contest and been m a d e a lca ld es of the city. t hey ce even said they re com­ ing back on a pleassure trip! 

 leasts is obvious. 
It offers a clean, clear, hot, appetite-wbetting in­ t r o d u c t i o n to a m e a l , particularly one that will include rich foods laced w ith c r e a m — be t h e y m a i n c o u r s e s , a c c o m ­ panim ents or dess erts 
And th e k in d s of c o n ­ s o m m e s a r e a l m o s t without n u m b e r . N ea rly

Win dsor 
(c on­ s o m m e with ca lv e s foot and flavored with tu rtl e h e r b s , g a r n i s h e d w ith 

 j u l i e n n e of c a l v e s foot- a n d - c h i c k e n q u e n e l l e s with chopped yolk of egg). 
As w ith m a n y d i s h n a m e s in th e F r e n c h repertory', th e r e ’s a goo-' deal of ro m a n ce and hi. tory in the h a m e s of the various consommes. .

C o n s o m m e c h a s s e u r o r h u n t e r - s t y l e is, b u t of course. a g a m e consomme.

Chicken 
Consomme 

6 pounds m eaty ch ic k ­ en bones (n eck s backs, wings and so on) 
I chicken (3 lb s .) 
J',, c u p s c o a r s e l y chopped celery 
I 1 2 c u p s c o a r s e l y chopped c arr ots 
I bay leaf 
I 1 2 c u p s c o a r s e l y chopped leeks 
I cup coarsely chopped parsley st e m s 

1 * 2 c u p s c o a r s e l y chopped onions 
I sprig fresh th y m e or 
I teaspoon dried 
14 pep perco rns, crushed 
J whole allspice 
J whole cloves 
6 q u a rts 
(J4 cups) water 
Salt to taste 
I large unpeeled onion ti egg whites ti crushed egg shells. 

P l a c e 4>2 p o u n d s of c h ic k en b o n e s a n d tin* chicken in a large kettle and add wate r to cover. 
B r in g to th e boil. Let s i m m e r about 3 minute s and drain. 

Add cold w ate r to the kettle and let it run until t h e c h i c k e n a n d t h e c h i c k e n p i e c e s a r c c hilled . D ra in t h o r o u g h ­ ly. 

Wash out the kettle and re tu rn the chic ke n an d chicken part s to the ket­ tle. 
Add 
J c u p s of c h o p p e d c e l e r y . I c u p chopped carrots, the bay leaf, I cup of leeks, \<2 cup of parsley, I cup of onions, the th y m e, p ep ­ p e r c o r n s , a l l s p i c e , cloves, the ti q u a r t s of w ater and salt. Bring to the boil and s i m m e r 3o minutes. 

M e a n w h il e , split th e un peeled onion in half. 
Pla ce the onion halves, cut side down, in a black iron skillet and cook over m oderate heat uni ii the b o tt o m s a r c s o m e w h a t b u r n t a n d b l a c k e n e d . 
Add this to the kettle. 
At the end of 3o m i n ­ u t e s c o o k i n g t i m e , remov e the chicken and set it aside for ano ther use su ch as for a c a s ­ serole. s a n d w ic h e s an d so on. 
Let the kettle continue to s i m m e r for 3 hours longer. 
Using a sh a rp cleaver, chop the re m a in in g m e a ­ ty c h i c k e n b o n e s in to s m a l l p i e c e s a n d a d d them to a mixing bowl. 
Add about J* cup s of the strained broth. Add the re m ain ing cu p each of p a r s l e y , onion, c e l e r y . leeks and carrots. 
B e a t th e e g g w h i t e s u n t i l f r o t h y . A d d th e whites and cru shed egg shells and stir to blend. 
This m ix tu re is called a clarification. 
Add this to the kettle and let s i m m e r slowly for a b o u t J h o u r s w i t h o u t dis turbing the top of the 
-mixture.

New York Times food writers meet Chef Joaquin Gonzalez in the kitchen at La Louisiane. Craig Claiborne, center, and Pierre 
Franey were entertained at lunch by the restaurant's director, 
George Dareos. Claiborne and Franey have been in San Antonio conducting a benefit Cooking School sponsored by the Junior 
W om en’s Committee of the 
San Antonio Symphony. 

H ow ev er, as the m i x ­ ture cooks, use a ladle and scoop out a little of t h e s i m m e r i n g l i q u i d f r o m a r o u n d t h e p e r ­ im ete r of the soup. 
L a d l e t h i s o n t o t h e center of the solids that float on top.

Consomme 
Julienne

Madrilene

S A N A N T O N IO EX P R E SS— 
Thursday M arch 3 1 9 7 7 

Tapas whet the appetite 
Perk up with 
Nestle Hot Cocoa this morning. 

By JANE ULBRICH 
Express Food Editor 
Chef Juan T urpin of Spain hardly had time for lunch dur­ ing his whirlwind day and a half in San Antonio — much less a chance to eat any of the city ’s fam ous Mexican food. 
Ut* hopes to rome back in about a year, however, to see more of the city, taste its cuisines and prepare some of his specialties for San Antonians. 
We talked about his cooking via an interpreter during his brief visit, and 
Chef Turpin promised that if I got to 
Spain before he got back to the States, he would personalty prepare a meal for me in his Restaurant Via Veneto in 
Seville. 
(Who could resist such an invitation from this handsome Spaniard!) 
Seville is in the heart of Spanish green olive country, and Turpin is in the U.S. on behalf of his nation s green olive industry. 
Although several types of olive trees are grown in Spain, only two varieties of green olives are exported to the 
U.S.—Spain’s best customer 
The queens are large, deep green, fleshy and plump; the smaller man- zanilla olives are lighter green in color and have a finer texture with a smooth, silky skin. 

(Tower of Gold Canapes) 
(Makes 8) 
\ cup mayonnaise 
1/3 cup Spanish stuffed green olives, finely chopped 
I tablespoon prepared mustard 
I tablespoon milk 
8 white bread slices 
I large tomato, cut in 8 slices 
Vfe medium cucumber, cut in 8 slices 
1 large cooked potato, peeled and cut in 8 slices 
2 hard-cooked eggs, each cut in 4 slices 
8 .anchovy fillets, drained 
8 Spanish stuffed green olives 
Parsley sprigs for garnish 
In small bowl, combine mayonnaise, chopped olives, mustard and milk until well mixed. Using 3-inch round cookie cutter, cut out a circle from each bread slice; discard crusts (see note). 
Spread bread with some mayonnaise mixture; place on cookie sheet. 
For each canape, arrange in layers on bread, a slice of tomato, cucumber, potato and egg. Spoon on I tablespoon mayonnaise mixture; top with anchovy fillet and olive. 
Repeat, making 7 more canapes. 
Bake in 35o degrees F. oven for IO minutes or until canapes are heated through. Serve with knife and fork. 
Garnish parsley. 
Note; 
Use crusts in stuffings or bread pudding. 

O liv e C r o q u e tte s 
S u p r e m o s 

To be sure you’re buying olives from 
Spain, look for the Spanish Olive Ex- porters Association’s symbol , —a pimicnto-stuffcd olive wearing a top hat — on labels or caps of jars. 
Though olives are an important in­ gredient in Spanish cuisine in general, they are particularly tasty in Turpin’s specialty— tapas. 
Turpin calls tapas ' knife and fork” appetizers. 

°°zss Wake up with

Every Day in The News. 

By RUBY LOU POTTS 
Home 
Service 
Supervisor 
City Public Service 

Tasty, thrifty and convenient are the magic words for food preparation today. Everyone wants food to taste good. 

B udgeting has to be a part of the most g en e ro u s household and w hat pantry and refrigerator are not stocked with convenience foods? 
Put all these assets together, and you have the m ak in g of a great m eal or snack. Many tim es new roles can be given to fam iliar foods for a creative lunch or supper. 
Today’s recipe com bines som e old favorites to m ake a new hit. Corned 
Beef Pinwheels with Hot Cheese Sauce. 

Corned Beef Pinwheels with Hot Cheese Sauce 

1 can (15-ounce) corned beef hash 
2 tablespoons prepared m ustard 

1 2 teaspoon onion powder . 

* 4 teaspoon garlic powder 

1 4 teaspoon pepper 
2 cups biscuit mix 
2 tablespoons shortening 

J 2 cup water 
C o m b in e h a s h , m u s t a r d , onion powder, garlic powder and pepper. Mix well and set aside. 
Blend biscuit mix. shortening and w ater to make a soft dough. Form into 

 a ball; roll out on a floured surface into a 12x9-inch rectangle. 
Spread hash over dough; roll like jelly roll beginning at narrow side. Cut into nine I-inch slices. 
P lace in a lig h tly -g re ased 9-inch square pan. Bake at 45o degrees ap­ proximately 3o minutes. 
Serve with Hot Cheese Sauce. Makes 
9 pinwheels. 
Hot Cheese Sauce 

2 tablespoons m argarine 
2 tablespoons flour l i teaspoon salt 

> 2 teaspoon dry m ustard 

1 4 teaspoon pepper 
I cup milk v2 cup grated Cheddar cheese 
Melt m argarine over low heat. Blend in flour and se a so n in g s; s tir until smooth. Add milk and cook slowly until thickened stirrin g occasionally. Add cheese and stir until melted. 

MICROWAVE OVEN METHOD: 
Melt m a rg a rin e in m icro w av e 3o seconds; blend in flour and seasonings and stir until smooth. Add milk and conk in m icrowave 3 m inutes or until thickened stirring after each minute. 
Add ch eese an d s tir until m elted . 
Makes I1** cups. 

HOME ECONOMIST RUBY LOU POTTS 
...serving Corned Beef Pinwheels 
Egg dish for dieter 

If you're the only dieter in y o u r fa m ily , m e al planning can be a pro b ­ lem. Solve it with a low- c a lo rie eg g e n tre e . An o m e le t. q u ic h e or poached egg dish can be satisfying for everyone. 
F o r n o n - d ie te r s . 

 p ro v id e e x tra s such as bread and butter, a sauce lor the vegetables you eat with herb seasoning and a “ store-bought” dessert th a t a n o t h e r fa m ily m em ber serves while you reach for yo u r u n sw ee ­ tened fruit. 

Nibbling at good nutrition 

S n ack in g and d ie tin g seldom go hand in hand. 
But. if three m eals a day just isn’t enough for you. keep h ard -cooked eggs on hand in the refrigerator. 
For a price of only 82 calories, a large egg will provide lots of high-qua­ lity p ro tein an d an im ­ p ressiv e a s s o rtm e n t of 
\ gam ins and m inerals. 
For variety, try a d if­ ferent herb or seasoning each tim e you nibble an egg.

Wine hits a peak 

A glance along the shelves in your local wine shop will show the vintages availa­ ble in 
Burgundy wines to be 74s, 73s. 
72s. and some 7os. 

Tin* B9s and Tis, for the most part the outstand­ ing vintages, have disap­ peared from \ leu. If you should see either of these two years at a reasonable price then by all means buy them in preference to the others mentioned 
The 73s are probably the harshest of the Bur­ gundies available today. 
The 72s and 74s matured sooner and in many cases are pleasant to drink, especially the wines from the Cote De Beaune — l’ommard. Yolnuy. San* tenay and Aloxe Carton. 
Look into your cellar this time of the year and think about the life ex­ pectancy of your B u r­ gundies/ t'nder ideal conditions 
(.V> to Btl degrees, dark and no \ibrations) Bur­ gundies will last as much as 5o years. Iii rare cases longer. 
Plateau 

But they reach their peak in about 111 years and will maintain a pla­ teau depending upon the 
'strength of their particu­ lar vintage. 
We have some 1o57s thai are elegant and ex­ cellent. Yet. we have some 1%‘Js that were not 
- handled as well (subject- 
‘ eci to varying tempera­ tures). and they are dy­ ing. 
It would be g o o d to drink your 59s. B“Js. aud 
Bds now. Your Bls may last longer than any of these. The Otis are in their prime, with a full robe and a big nose. 
The B9s. in some eases, are not quite ready and iii others have reached al­ most full bloom. 
Probably the greatest sadness iii the cellar is to have a beautiful bottle rem ain too lo n g and quietly slip away without being drunk. 
Let's take this oppor­ tunity to inventory and catalog!

New bread is available 

(irain'ola, a whole grain, high fiber bread has been in­ troduced by | 
Richter's Bakery. 
Herman J. Kidder Jr.. bakery president, calls 
(irau i’ola a unique com­ bination of natural whole grain* and nature s fiber. I 
I’he new bread is now I available Iii San Antonio. 
Austin. Corpus Christi. 
Victoria and surrounding areas Valley and South I 
Texas shoppers can also find it on their grocers' shelv cs. 
Uram 'ola contains no preservatives or refined i sugar, Richter points out i and it is sweetened with | molasses and honey. 
**\\e know that housewives prefer flavor, nutrition and genuine ingredients and that s why we are offering this new bread. 
•(irain'ola offers a nu­ tritious aud deliciously flavorful loaf. 
Richter notes, ‘ and when toast­ ed, ifs extra delicious, 
’ By including such na- tut ai ingredients as whole rye meal, steam rolled whole wheat and tracked rolled burley along with spring wheat and old fashioned oat­ meal, we have produced a delicious loaf of bread the whole family .wifi en tov," Richter says
