Introducing Samovar 
868 proof vodka. 
What makes it different is what makes it better. 

.Just like the world’s finest Scotch and Canadian whiskies. Samovar comes toyon at 8 6 .8 proof. The International Proof 
8 6 .8 , however, is more than just the International Proof. When it comes to vodka, it’s the perfect proof. 
Perfect for drinking straight and ice cold— the ultimate test of a vodka. Ju st as perfect for adding a touch of perfection to your favorite mixed drinks. 
But proof isn’t the only thing that makes Samovar different. I low we get it to that very special proof is different, too. 
No other vodka is quite like Samovar because no other vodka is distilled like Samovar. Through a costly and painstakingly precise method. 
Resulting in a vodka that's Ultra I)ry. And exceptionally sine Kit Ii. Vet, with a lively quality that's unique and consistent Iv rewarding.

It you want a better vodka, look for proof.

S A N A N T O N IO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 I 977 
Two U.S. courts’ staffers spending nights in classes 

Two employes of the federal courts here are spending their evenings attending college classes with an eye toward car­ eer advancement. 
Sarah Munford, who works in the U.S. District 
Clerk s office, is major­ ing in criminal justice at 
Southwest Texas State 
University. 
Mrs. M unford, who lacks 21 hours for a degree, attends class at the SVYTSU extension t enter at Lackland AFB 
And 
Marcie Mood is studying to be a legal assistant in a program 

 offered by San Antonio 
College. 
The U.S. Magistrate 
Court secretary is in her first semester in the pro­ gram. 
Also participating in educational programs is 
Ld Prado, an assistant federal public defender. 

Prado attended an ad­ vanced evidence seminar in Los Angeles last week. 
The meeting was spon­ sored by the National 
College of Criminal De­ fense Lawyers and Pub­ lic Defenders. 
A 
Mac Arthur High 
School graduate. Stan­ 

 ley E. Crawford Jr.. has joined Chief U.S. Dist. 
Judge Adrian A. Spears' staff as a law clerk 
Crawford also attend­ ed Brown University and the University of Texas 
School of Law in Austin. 
He came on board 
Monday, fresh from last week's state bar exams. 
Another U.S. Courth­ 

 ouse newcomer is Diane 
Jacoby, who joined Sgt. 
Adolph P ena’s federal complex security staff. 
The wall is still bare at the front entrance of the 
Courthouse where the picture of former Presi­ dent Ford once hung. 
The President Carter photographs have not ar­ rived for posting. 
Grape group elects chief 

AUSTIN (AP) - Ed 
Auler of 
Austin has been elected as the first president of the Texas 
Grape Growers Associa­ tion, which w as organ­ 

 ized to promote the grape industry in Texas. 

Texas grape growers held a one-day confer­ ence Tuesday. 

Lorry Kingry, in top aircraft, and Harry Shepard, in bottom one, practice precision flying routine over Aeroflex Airport near Andover, N J . Copilots for large airlines, the men demonstrate during their spare time — precision aerobatics in their W aco Aerobatic aircraft at shows around 

 the nation. — AP Wirephoto.

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 

Blood sought for policeman 

A volunteer blood drive will be held Thursday in the name of a San 
Antonio police officer wounded in the line of duty. 

S tu d e n ts at the Air T ra in in g 
( ominand Non-commissioned Of- iicer Academy at Medina Annex. 
Lackland AFB. will conduct the blood drive in honor of Patrolman 
Valentine Lope/. 

Lopez was wounded on the night of Feb. 17 while making a distur­ bance call at an East Side lounge. 

The drive is being held in con­ junction with the South Texas Re­ gional Blood Bank. 

During his first 48 hours at Bap­ 

 tist Hospital. Lopez received 23 un­ its of blood. 

Sgt. Barr K. King, student co-or­ dinato r for the drive said, “ We realize that Officer Lopez is covered under the South Texas Regional 
Blood Banks Blood Assurance Pro­ gram . nonetheless, we are public servants as is Officer Lopez and we want to do this in his nam e." 

Marty Stone, volunteer donor re­ cruiter for the South Texas Regional 
Blood Bank, said the drive will be at 
Building 146 on Medina Base from ll a.m. to 2 p.m. 
She said 48 volunteer donors had all ready signed up for drive and pledge cards were still available for those who wished to donate in Of­ ficer Lopez’s name. 

Epilepsy research grant made 

By DAVID MCLEMORE 
Epilepsy, a common disorder affect­ ing more than 6oo San Antonians, is surrounded by widespread prejudice and misconception, according to Dr. 
John P. Allen. 
Dr. Allen, assistant professor in the neuroscience div ision at the University of Texas Health Science Center, re­ cently received a $3o,ooo grant to help correct those misconceptions. 
The Texas Department of Mental 
Health/Mental Retardation made the grant to foster research to develop a com prehensive epilepsy education program for patients of the Bexar 
County Hospital District. 
O s tra c is m 
"The tragedy of people with epilepsy is that while treatm ent is usually ef­ fective in controlling seizures, patients still suffer social and psychological consequences like ostracism and job­ lessness," Dr. Allen said. 
" It’s extremely difficult to erase the mystique that has surrounded epilepsy 

 for centuries, especially when the dis­ ease has been associated with demonic possession and exorcism." 
Dr. Allen prefers not to use the term 
"epileptic." He describes the neurolo­ gical d iso rd er as the o ccu ran ce of sudden sp o n tan eo u s ep iso d es of temporary loss of consciousness. 
Severity of the episodes may range from sm all, often unnoticed lapses 

(petit mal) to the incapacitating gran mal convulsions that cause ‘total lack of control. 
Dr. Allen said patient compliance with medication rates in San Antonio is low and he hopes his research will lead to an answer why. 
Paramount to treatment success, he said, is the maintainance of the patient on anti-convulsant drugs to keep him 

 seizure-free. 
The grant w ill enable development of education and group sessions to give patients e n c o u rag em en t in dealing with social and psychological prob­ lems. 
Comm on se n se in fo rm a tio n and educational materials will be prepared for physicians and employers. Dr. Al­ len said. 
Top T exas Mason due honors 

The top ranking Mason of Texas will be honored Saturday during Texas 
Masons Day. 
Herman Vinyard of McAllen, grand m aster of the Grand Lodge of Texas, 
Ancient Free and Accepted Masons, together with other Grand Lodge of­ ficers from Waco, will be honored in the all day ceremonies. 
Texas Masons Day will begin at IO a m. with a procession from the Scot­ 

 tish Rite Temple to the Alamo, where heroes of the shrine of Texas liberty will be honored, especially those who were Masons. These include Ben Mi­ lam, Davey Crockett, William B. T ra­ vis. Jam es Bowie. Jam es Bonham, 
Almoron Dickenson and John ('. Clark. 
Members of Masonic Blue Lodges. 
Alzafar Shrine Temple, Scottish Rite bodies. York Rite bodies and members of the Order of DeMolay will partici­ 

 pate in the procession to the Alamo for the wreath laying ceremonies. 
A Masters, luncheon sponsored by the Wardens, Secretaries and Past 
Masters Assn. of Masonic District 39 will honor the Grand Master and other 
Grand Lodge officers. 
The luncheon will be in the banquet hall of the Scottish Rite T em ple. 
Avenue K and Fourth Street, starting at noon.

HOMECRAFT CORPORATION is an aggressive fast paced residential construction firm, dedicated to sound principals of managerial develop­ ment. We are seeking self-starter, who is interested in all phases of residential construction and management. 
This Management-Trainee position will be filled by an intelligent, goal-oriented individual who is wining to wo rte long Pours, o days a week and who needs a growth position, where income is directly related to his contribution to meeting company objectives. A college degree is not necessary, but any college is a plus. Construction experience is not required, but we prefer 5 years business and/or military background. 
W e offer company paid benefits, 2 weeks paid vacation, profit sharing, and salary and performance reviews every 6 months. lf you are in the formative stage of your career and meet the above qualifications, call Collect immediately:

" 
Gold, Silver and Precious Stones 
Sunday Worth 6, 1:3o PM 
Mondoy Worth 7, 1:3o PW 
A t The La Posada H otel lOOO Z a ra g o za , Laredo Texas 7 8 o 4 o ova 1ooo lo ts Of solid gold rings, bracelets, pocket watches, necklaces, earrings, brooches, pendants, medallions, coins, fobs, platinum, sterling, rubys, diamonds, peorls, emeralds, topaz, tiger eye, etc, etc - appraised con servatively at one half million dollars. 
HIGHLIGHTING: Several repeater pocket watches including a Petrel and 
Berthoud, railroad ond hunters watches, lotion Pkard ond Roles watches 
Dozens of solitaires ond clusters of mounted precious stones jewelry in eluding a lot of 8o carats bag diamonds I8S4 Kellogg and Co S?o goldpiece, silver coins by the bog 8 oz man s choinlink Gold bonds Religious medals, you nome it'! You will be dazzled by the variety ond quality of the aesthetic beauty of this collection 
HISTORY: this auction represents the lifelong investment of a Laredo businessman who for 5o yeocs, shrewdly invested his funds in the world s most stable morket-Gold, Silver ond precious stones Inspired by o recent U 
S Customs Gold Auction in Laredo, and serious health problems, he has com­ missioned our firm to liquidate his possessions Although the owner wants his nome withheld, his story is fascinating. It began rn 1979 in Cuba, going door to door buying precious items Starting with only S7S ond parlaying it into a pirates chest! Before moving to Laredo he spent 7o years in the hills ond cities of Mexico, living in recluse but buying gold! 
A 14-page catalogue will be available at $3 from our firm with over 
1ooo lots going on the Auction Hock, you will need it!!! There is just too much to list in the media. 
TIRWS: Cosh, cashier s check or letter of credit with droit A S7S entrance fee per person must be levied to control attendance. 
We are acting >o!ey os agents, all sales are final sublet to consignor

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 

House okays tough new ethics code

County, N .Y ., Sh eriff's office uses a ring to sight his w eapon over his shoulder during 

 an exhibition of trick and com bat shooting. 

He is the U .S. and world titlist in com bat shooting, and was giving the exhibition at 

N e w Y o rk ’s W e s t Sid e Rifle and Pistol

Solons rub massage bill off the floor 

 tXPRt SS CAPITOL BUM AU 
M STIX - A bill giv­ ing counties authority to regulate massage parlors was rubbed out on the 
House 
Hour here 
Wednesday. 
HB34 by Rep. Gebe 
Green of Houston was sent back to committee on a successful point of order raised by his fellow 
Houstonian, Rep. Ben T. 
Reyes 
Almost as soon a 
Green's bill was brought up for second reading 
Wednesday morning, it was apparent it rubbed several legislators the wrong way. 
Serious, funny 
Points of order to block consideration ot tin* bill flew fast and furious — some serious and some downright funny. 
House speaker 
Bill 
Clayton remarked at one point. “ It looks like this bill is getting quite a massage of its ow ii. 
Finally Reyes raised the point the Intergo­ vernmental Affairs Com­ mittee which passed out 
( irecti s bill, had \ iolated the House rule requiring five days posting of no­ tice before hearing a bill. 
After a head-huddlc ut 
Clayton's podium, it was determined the com­ mittee had indeed heard the bill earlier — exactly 
24 minutes too early to comply with tin* five-day rule 
Clayton then ordered the bill back lo tin* com­ mittee which must now consider it a second time 
Support idea 
Meanvinile. in San An­ tonio Bexar County offi­ cials Judge Blair Reeves and — tor Sheriff \\ B. 
••Bill’* Hauck — Chief 
Deputy Rudy Garza sup­ port the idea of county regulation of massage parlors. 
“ Sure I ’m for it ," 
Reeves said. “ It s asinine t»» have the law circum­ vented iii that manner. 
AH they need to do is move outside Hie city li­ mits We live in u metro* 
|M»litan area and need the regulation 
Metropolitan problems 

 transcend arbitrary boundary lin es,” the judge added. 
Garza, meanwhile, in­ dicated comity officials bad talked to some stale legislators about their support foe county regu- lation of massage par­ lors 
No formal testi­ mony was offered, how­ ever. he said. 

Control areas 
( ireen’s bill set sevoral regulatory areas iii which counties may control massage parlors. 
These include licens­ ing. health standards, suspension or revocation of license for conviction of any penal code offense, inspection, limits on con­ tent of advertising, clothing standards and prohibiting massages of persons of the opposite sex. 
Rep. Smith E. Gilley of 
G reenville raised the lust two challenges to the bill. iii the first he charged the lull with violating the equal rights amendment to the Texas constitution bv barring massages of persons of the opposite sex 
Amid a burst of a laughter. 
Clayton overruled Gilley 's first objection. 
Charged 
Then G illey charged the advertising section of the bill was a violation of freedom of speech rights 
— again overruled by 
Clayton. 
Then Rep Craig W a­ shington of 
Houston wanted to know if Gilley would objeet to the lull oil the grounds it violated the constitutional protec­ tion against illegal search and seizure. 
Filially, Rep Bd Wat­ son of Deer Bark wanted to know if a point of order w.ym rfng to be raised that u p h ill violated sec­ tion 14B of the Taft-Hurt* ley Act known as the right to work law 
Amid |M*als of laughter over Washington and 
Watson's moves, Reyes made one of his own and had the last move and the last laugh 
First juror taken iii 
Davis m urder trial 

FORT WORTH <AC) 
- A Federal Aviation 
Administration employe became the first juror 
Wednesday to be selected for the capital murder trial of Fort Worth millionaire Cullen Davis 
It was the fifth day of jury selection 
Richard Ard of suburban Hurst was the 28th pro­ spective juror interviewed by the attorneys 
Ard told defence and prosecution attorneys that he subserdied to three local newspapers, but had read virtually nothing about the highly publicized slay­ ings at the Davis mansion on Aug 3, UGH 
Davis is on trial for the fatal shooting of his step­ daughter Andrea Wlibero. 12. and Stun Farr, JU, boyfriend of Davis’ estrarigged wife Priseilla 
Mrs Davis, who was living in the mansion while getting a divorce from Davis, was wounded along w itll a v is I tor, tills Cav ret 
Davis is also charger! with attempted murder in the Cav re! and Mrs. Davis shootings 

\rd was questioned for approximately three hours before both Sides told state District -fudge Tom I ave that ll*; was accepted. 
I ave then swore iii the juror admonishing hun not lo allow the death |M*ualty to affect his weighing of 
IIH tacts in the rase 
The stale has indicated a wilt **ek the death 

Afd answered most ut the questions with a bf lei 
"Aes stf" of no sit toil at one point during his 

D allas fie sm e a re d destined lo be passed 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - The House adopted a tougher new ethics code for itself Wednesday night after Speaker 
Thomas P. O’Neill, declaring that “ the issue is credibility," helped quell a rebellion over limits on outside in­ come. 
The code was approved on a roll call vote of 4o2 to 22 
O'Neill’s appeal to “ eliminate the potential conflict of interest," and “ the suspicion of impropriety,’ climaxed seven wearying hours of debate on the measure. 
Supporters of the bill were able to beat down a series of moves aimed at killing certain sections of the code, and in the end it was approved in virtually the same form as written by a special ethics reform commission. 
Before debate began. O 'N eill had expressed confidence that tin* lim ita­ tion on outside earnings would be passed. 
Outside income 
The Democratic majority soundly defeated a move by Rep. Morgan 
Murphy,’ D-111., backed by many 
Republicans, to wipe out the bill's most controversial provisio the fixing of a limit on lawmakers’ outside in­ come at la per cent of the legislative salary. 
The restriction means that a House 
Divestiture effort hit by Newton w 

ALIC E (A P ) — Breaking up/flic oil companies would increase p r i c e s . 
Railroad Commissioner Jon Newton said today . 
Newton called on the federal government to cease its effort toward divestiture. 
“ It should be plain to one and all. now, that such legislation would ac­ complish only one thing, and that is to sharply increase the cost of energy to the ultimate user,’’ Newton told a regional meeting of the American Pe­ troleum Institute s production d ivi­ sion. 
“ Rather than more Potomac plan­ ning — or perhaps plotting — we need to move rapidly to the development of alternate sources of energy . . . (with) our government in there encouraging, not discouraging,’’ he said 
Newton said Texas has appropriated no funds for energy research, "yet, we are spending money on highways, on education aud on health as though we have a printing press in the base­ ment." 
Carter puts lid oil hiring by agencies 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - President 
( arter ordered all federal departments and agencies Wednesday to fill no more than 75 per cent of their civilian job vacancies pending the establish­ ment of new employment ceilings 
The directive takes effect immedia­ tely and will continue nill ii the Office of Management and Budget develops new agency-by-agency ceilings, proba­ bly in April. 
\\ lute House Press Secretary Jodv 
Powell said N«tine departments might have to continue the hiring lids for a lunger period iii order to meet the ceilings now being prepared 
Iii his first “ fireside chat” to the nation on Feb. 2, Curter said; “ Soon. I will put a ceiling on the number of people employed by the federal government agencies, sn we can bring the growth of government under con­ trol." 
Spine affliction is corrected 

WASHINGTON (A P ) - A new kind ut internal splint is tieing used suc­ cessfully to correct a crippling spinal abnormality afflicting children that has been virtually untreatable, it was announced Wednesday 
Children’s Hospital National Medical 
(enter said tho device straightens an exaggerated outward bowing of the spine called kyphosis, winch produces an unsightly humpback effect. 
Dr Douglas VV McKay, chairman of pediatric orthopedic surgery and developer of the device, said he has placed the dev ice into eight children at the hospital 
The curved spine was completely corrected in five cases and about HU per cent corrected in the other three, he said 
“ This is a very difficult problem to manage and one of a lew problems of the spine in children that we don I have a good treatment for," McKav said. 

 member could earn no more than 
$8,825 a year from such activities as business or law practice, but it applies only to such “ earned" income and not to “ unearned” income from invest­ ments or other sources. 
Opposition to the limit centered on the distinction between “ earned” and 
“ unearned” income, which some claimed was discriminatory and would transform Congress into a stronghold of the wealthy. 
Constitution 

“ It was not the intention of the framers of the Constitution to exclude farmers, lawyers and people with bu­ siness experience from the Congress,” argued Rep. James Quillen, R-Tenn. 
But with sentiment for M urphy’s proposal apparently rising, O'Neill — who had staked a measure of bis leadership's prestige on adoption of a new code of conduct in this session — told tin* House: 
“ I appreciate that some of you are going to have to make sacrifices. But sacrifices we must make. The people of America demand an ethics code.” 
Rep. David Obey. D-Wis., who chaired the reform commission that wrote the new code, credited O’Neill's speech with stifling the opposition. 
“ ll was the most powerful statement of the night. After I heard that speech I knew we weren’t in trouble," Obey said. 
Disclosure 

Iii addition to setting the income limit, the code requires extensive fin­ ancial disclosure by law m akers, prohibits gifts over SUMI, abolishes of­ fice “ slush funds” while providing each House member with a $5.-ooo annual boost in orifice funds and bars foreign travel bv lame duck members and “ dutiable dipping” in official ex­ penses. 
The Senate is expected to act next week on a separate but similar ethics code of its (i\vn 
Republicans had com plained throughout the long debate that by sending the bill to the floor under a rule that sharply restricted the type and number of amendments that could be made, O'Neill and the sponsors were denying the House a chance to 
“ work its will” on an important piece of legislation. 
A Republican-led effort to change the rule and open up the bill to any and all amendments was firmly rejected. 
Obev and other supporters of the code said they feared unlimited am end­ ments would result in the proposal being torn apart.

 fD etox’ unit eyed for B exar 

A $425,ooo federal Economic Deve­ lopment Administration grant will let 
Bexar County Commissioners Court build a 52-bed alcohol detoxification unit next to the County Jail. 
Com. Tom Stolhandske Tuesday headed a special committee review of plans for the one-story building and settled the problem of operating the alcohol abuse-related facility, 
Services in the unit will be super­ vised directly by Bexar County Mental 
Health/Mental Retardation whose dir­ ector, Dr. Aaron Lie herman, has se­ lected Dr. Ardow Anted un as staff physician for the treatment center. 
Formal approval for the plans will be sought this week from the regional 
EDA office in Dallas, according to 
Stolhansdake, who also said bids should be let in JO days and contraction finished in six months. 
“ We’re trying to take the drunks out of the jail," Stolhandske said 
2o,ooo drunks 

In 1o75 alone, 2o.ooo bookings for drunkeness were caused by about 8,ooo people, the commissioner noted. He said such chronic illness needs to be handled iii a system other than the jail. 
Stolhndske hopes local judges will provide conditional sentencing that allow the alcoholics caught in the jus­ tice system to be processed through the detoxification center and into a treatment facility. 
“ V\e want them to understand what our program is,” Stolhandske added. 
A prisoner at Bexar < aunty Ja il booked lur drunkeness died of internal injuries there lust mouth. 
An investigation is still under way in that situation 
Stolhandske said current rules re­ quire a prisoner with visible injury or one who is complaining is immediately sent to Bexar County Hospital. 
Jail officials will fie responsible for security and maintenance of the de 
Unification unit. After reviewing plans for operation and construction, Stol­ handske told staff lo apply for tEDA approval and get on with tin* project

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 
Special brain problem 

Dear Dr. Thosteson: My mother is in her mid-7os and is a patient in a nursing home. 
She is physically in good condition. Her behavior is becoming impossible. Atter several months of treatment with tran­ quilizers and sedating drugs she still fluc­ tuates between great agitation and bland staring. 
The neurologist’s opinion is that she has Alz­ heimer’s disease. Other tests are being "planned. 
Will you tell me about Alzheimer’s disease? Is it physically or emotionally caused? Are there any cures? Are there any hereditary factors? — 
P.S. 
Alzheimer’s is a form of brain deterioration. It begins at a relatively early age (4o or 5o). but severe mental sym p­ toms occur later. 
•The cause of the aging is not entirely clear. It may be a brain cell en­ zyme deficiency that shortens cell life, or it nj ay be caused by artery hardening that leads to oxygen starvation of the brain cells. 
• There is no specific treatment. Blood vessel d-ilators 
(expanders) spell as niacin, one of the 
& -complex vitamins, has been tried. Possibly sex hormones of or mood boosters for depression can be considered. Hyperbaric oxygen chambers have been used, but the results of the artifieally increased brain oxygen supply are rather temporary. 
O ne might speculate on whether your mother's problem is as much mental as physical — for ex­ ample, a rebellion against the nursing home em ironment. 
You mention that other tests are planned These may reveal a more specific cause than Alzheimer’s disease, lf so, a specific treatment can follow. 
There is thought to be some family disposition to 
Alzheimer’s disease. 

L e g c r a m p s 
Dear Dr. Thosteson: I am HH years old and am getting leg cramps at night. Also I get dizzy spells. I have been using diuretic pills and wonder if they can be causing these problems. — TM . 
Diuretics (water pills) have to be used cautiously, particularly by older persons. They can cause ex­ cessive loss of important minerals (potassium chiefly), and that may produce muscle pain You should report the symptoms, including your dizzy spells, to your doctor. He may want to reduce the dosage in your pills or discontinue them altogether. 
It is difficult to comment on such general symptoms as dizzy spells, but you may find some helpful in­ formation in my booklet on the subject. Send a quarter and a stamped return envelope to me in care of this newspaper. 
Arthritis sufferers can be helped. Dr Thosteson s booklet discusses many types of arthritis and related |omt diseases as well as effective treatments and medications. For a copy of 
How You 
•Can Control Arthritis,’’ write to him in care of this newspaper. 
"Inclose a long, self addressed, stamped envelope and 35 cents 

Health 
By George C. 
Thosteson, M.D.

4) 
• 
TOMORROW - Guest is 
Robert Randall, a victim of glaucoma who is per­ mitted to smoke govern­ ment-supplied marijuana cigarettes. 

“ I ve been a has-been 
.nine times in my life.” said actor Eddie Brack­ en. 

 lie was in Hollywood to play a familiar Bracken role — a smooth-talking con man, who lures 
Lenny Markowitz (series star Adam Arkin) into his phony announcer’s school in the episode of 

"Busting Loose” to be broadcast Monday at 7:31) p.m. on KENS-TV. 

Touring on the stage and engaging in various outside interests have kept the former motion picture star constantly active since quitting I lol­ ly wood perm anently, after finishing his last feature film, "A Slight 
Case of L a rce n y.’’ in 
1953. 

“ I'm a workaholic,” he claims, as his schedule of the past few years would attest. On the stage, which has dominated iiis time since leaving 
Southern California, lie toured most recently in 
"The Odd Couple” and 
"The Sunshine Boys.” 

C urrently. 
Bracken operates his own ad agency-public relations firm in Houston. Texas, and for a time he owned a chain of eight community newspapers. His past even includes a stint as disc jockey on radio sta­ tion W B K ’. Bay Shore, 
N Y . 
— appropriate training for his “ Busting 
Loose” guest-starring role. 

His entertainment car­ eer has had its share of ups and downs. “ I've been broke twice.” be admits, “ but the ups' predominate.” 

At the moment, he is preparing a comedy. "A 
Hot Line to Heaven.” for 
Broadway, with writer 
K arry M aravig lia. in which his wife, Connie, and daughter. Carolyn, play his wife and daughter. 

Why did Bracken give up Holly wood at a career high point to concentrate on the theater? 

His reasons are sever­ al. Primarily, he regards the stage as his first love. 
He made his debut as an unsure 6-year-old in a 
Knights of Columbus play in Astoria, N Y., and it was the theater that led to his marriage, of 38 years standing, to Connie 
Nickerson, his leading lady in "What a Life.” the stage predecessor of the radio and film series about teen-ager Henry 
Aldrich. But there was an even stronger motive for his defection from motion pictures. 

" I was tired of playing schnooks.” he explains. 

Bracken finds it diffi­ cult to recognize the Hol­ lywood of today as Un* film capital lie knew in the 194o s. But. returning to Paramount lo shoot 

"Busting Loose" on the lot where he starred in four film s with B elly 
Hutton prov idee! a plea­ surable blend, he notes, of "fun and nostalgia.”

With spring in air, indoor plants abound 1 

SAN A NTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 I 977 
Pog< 
3-F 
Talk on energy due Friday 

Magnolia is in bloom about town, m ountain laurel has begun to dower and within the walls of Bexar County 
Courthouse th e r e ’s a sense of roses in the air. 

Clerk Lillian Galindo is dreaming up a storm of roses for this coming sum m er. And 
Lillian 
Powell the African violet lady in 
District 
Clerk 
Flton Cude's office, in­ sists her m arvelous plants visibly perk up with spring in the air. 
They never, never really look un-perked because her green thumb works year-round. 

Plants turning up on the table and by the wall in County Court at Law 
.lodge Carol Haherman's courtroom and rooting, clim b in g the w alls in 
Asst. L ist. Atty. Ted 
Lewis’ office, too. 

Mary Ann Lopez, in the District Clerk s of­ 

 fice. finding a large bou­ quet of pink-mauve-w hite flowers on her desk as a birthday token this week. 

Over in 87th District 
Court, clerk 
Ja n e 
Vollmer finding ways to help her grandparents — 
Mr. and Mrs. 
O scar 
(Kdna) Wood 
— cele­ brate their 89th wedding anniversary this month. 
There’ll be an open house in th eir honor at the 
Southern Manor Nursing 
Home where they now live. 

Young Jefferson High 
School senior 
Stephen 
Havel learn in g the 
Courthouse ropes from staffers in County Court 

 at Law Judge 
Spears’ office. 
Caroline 

At 18, 
Stephen plans on a law-related career and intends to enroll at 
St. M ary ’s U niversity this fall. The son of Mr . and Mrs. Charles Havel the young senior is one of about 23 students in the 
San Antonio School Dis­ trict executive internship program this year. 

The you n gsters, all good students, spend their third quarter learn­ ing what the working world is all about. Some 
“ apprentice” with attor­ neys in practice, other divisions of government or private industry. All 

 m ust report back to school each Friday to re­ view what they have done and learned and hear what others in the pro­ gram are experiencing. 

Graduation at Je f fe r ­ son is late May, about a week after Stephen fin­ ishes up his Courthouse assignment. 

Two assistant DAS de­ voting a good part of their time to that convo­ luted home repair swin­ dle — which is, appar­ ently. not wholly resolved yet — are David Ber- chelinann and 
Nelson 
Atwell of the special crimes section headed by 
Asst. Hist Atty. 
John 
Quinlan III.

WHAT TV IS 
- DOING TO OUR KIDS fljf I* ijflf Preschoolers are the largest TV audience, 
I J spending on the average a third of their waking hours in front of the tube. For that reason, parents — who put them in front of the set in the first place — are greatly concerned over the content of TV. But, says Marie Winn, author of the series WHAT TV IS DOING TO YOUR 
CHILDREN, what they should be worrying about is that while quietly watching TV, their children are forgetting how to play. 
You won't want to miss this series...

Marine auxiliary plans benefit sale 

A benefit sale sponsored by the Marine Corps 
League Auxilary will be held IO a.m. to 3 p.m. 
Saturday at Our Lady of Guadalupe Catholic Church. 
1321 El Paso St. 
Draperies, sheer panels, drapery remnants and lining, valances, fringe, satin bias binding, table rounds and other items will be sold. 
Proceeds from the sale will go to community 
P orojects.

National Environmental 
Assn.’s Triple E Award.

M cK etta was named outstanding A m erican engineering educator of the year in 1978 by the 
A m erican Society for 
Engineering Education.

Energ y 
Policy 
C om m ittee during the 
Nixon administration, chairman of the National 
Air Quality Management 
Committee of the Nation­ al Academy of Science and E n g in ee rin g and president of the Am eri­ can Institute of Chemical 
Engineers.

 of the

R eso u rces 
P lan n in g

G o v e rn o r’s 
Advisory 
Commission on Energy and was formerly chair­ man of the Texas Atomic 
E n erg y Advisory C om ­ mittee.

SAN ANTO NIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 

Gas settlement refund urged 

San Antonio Manufacturers Assn. has urged 
City Council to refund all funds from any settlem ent between City Public Service and 
Coastal States Gas Corp. 

“ All utility users in the metropolitan San 
Antonio area have been burdened with the passthrough charges and are certainly entitled to some compensation as a result of any finan­ cial settlement,” the manufacturers said. 

The association said, in the letter to the council, if the money is not refunded it then urges it be set aside in a special account and both principal and any interest be used for power generating facilities which will benefit all utility customers.

FEA cuts ceiling price of crude 

WASHINGTON (A P) - T h e F e d e r a l 
E n e r g y A d m in i st ra ti o n said W e d n e s ­ day it is reducing the ceiling p rice for dom es tic cr u d e oil by 45 cen ts a b a r r e l for the next five mo n th s to m a k e u p for excessively high ceilings last year. 

Pe ter Luedtke. an assista n t g e n e ra l counsel for F E A , said th e i m p a c t on c o n s u m e r p r i c e s w o u l d b e s m a l l , shav ing only a b o u t o n e - q u a r t e r of a cent p e r gallon fr o m th e c o st of oil 

 when av erag ed over the n a ti o n ’s total supply. 
Since F e b r u a r y 1978. th e F E A h a s set a series of g ra d u a l ly ri s in g p ric e ceilings on c r u d e oil as r e q u i r e d by 
Congress, following rules for r e s t r a i n ­ ing the av e rag e price. 
To avoid windfal l p ro fits for c o m ­ panies with low-cost oil from old wells, 
F E A h a s s e t tw o c e i l i n g p r i c e s , a 
“ lowertier” price for this old oil, an d an “ u p p e r-tie r” p rice ab out twice as 

 high for newer oil.To keep the a v e r a g e price moving u pw ard at ju st the right slow pace, F E A has had to e s t i m a t e how m uch old oil and new oil would be produced at the two dif ferent prices. 
Th e agency found late last y e a r th at its e s t i m a t e s hav e b ee n s l ig h tly off, perm it ti ng the a v e ra g e pri ce to rise too high. 
By t h e e n d of D e c e m b e r , s a i d 
Luedtke. oil p r o d u c e r s h a d co ll ected som e $22o million m o r e th a n F E A in­ 

 tended. an amoun t equivalent to only one or two p e rc e n t of t h e i r total oil receipts. 

Last Jan. I. the agency cut 2o cents from the “ u pper- tie r” price ceiling to begin correcting the a v e ra g e price. 

The latest move, c u tt in g the p rice another 45 cents pe r barrel, is to apply throughout M a r c h , April, May, J u n e and July, he said. 

London gold in 
$3 jump 

LONDON (A P) - Gold s u r g e d to a 1 5 - m o n t h hig h in 
L o n d o n 
W e d n e s d a y , g a i n i n g $2 an o u n c e to c l o s e a t 
$144,625 a few h o u r s a head of the latest gold auction in Washington. 
In Z u r i c h . E u r o p e ' s o t h e r m a i n b u l l i o n center, the yellow metal gained $2,75o from T u e s ­ day to close at $145,125. 

It was the highest Eon- don c lo s in g p r i c e s in c e 
; Nov. 8 . 1975. when gold closed at $145.9*1. 
D e a l e r s sa id s p e c u l a ­ tors and in v e s to r s w e re r e t u r n i n g to E u r o p e ’s gold m a r k e ts for the first t i m e s i n c e D e c e m b e r 
1974 when a new U.S. law- m a d e it legal for A m e r ­ icans to trad e in the bul­ lion. 

T h e W e d n e s d a y a u c ­ tion was the latest in the 
I n t e r n a t i o n a l M o n e t a r y 
Fu n d s sale of 25 million ounces to ra ise d e v e lo p ­ ment fund s for poor n a ­ tions. The se rie s of a u c ­ ti o n s s t a r t e d in t h e spring of 1975.

Viet loan eyed 

WASHINGTON POST StRVICf 

WASHINGTON - T h e World Ban k rep or ted W e d n e sd a y it has u n d e r co n­ sid erati o n r e q u e s t s by V ie tn a m for subsidized loan s to help reb uild its war-torn economy. 
A b a n k mission, which r e tu rn e d to 
Washington last w eek after sp en d in g about a m o n th in Hanoi and els ewhere in V ietn a m , describ ed its visit “ as a useful an d c o n stru c tiv e start to the b a n k 's relati on ship with unified Viet­ n a m . " 
Pri v ate ly , b an k so u r c e s said it is c le ar the outlook for a loan is good. 
In a formal pre ss release, itself an indication of a positive reaction by b ank off icials. \ i e t n a m e s e officials w e r e q u o t e d a s c o n s i d e r i n g t h e i r country “ to be part of an e x p a n d in g international tr a d in g s y s t e m . ” 
V ie tn a m e se le ade rs who met with the han k mission also said they “ look forward to c onstru cti ve eco no mic e x ­ c h a n g e s with all c o u n tr ie s .” 
Accepted m em ber 
T h e Socialis t R e p u b l i c of V i e tn a m was ac cepted as a m e m b e r of both the

Big bull

S prings.

515 No. Main 
226-72o) 

County supports an aquifer laws study 

A resolution asking for a legislative study of possible new Kdwards aquifer safeguard laws drew support from 
Commissioners Court Wednesday. 
Court support cam e following a plea from Mrs. Rowena Rogers, spokesman for the League of Women Voters. 
As Mrs. Rogers outlined the propo­ sal, State Rep. Run Bird intends to submit a resolution asking the legisla­ ture for creation of a special interim com m ittee in study the need lur few 

Civilian is needed for this position 

WARMINGTON St Ak SliV lC t 
WASHINGTON - Defense Depart­ ment manpower officials are consi­ dering hiring civilians for a job Ute armed forces seem unable to handle: 
Giving servicem en and women an adequate picture of what their salaries and benefits are worth. 
Gen. George S. Brown, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, has told 
Congress it should wait a year while the services promote program s to eliminate some members perception of erosion of benefits. 
A recent Defense Department survey of all services showed that more than half of the service members polled felt they could make more money in civi­ lian life. 
M ilitary o ffic ia ls b elie v e that outsiders could prepare a much better public relations package than someone involved directly in the service. 

 legislation to protect the purity and adequacy of the water in Kdwards aquifer studies. 
That committee also will study find­ ings from several on-going aquifer studies. 
H ater source 

The aquifer, running north and west through seven counties, currently is the sole source of water for San An­ tonio.

Oswald letter probed by FBI 

DALLAS (AP) - The 
FBI is in v estig a tin g a letter reportedly written by Lee Harvey Oswald to the late Dallas billionaire 
LLL. Hunt asking about 
.Oswald’s “ position'' on 
Nov. 8, 1982, two weeks before President John F. 
Kennedy was assassinat­ ed. 
A spokesm an for the 
FBI in Dallas said the letter was in their hands and was under investiga­ tion. 
“ T h a t’s all we can say,’’ he stated. 
Asked when the letter reached the FBI office here, he replied. “To my knowledge, a few weeks ago.’’ 
According to the New 
York D aily N ew s, the letter said: 
“ Dear Mr. Hunt; 
"I would like informa­ tion concerning my posi­ tion. I am asking only for information. I am su g ­ gesting that we discuss the matter, fully before any steps are taken by me or anyone else. Thank you.” 

Comparison 

A com p arison of the handw ritten note with sa m p les of O sw a ld ’s handwriting has led in­ vestigators to conclude that it was w ritten by 
Oswald or someone who could imitate his hand­ writing 
E arlier this month there were reports that a copy of the letter had been sent to a retired 
Texas editor. Pent Jones, at Midlothian. Tex., by an unidentified source in 
Mexico City. Jones said the source had sent an accompanying letter say­ ing he had given a copy of the letter to FBI director 
Clarence Kelley in 1974, but had received no re­ sponse. 
Jones said he answered the letter, but never heard from his source again,

War vet, antiwar activist to head federal agencies 

WASHINGTON (A P) - President t arler paid tribute W ednesday to a triple-am putee hero of the Vietnam 
War and to one of the leading antiwar 
Betis toto when both men were sworn in to head federal agencies 

"I dun I think we could have two more startling contrasts among young m en ,” Carter said as the am putee, 
.Maxwell Cli land, was installed as head of the Veterans* Administration, and 
Sam Brown, leader of at a n tiw a r march un Washington, became tty rec- 
Un of ACTION. 

At an Oval Office ceremony, t arter said American Involvement in V iet­ nam and Cambodia had “ torn apart” 

 the nation and that men like Brown and Cleland look different paths to dem onstrate “ their d isp lea su re or their commitment ” lie said Brow ii, 33-year old former treasurer of Colorado, “ engaged in a form of civil combat*’ as leader of an­ tiwar demonstrators who “ showed a gri’at deal of courage ” 
As for the 34-year-old C leland, a former member of the Georgia Senate. 
Carter said the Vietnam veteran had volunteered for service there although he had already earned a masters de­ gree in college and did not have to go. 
He said Cleland was gravely wounded when lie threw hmisell un a live gren­ ade.

L o o s e d o g s 

Help' Could you please advise me on what can hi* done about this family iii our neighborhood who own two dogs. 
Every day these dogs are let out of their fenced yard so they can deposit their mess on our yards across tin* st md. 
We don’t want to clean up after their dogs anymore. These dogs don’t even have their shots. 
Thank von for any help. 
CONCERNED FAM ILIES AC ROSS THE STREET 
A spokesman from the city dog pound said they cruise areas and pick up loose dogs that are on ci­ ty property. 
There is a city ordin­ ance requiring dogs to be kept in fenced yards or tied up in a place that is not city property. 
If they are not in a fenced yard or tied up. the> must be on a leash. 
The city dog pound will pick up a loose dog on your property if you file a 

 complaint at Municipal 
Court and the judge decides the dog must be picked up. 

In most cases, though, the judge will ask the owner to either tie up the dog or turn it over to someone who can care for it properly if it is the first complaint. 

To file a complaint, contact the city prosecutor at Municipal 
Court. 

D ead b attery 

In August, 197K. my son bought a battery for his 
1974 ear. Now the battery is completely clead and will not take a charge. 
He has hist the receipt and when I took it back to the dealership where the battery was purchased, they told me they would not replace it even though it has the purchase date stamped on the battery. 
Their reason is that he has to have the receipt to get the faulty battery made* good. This is a company product. 
After being shuffled between parts and service departments, they finally said, “ No receipt, no exchange.’’ 
I would like the address of the office in charge of importing these cars and their parts. I carried the battery into the dealership this month, so the battery is still under warranty. c. o. w. battery, two years, is on­ ly good if you have the date stamp and the receipt number. You cannot cash in on the warranty without either one.

PRICE 
NOT QUALITY 

ALL STORES 
OPEN TO SERVE YOU

SAVI ON 

The company policy of no receipt, no exchange is printed at the top of the receipt. It says. “ All claims and returned goods must he accom­ panied by this hill. No refunds after IO days." 
A spokesman said if vou would hate brought the battery in within IO days without a receipt, he probably could have ex­ changed it because he would hate had his copy oi the receipt then.

THURSDAY IO A.M. - 8 P.M 

Robinson 

Scandal rum ors 

 interest b ook ies 

His real name cannot be used for obvious reasons. We will call him Tom . He is a big-tim e' bookie in a major Texas city. 

Like most bookmakers and basket­ ball fans in this country, he was inter­ ested in an item which appeared in 
E arl W ilson’s nationally syndicated column Tuesday. 
To quote Wilson, "T h e hush-hush rumors of a basketball scandal have made everybody nervous with millions of dollars and formidable nam es in­ volved in g a m b lin g on a nation al scale.” 
Wilson doesn’t say if this alleged scandal involves college or pro teams. 
Officials of the NBA and NC AA don’t even like to talk about such possibi­ lities. To them, scandal is the worst four-letter word in the book. 

Tom, who was contacted through sources in S.A., was hesitant to talk about the possibility of "fixing” games or paying players to shave points. 

Not until he was promised that his real nam e would not be used or re ­ vealed did he agree to discuss the subject. 
He talked mostly about the NBA. 
" It’s easier to fix an NBA game than a college gam e.” he told me. "This is because pro athletes are money o r­ iented. To som e of them , money is everything. ” 
Tom does not know for a fact that there is a scandal in pro basketball this season but he is quick to point out that 
" t h e r e is so m e th in g w ron g, real wrong. Things just don’t add up." 
He is referring to the trem endous edge for home teams. At one point this season, home te a m s w ere winning about 75 per cent of NBA games. 

Maybe mental 

The best ones are losing to the worst ones on the road. There is no consis­ tency although m ore visiting team s have been winning recently. 
“ A lot of guys are saying that games are fixed in the NBA this year. I t s because of the home te a m ’s ad v an ­ ta g e .” says Tom. 
"Like I said, though. I don’t know anything about it. It s possible that they are fixed but. personally, I don’t think so. It'd have to be a big, real big operation. 
"I think the big advantage to the home team is mostly a mental thing with the players. Let’s face it. some of those guys are pretty dumb. (Bleep), they’re real dumb. 
"T he season starts with the home team winning almost every game. The players hear everyone talking about winning at home, losing on the road — everybody is doing it. 
“ So they start thinking that as long as they win at home, they aren’t sup­ posed to win on the road. They figure if other teams are losing on the road, it s okay for them to do it, too. 

"Like I said. I think B's mostly mental. But I will tell you one thing — there is definitely something wrong. 
Ifs either a fluke thing bv nature, or something wrong is going on.” insists 
Tom. 

"T h ere is always one safe way to know what is going on in sports," he continued. "L as Vegas. You can tell what is happening in sports by seeing what’s happening in Vegas. 
"Know what they’re doing in Vegas now?” he asks. "You won t believe it, not if you know anything about gam ­ bling. I f s so bad that in Vegas you have to lay ti-5 (put up $8 to win 15) and the maximum is $2oo.” 
In cast* you are a non-gambler, the usual rate is ll I -$1o “ In other sports in Vegas ifs $11-$H) with the sky the limit." says our friendly bookmaker. 
“ You know that there is something real wrong when you can bet more money in Texas than you can in Vegas. 
'That’s true. You can get a lugger bet on an NBA game in San Antonio than you can in Vegas." 

Bad business 

Tom says that bookmakers are being run out of business because of the home teams winning so much. 
" I t’s ridiculous. It was the same way this past football season. For example. if you had bet $2tMI on every game, and taken the fa v o rite each lim e . you would have made at least $5o,ooo.” he says. 
“ You bet the di gs this year, either football or basketball, and you lose big,” he adds. "It killed the ixxtks, It put them out of business. 

“ I’d say that DO per cent of the bet ting in Texas is just straight bels. 
Most people just don’t know a bookie. 
(hey bet with each other.” 

The home court edge now means up to five points on the betting line. ac­ cording to Tom. “ Tuesday night the line was the Knicks two over the Spurs. 
But because they played in the Garden, the line went up as high Os seven and one-half." he explains. 
E arl W ilson m ig ht know all the details about a major scandal iii bas­ ketball but Tom says he is not sun* what the problem is. **All I know is everybod.v is talking because there is something wrong. Maybe i f s the re­ ferees. Maybe a mental thing with the players. Maybe the coaching. Maybe som ebody is being bought. I t s so­ mething we can’t put our finger on 
“ But something is wrong.”

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 

LOS ANGELES — Trinity, rebound­ ing from an upset loss to Southern 
Methodist,‘Stunned Southern Califor­ nia. 6-3, in a dual m en’s tennis match 
Tuesday. 
It was the second time the Tigers have bumped off the NCAA Tennis 
Coaches’ top rated team . E arlier, 
Trinity heat Southern Cal. 7-2, in the finals of the National Collegiate Team tournament. 
Tony G iam m alva got the Tigers started with a 7-5, 6-4. win over the 
Trojans’ top player. Bruce Manson, in the number one singles. 
Larry Gottfried, who suffered his first individual match loss in that 6-3 setback to SMU in Corpus Christi, began slow but eventually subdued 
Chris Lewis. 
Gottfried lost the first set, 2-6, but won the dividing two sets, 6-4, 7-6. 
Ben McKown and Erick Iskorskv quickly gave Trinity a 4-o advantage. 
McKown beat Andy Lucchcsi, 6-4. 7-5, and Iskersky outlasted Earl Prince, 
6-1, 2-6, 6-4. 
Southern Cal. however, got back into 

NfcW YORK TIMES SERVICE 

NEW VORK - Larry O’Brien, the commissioner of the Nation­ al Basketball Association, has warned coaches and players that a continuation of "punching and fighting will be met with stern measures” by his office, includ­ ing ejections from the gam e, fines and suspensions. 

Showing concern about the recent rash of violence involving some of the g a m e ’s biggest nam es, the com m is­ sioner threatened to take action last week in a m em o ran d u m to g eneral managers and coaches. 
Then, Mike Bantam of the New York 
Nets floored Marv in Barnes of the De­ troit P isto n s last F rid a y , and now’ there are rep orts that even s te rn e r penalties to curb violence are being contemplated. They are expected to he presented soon to the club owners for approval.

By MIKE BRUTON 
OE THE EXPRESS STAEE . 
Dinggggg. dinggggg. Ladies and gentlemen, the 1977 San Antonio Re­ gional (tolden Gloves Boxing Tour­ nament is about lo commence. 
At 7:3(1 p.m. Thursday, Friday and 
Saturday, the Municipal Auditorium will be lilied w ith the sig h ts and sounds of am ateur boxing. 

GG Po iring*, l\ig c Th 

T here will be novice and open d i­ visions. each having ll weight classes. 
Thursday night s card shows 34 bouts. 
So, what’s new? 
Well, for openers, the matches will be judged with a five-man Olympic boxing system , instead of the three- 

 man setup 
"T hat s going to he a significant difference,’’ said assistant tournament director Jack Harris. "You should get more accurate decisions.” 
Harris said a clinic was held earlier in the week for all tin' Golden Gloves officials to “ review rules in general." 
"None of the officials are connected in any way with any boxing clubs or 

 organizations in this area," Harris ad­ ded. “ We should have unbiased re ­ sults. 
"It should be much more organized this year and I’m hoping the public will enjoy it “ 
No doubt, with 34 bouts on opening night, there should be some scrappy ones. But th e re are two binits on

Spurs becoming 
TV celebrities 

CBS television has decided to televise another 
Spur game regionally, it was announced Wednesday. 
The Sunday. Mar. 13 game between the Spurs and 
Detroit Pistons will tx* regionally televised from the 
Arena, beginning at 12:45. 
This will be the seventh time for CBS to televise the Spurs — five i i i the Arena and two on the road 
Only the Philadelphia 76crs, with eight, have had more games televised than the Spurs this season. 
So fur, S A. is undefeated oil CBS, winning all six televised games. 
Tickets for Tuesday’s game against Phoenix and the Mar. 13 outing with Detroit are on sale at the 
Arena box office, or bv calling 224-957H The ticket booth is o|x*n daily from 9 a in until 5 p.m.

HOUSTON - This y e a r ’s 
Baylor basketball season sounds like a plot from a daytime soap opera. 
The Bears, picked by some to finish atop the Southwest Conference, win their first three SWC games. 
Then. the heartbreak comes. 
Baylor, at home, loses a one-point game to Texas AAM on a last-second shot by Steve Jones. Six days later in 
Dallas, the Bears blow a 14-point lead and lose to 
S o uthern 
Methodist. 
Two days after the 
SMU defeat, 
Head 
Coach Carroll Dawson unexpectedly resigns. 
One week later, guard 
Tony Rufus, fo rm er 
SWC newcomer of the year rn his freshman season, quits the team and leaves school. 
But San Antonio's Arthur Edwards, a tumor forward on the Baylor squad, suns the team has su rv iv ed th ese problems and now wants to erase the bad memories of a 5-11 SWC slate and a se v e n th -p la c e finish in the conference. 
* We have new life." Edwards said 
Wednesday as he and tin* other B ears prepared for Thursday’s SVN <' Tourna­ ment encounter with Texas Tech, the winner of last year’s inaugural tour­ ney. "I really believe we have a chance lo win this. 
"We have gotten ourselves together now. We have regrouped. Losing Coach 
Dawson was a big shock to everybody 
Then, Tony quit. But I was not su r­ prise! by his decision. 
"Oh, I was surprised that In* quit before th** end of the season. But he waa not playing at all aud did not want to sit on the bench 
Edwards, an all-state perform er at 
Brackenridge, was the* Bears* second leading scorer this year, averaging 
15.8 points per game and ranking lith 

 i i i the SWC in that category 
He was tops in field goal percentage at Baylor with a 54 3 murk and was the

NEW YORK (A F ) - Scott LeDoux found the range with his right-hand povvdr in the late rounds and came on to pound out a split. 1o-round decision over Pedro Soto in the featured hea­ vyweight fight Wednesday night at 
Madison Square Garden. 
.Judge Sam Irom scored it 5-4-1 for 
LeDoux and referee .Johnny LoBianco favored him 6-4. .Judge Arty Aidala scored it 7-3 for Soto. 
In one of the three co-features. Hon 
Harris, 158Va. of Canton. Ohio, a 1968 

Olympic Gold Medal winner, boxed his way to an easy 1o-round decision over 
Sugar Ray Seales. 158. of Seattle, a 
1972 Olympic Gold Medalist. 
In two other 1o-rounders. M ike 
Rossman. 173. of Turnersville, closed the left eye of Ray Anderson. 174, of 
Akron, Ohio, and won when the referee stopped the fight after the fourth round on the advice of a ringside doctor. 
Harold Weston, .lr., 145^. of New 
York, won a unanimous decision over 
Jim m y Heiar, 144, El Puso. 

Rattlers sweep 
Oklahoma City 

By HARRY FAGE 
OF THE EXPRESS STAFF 

Greg Krueiak and Art Perez com­ bined for a one-bitter in the first game as St. Mary’s snapped a three-game losing streak by sweeping Oklahoma 
City University. 5-2 and 3-1, at V .J. 
Keefe Field Wednesday. 
Boh Wagner scattered five hits, walked three, and struck out three in the nightcap. 
Krueiak pitched hitless ball for 5Va innings before running into control problems. 
Chuck Page’s two-out single past the out-stretched glove of reserve third baseman Mike Krupski off Perez spoiled the combined no-hit bid in the top of the seventh and final inning. 
Danny Beep slammed a two-run single in the first inning and a HBI single in the fifth to spark St. M ary’s 
1o-hit attack. Charlie* Migl drove in another run with a double. 

Julies Mopier tripled and singled and 
Mike Zamora doubled to boost the 
Rattlers in the opener. 

Ted Trevino, d ay Slolte. and Marty 
Zolkoski eac h collected two singles as 
St. Mary’s again erupted for IO hits off loser Tucson Redd and reliever Roil 
Smith in the second game. 

Migl sliced a run-scoring single and 
Stolte walked with the bases-loaded as the Rattlers provided all the runs 
Wagner needed in the first inning of the second game. Paul Tejeda scored on a wild pitch for St. M ary’s final run in the second inning. 
St. Mary's, which meets Baylor in a doubleheader Friday at Keefe Field, is 
3-4. Oklahoma City was opening its season. 
“ We should have blown them out both games.’’ said Elm er Kosub, St. 
Mary’s coach. "W e still left too many men on the bases.”

7 OUT OF EVERY 8 
VOLVO BUYERS ARE 
TEST DRIVERS. 

But foolhardy, they’re not. 
That’s why 87% of the thinking people who bought Volvos in 1976 insisted on a test drive before buying.(Or leasing...a financial alternative we can easily arrange.) 
They wanted to see if the car performed up to their expectations. And if it handled as well in the real world as the salesman said it would back at the Volvo dealership. 
Obviously, these cautious people decided that our car had passed their test. 
So while our Volvo showroom is an excellent place to ask questions,examine and price a 
Volvo, it’s out on the road—behind the wheel— where most people buy them.

The Rattlers left seven in the first game and IO in the second game. 
“ We’re still not getting the consis­ tent timely hitting when we need it." 
Beep added. “ W e’ll be all right as the season progresses. ’ ’ 
Krueiak. after getting the first batter out. walked five of the next seven bat­ ters he faced in the seventh inning before exiting for the showers. 
" I guess I ’m getting old,” kidded the former All-City left hander from St. 
Gerard’s. “ Really, though, the entire pitching staff hasn’t had enough mound work in practice.’’ 
“ The pitch that dude hit (Page) was around the letters,” Perez added. “ He just swung down on it and chopped it out of the infield. It wasn’t a bad pitch.” 
Duane Haynes and Glynn Tschirhart had both walked before Hoop delivered his two-out single to left. Singles by the pair set up the big three-run fifth inning. Haynes scored on a throwing error, Tschirhart rode home on Migl's double, and Beep singled Migl home with his single to right. 
Haynes got things started in the second with a single and a stolen base with one-out in first inning. He scored on 
Migl's two-out single. 
Tejeda walked, went to second on Paul Szy- marek’s infield single, move to third on a sacrifice by Haynes, and scored or 
Sm ith ’s wild ball four pitch to 
Tschirhart in the second inning.

( ’heils’ lone run in the fifth.

Broncs upset 
NTS 
DENTON (A P ) - Pan 
A m erican, led by M i­ chael Edwards with 27 points, put a cloud over 
North 
Texas State's post-season basketball tournament hopes. 86-72,- at the 
“ Super 
P it ” 
Wednesday night. 
Henry Taylor added 26 to the Broncs cause and 
Randy Woods 23. 
The Broncs broke away in the final seven min­ utes of what had been a close game, outscoring the Mean Green. 17-5 at the end. Edwards hit se­ ven of his points in the last Pan American surge. 
The lead bounced back and forth in the first half and Pan American led by only one. 68-67. with 6:45 left. But North Texas hit a cold streak and ended their NCAA and N IT hopes. 
North Texas hit only 37 per cent in the second hull while Pan American was hitting 54 per cent. 
Walter Johnson hit 21 and Mel Daws had 18 for 
North Texas. 
Pun American finished the season 17-9 and North 
Texas ended al 21-6

SAN ANTONIO EXPRESS— Thursday March 3 1977 
H 

Outdoors 

 w ith Hun K l^ p p e r 

Webb buck permit system successful 

Tho buck permit system, an experimental management pro­ gram initiated last season in 
Webb County, resulted in an increase in the doe deer kill. 
And that was something biolo­ gists wanted to do. 

“ We are extremely encouraged with the increased doe kill.” said Charles 
\\ inkier, big game program director for the Parks and Wildlife Department after viewing preliminary results of the kill. 
“ lf the doe kill continues to increase. we will be able to reduce the herd to the carrying capacity of the range as well as have a well-balanced sex ratio m the overall population.” 
An estimated 2.793 bucks were taken last season in Webb County. The doe kill was approximately I.(IHT. an in­ crease of 125 per cent over the 1975 doe harvest of 475. 

W inkler pointed out that the doe 

 harvest has increased almost IOO per cent in the county oxer the last three seasons. 

Biologists want to shift some of the gun pressure from bucks to does. The average age of bucks killed in Webb has been decreasing as younger and younger bucks are killed. If more bucks are given an opportunity to at­ tain some age. they w ill be better trophies. 
The issuance of perm its on an acreage basis was assisted by the weather iii decreasing the buck kill. 
Many hunters were severely hampered by muddy conditions in Webb and most other counties in South Texas. 
Redistribute the harvest 
Intent of the permit system is to re­ distribute the harvest of bucks by re­ ducing excessive kills on sm all ranches. 
“ Hunters on the small ranches were killing more deer than the land was able to produce,“ Winkler said. “ The harvest data gathered so far indicates these ranches are harvesting closer to their buck-raising potential. 

A total of MW landowners represent­ ing 2.1 million acres drew permits last season. The permits were issued on the basis of one for every 23o acres of land, livery landowner was entitled to re­ ceive at least one permit regardless of the size of his ranch. 

“ Although our results are still ten­ tative. since not all landowners have returned their permits, there was a definite redistribution of the buck kill in the county,” Winkler said. 
“ At the same time, there was a de­ cline in the deer harvest, which was expected." 
Prelim inary estimates were based on a 63 per cent return of cards sent to landowners at the end of the season. 
“ If the pattern of harvesting more does continues and more young bucks are allowed to reach trophy size. the permit system s goal will have been accomplished." Winkler said. ll will be interesting to see what ef- 
1‘ects the permit system will have dor- 

C le m e n s’ girls n a m e d 

 to state to u r n e y te a m 

 mg a normal (reasonably dry) season when hunters can get into pastures without getting stuck. I suspect the mud reduced the buck kill in most of the Brush Country. 
Bad winter killed wildlife 
Wild animals, birds and fish appar­ ently suffered severe losses in the north this winter, reports Ray Card, outdoor editor of the South Bend. Ind., 
Tribune. 
“ The Indiana Department of Natural 
Resources is just beginning to get the total picture together.” he said, “ and it looks pretty bleak for mourning doves and quail, which have been found dead in large numbers through­ out northern Indiana.” 
A farmer who lives west of South 
Bend told Gard, “ I don’t think we’ve got a song bird left." Snow was still hip deep on level ground the middle of 
February. 

.Muskrats, unable to live in ponds 

 and swamps frozen all the way to the bottom have moved into barns in rural areas, searching for something to eat, and raccoons, forced out of dens by hunger, froze to death in their wea­ kened condition. 

(lard said all farm ponds eight feet or less in depth probably froze solid, killing fish. Even in lakes deep enough to keep from freezing to the bottom, fish kills are occurring. 
Deep snow on the frozen surfaces blocks sunlight, and oxygen-producing aquatic life dies. The fish suffocate from lack of oxygen. 
Even city song birds have had prob­ lems, especially in the extremely high winds, tine woman told Gard that she watched a bluejay try to eat from her feeder, but the bird couldn’t hold on in the wind. It finally fell backward into the snow .

Player in

ROSE PENKUNIS 
Redfish 
|- legislation delayed 

EXPRESS CAPITOL BUREAU 

A U ST IN - Com mer­ cial and sports fishermen appeared in droves 
Wednesday before the 
Senate 
N atural 
R e­ sources Committee to fight over the coastal redfish. 
Their fight was cen­ tered over legislation be­ ing proposed by State 
Sen. 
A R . 
“ Bab e” 
Schwartz of Galveston to limit the redfish catch by commercial and sports fishermen. 
Schwartz/ Senate Bill 
624 is officially called the 
Texas Red Drum Con­ servation Act. 
Overharvested 

He said he proposed the measure because of evidence compiled by the 
Texas Parks and Wildlife 
Department that redfish are being over ha nested. 
After a long round of testimony, Schwartz said he would delay his bill in committee for about a week in order to make some changes. 
The legislation would restrict com m ercial fi­ shermen to a daily catch of IOO pounds of redfish and impose a slight li­ cense fee increase to sports fishermen, lim it­ ing their catch as well. 
“ A daily lim it is im ­ practical and would se- verly hurt the industry by cutting its catch by as much as one half," said 
Jim Pace, a Brownsville fish company owner. 
On the other hand, a sports fisherm an who said he had fished redfish I for over 2o years, said. 
" lf they could, commer­ cial fishermen would j catch every last redfish today and gripe about it tomorrow because there’s no more left." 
Popular 

The red drum fish is ; popular among sports fi- j shermen and is one of the most m arketable sea- j fluids in Texas. 
Bodfish are harvested along the Texas coastline mostly in the southern waters of Laguna Madre. 
The fish has provided a livelihood for com m er­ cial fishermen for years. 
Bob Kemp, fisheries director with the Parks and W ild life D epart­ ment, was the only wit­ ness to appear before the 
Committee on behalf of 
Schwartz’ legislation. 
Kemp said a recently completed fish census made by the fisheries cli- 
Alston indicates redfish are being subjected to heavy fishing pressures. 
Although the fish has not been placed on the endangered species list, 
Kemp noted, “ the classic symptoms of oxer-fishing exist.” 
“ In the past large schools of redfish were often sighted in the gulf and today they are no longer seen ” 

SPECIAL TO THE EXPRESS 
AUSTIN — Forward Rose Penkunis and guard Sylvia Godfrey of Clemens have been named to the girls’ All-State 
Tournament basketball team s by writers covering the tournament last weekend. 
Krista Irxxin of Devine made the AA 
All-Tournament team. 
Four performers in Class AAAA al! came from state champion Dallas 
South Oak Cliff, forwards Lorretta 
Lister and Anita Foster and guards 
Pam Green and Barbara Brown. All but Brown xviii return next year. 
Rounding out the eight-player AAAA squad are Ann Moon of Angleton and 
Lori Gray of Arlington.

THE 
TRUCKERS 
CHOICE 

 f t ’s ruggers, not muggers 

BRUTON 

By M IR K BRUTON 
Of THE EXPRESS STAFF 
They come from varying 
(backgrounds, races, nationa­ lities, socio-economic levels and 
[professions. 

If you meet them on the field, they 
Iwill try to knock the daylights out of you and a few hours later they will sit and have a genuinely friendly talk with 
I you over a beer. 
They are doctors, florists, engineers, 

I football coaches, computer scientists, 
I students and businessmen. 
But there is one thing they all have in common — they are winners! 
The San Antonio 
Rugby Club is an amateur, fraternal or­ ganization that has made itself known from Canada to the 
Bahamas. 
The organization is not rolling in funds. In fact, most of their ex­ penses come out of their own pockets. 
The SA RC has only two sponsors, 
Apache Distributing Company and 
Bexar County Savings. 
On the weekend of Feb. 19-2o, San 
Antonio played in one of the top rugby tournaments in the nation, with some of the best teams in the Western He­ misphere and won it. 
It was the Mardi Gras Rugby Tour­ nament in New Orleans, which limits its invitations to only eight teams. 
In the tourney was Team Canada, a touring side of high prestige, George­ town University of Washington IXC., 
Boston College, Denison College of 
Ohio, the Tulane Blue side and Green side, a team from the Bahamas and the 
South Texas ruggers. 
The SARC, defending state cham­ pions, were riding a 2o-game winning streak after the Houston Boars forfeit­ ed to San Antonio on Feb. 28. 
In Texas Rugby Union competition, the club’s official league, the SABU is 
3-o this season and has scored 98 points while allowing its opponents only four. 
The local rugby club sounds like a bunch of guys who rigidly sticks to training rules, hard work and concen­ trates solely on playing and winning the games. 
Not exactly, because when you get around these guys you quickly learn the winning instinct and competitive attitude is there but ranked way above 

E X iC U T IV i 26 
THI PERFORMANCE R A D IO 
BUILT O N THE F A M O U S C O B R A 
29 CH A SSIS PLUS RF G A IN 

 c o b r a ars 

 av t*. 
<£> kb

. , i fc. - 

SARC p lays intra-squad m atches with the sam e intensity as a re g u la r g a m e , w hich h e lp s k e e p the injury rate extrem ely high p h o to by ric h a rd c r o w th e r 

 all is fun and brotherhood. 
Sounds a little corny, but it is true. 
Steve Ewing, a 26-year-old engineer who plays the wing for SARC, vividly describes the comradery that grips the soul of every member of this outfit. 
“ It s really addictive,” exclaimed 
Ewing. “ When I first came to San An­ tonio about three years ago, someone told me to come and watch a rugby game. I didn’t know the first thing about the sport. 
“ But before I knew it I was out there playing. It s an incredibly friendly bunch of guys,” he added. 
Bob Collins, a data processing manager, described the rugby club as a form of escape. “ We’re just a bunch of guys who want to get away from the work world every once and a while and 

 go out and have fun. I f s a social thing.” 
Collins went further, explaining that the togetherness of the organization exte: farther than the playing field. 
“ The injury rate is extremely high in rugby," he said. “ Some of the older guys end up being referees after being 
I .S. w ins 

Q U EBEC (A P ) - The 
United States downed 
Norway 1o-7 and Sweden defeated previously un­ beaten 
Canada 
1o-4 
Wednesday in a fourth round games of the 
World .Junior Curling 
Championships at Laval 
University. 

 hurt so much, hut they still remain a part of the team. 
G ra d y H o c rm a n n , a f o r m e r All- 
S o u th w e s t C o n feren ce m id d le lin e ­ backer at Texas A&M, said, “ You want to do som ething after you get out of college and most people turn to tennis or jogging hut rugby is a good sport. 
A top contributor on the San Antonio side, Hoermann also commented, “ It s every bit as rough as football and it s exciting for everyone that plays be­ cause anyone can score. ’ 
Competition 
Larry Gallego, the SARC’s answer to the Dr. .I of rugby, said, “ The whole thing about rugby is to get people out there to compete, and then later, talk to them and enjoy their company. 
“ You might knock the hell out of them in the game, hut once that game is over you sit down and have a beer with them.” 
Gallego, who scored 28 points in the 
Mardi Gras tourney, was voted to the 
Western All-Star team by the U.S. 
Rugby Union this past season. 
Hoermann, who played with greats like Dave Elm endorf of the Los 
Angeles Rams and Brad Dusek of the 
Washington Redskins while at Texas 
A&M, threw in this comment about 
Gallego. “ He’s probably got as much ability as anybody I played with in college.” 
Modest 
Gallego, who played on the nation s top collegiate rugby team in 1972. 
Texas A&M, was very modest about his achievements. 
“ I score so much because I ’m a kicker. Kickers get a chance to score on conversions like in football and penalty kicks if they’re in range of the goal. 
If you want to see about 35 or 4o rugged, friendly gents, then go out to the Olmos Park athletic field on any 
Tuesday or Thursday afternoon or Sa­ turdays when home games are scheduled. There you will find the San 
Antonio Rugby Club.__________________

Shapc-ls Itc-auliful G irin-—Fee l B e tte r Fan! 

Kuhn, 
Finley meet 

D A LL A S 
(A P ) 
— 
Baseball Commissioner 
Bowie Kuhn met with 
Oakland 
A ’s owner 
Charles Finley for almost three hours Wednesday to determine whether the sale of reliever Paul 
Lindblad to the Texas 
Rangers was a part of 
Finley plan to liquidate his assets. 
Kuhn said he would have a decision promptly on the legality of the matter. 
“ I would not make a decision today, but it could be tomorrow,” said 
Kulm when asked whether the SCHUMM) deal for the left-hander 
Lindblad stands. 

Optimist 
Both Finley and Texas 
Ranger vice president 
Fddie Robinson were op­ timistic that the Lindblad sale would go through. 
“ 'l our guess is as good as mine, hut I didn't come out with any scars, did I? " said Finley. 
Finley lawyer Neil Pa- piano said, "we are more confident he (Lindblad) w ill lie a Ranger,” 
Papiano said the meet- ing “ was an extension of the vendetta going on against Mr. Finley. Fin ­ ley wanted Kulm re­ placed as commissioner and Kuhn wants Finley out of baseball.” 

No vendetta 
Kulm said. “ It would take a little time to eva­ luate the evidence to see if the Lindblad sale is part of a Finley plan to liquidate his player as­ sets. There is no vendetta against Mr. Finley. 
"The issue is whether 
Lindblad is part of a plan lo liquidate the club.” 
The meeting was held on the lith floor of a 
Dallas hotel at the airport in a circus-like atmosphere with some 3o reporters and photo­ graphers sprawled out side the two doors of the room. 
The reporters took turns peering through a peephole and some picked up parts of con­ versations listening at 
Hie door. . 
Papiano said that the hearing “ was ludicrous. 
There is no reason why the Lindblad sale should not Im1 approved. The li­ quidation thing is a fig­ ment of (K u h n 's) im a­ gination You never know what the commissioner will do.”

Rivers, Yanks settle their differences 

ASSOCIATED PRESS 
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. 
— The New York Y ankees 
Wednesday reached an under­ standing with disgruntled out­ fielder Mickey Rivers but or­ dered holdout reliever Sparky 
Lyle to report immediately to camp. 

Rivers was the cause celebre Tues­ day when he said he was being hassled and wanted to be traded. 
A 15-minute meeting with Yankee 
Manager Billy Martin and President 
(>abe Paul Wednesday apparently smoothed over the situation. 
“ Any misunderstanding has been cleared up.” said Paul. who says he has no intention of trading his fleet center fielder. “ I don’t anticipate anv problems with M ickey?’ 
“ I don’t want to be traded,” said 
Rivers. “ We talked about things. We came to a conclusion and I feel a lot better.” 
Lyle. 32, is not happy with his con­ tract following his PITH season, in which he had 23 saves— tops in the 
American League— a 7-8 record and a 
2.23 earned run average. 
Because of inconsistency, he was not used much in the late season or in postseason play. 
On Wednesday, the Yankees sent a telegram to Lyle's New Jersey home, saying they were renewing his contract and directing him to report to camp immediately. 
Paul declined to discuss Lyle's ren­ ewed contract, but it was believed the lefthanded pitcher’s salary was cut the, maximum 2o per cent. 
Lyle is one of nine unsigned 
Yankees. 
(Cardinals 
ST. P K T E R S B t’RG, Fla. (A P ) - 
Right-hander Larry Dierker will be on the mound for the St. Louis Cardinals* 
March 12 exhibition baseball opener against the New York Mets, the Car­ dinals said Wednesday. 
Dierker, the former mainstay of the 
Houston Astros, also is a prime candi­ date for the “ stopper” role in this year's bullpen, said pitching coach 
Claude Osteen. 
Thirty-nine players reported to the club's first full-scale spring training workout Wednesday, including new arrivals Je rry Mumphrey, Hector 
Cruz. and 
Tony 
Scott—all outfielders—and infielder Je rry l)e- 
\ anon. 
Only rookie infielder Esteban Cas­ tillo. stranded in tin* Dominican Re- bublic with visa problem s, was missing, the National League club said. 
O rio le * 
M IAM I (A P ) — Ken Singleton ar­ rived at the Baltimore Orioles’ spring training camp Wednesday and an­ nounced he would not begin workouts until he has signed a contract. 
Singleton said that he was close to agreeing on a five-year baseball con­ tract and would meet Thursday with 
General Manager Hank Peters. The 
2o-year-old right fielder is due to begin working out Friday. 
Singleton has led the club in hitting in each of the last two years. 
In another contractual matter, the 
Orioles annoucned that pitcher Rudy 
May was not actually signed. May was supposed to have signed a thrceyeur contract during the offseason. 
D odg er* 
YERO BEACH, Flu. (A P ) - Tommy 
John, who made a brilliant comeback in the 1976 baseball season, signed a oneyear contract Wednesday for 
$1oo,ooo, and immediately took part in tin* Dis Angeles Dodgers workout. 
John. 33. had wanted a three-year contract but the Bulgers refused. By signing for the one year. John, with 13 

 years in the majors, can. at his option. become a free agent at the close of the season. 
Manager Tommy Lasorda said he was impressed with the physical con­ dition of his club, citing only a few players slightly overweight. 
Newcomers Rick Monday and Mike 
Carman are two that Lasorda has asked to shed some weight. 
Tin* club's first intra-squad game will be Saturday. 

M el* 
ST. P E T E R S B U R G , Fla. (A P ) - 
The New York Mets' biggest problem this spring will be trying to put an outfield together. Manager Joe Frazier said Wednesday. 
“ A lot of it depends on the kid. Lee 
Mazzilli," Frazier said following a two-hour workout. “ We know he can catch a fly ball and he can run. We’ll have to wait and see how much he hits. lf he makes it, we are set in center and that will solve one of our big prob­ lems.” 
Mazzilli commanded a $3o,ooo bonus after being the club's No. I draft choice in June 1973. 
At Jackson, Miss., last year. Lee hit 
.292 with 13 homers, drew 111 bases on balls and stole 28 bases. 
In a 
September look with the Mets he bat­ ted .193 but hit two homers and stole five bases. 
P ira te * 
BRADENTON, Fla. (A P ) - Pitts­ burgh Pirate W illie Stargell says he thinks players who sign multi-year contracts owe it to their clubs and their fans to play their best baseball consis­ tently. 
“ Security can be good.” the 15-year veteran said as the Pirates began their first full-scale spring training drills 
Tuesday. 
“ But it’s up to each player who has signed for more than one year to use his integrity. It would be very bad for the game, for instance, if a player with a three-year contract took advantage and took it easy his first year.” 
The 36-year-old first baseman has always worked under a one-year con­ tract. Last year, when he hit a disap­ pointing .237, he reportedly was paid 
$165,ooo. 

A stro * 
COCOA. Fla. (A P ) — The Houston 
Astros announced Wednesday pitcher 
James Rodney Richard and outfielder 
Leon Roberts have signed their 1977 baseball contracts. 
The signings leaves only three un­ signed players on the 4o-man spring roster. They are infielder Rob An­ drews. catcher Joe Ferguson and pitcher Doug Konieczny. 

Hed So x 
W IN T E R H A V E N . Fla. ( A P ) - 
Ferguson Jenkins, the Boston Red Sox’ veteran pitcher attempting to come back from a torn achilles tendon, suffered a setback in training 
Wednesday ln*cause of soreness and swelling in his ankle. 
Dr. Thomas Tierney, the Red Sox’ physician, advised the 33-year-old 
Jenkins to rest the ankle for a few days. 

W h ite Sox 
SARASOTA, Fla. ( A P ) — Richie 
/ask. disturbed at the lack of move­ ment in contract efforts with the Chi­ cago White Sox, said Wednesday that he doesn’t feel the American League baseball club wants to sign him. 
“ I honestly don’t think they’re going to try to sign me. Maybe they only want me for one year,” said Zisk. “ It looks to me like the year of rent* aplayer over here.”
